Original: Per correr miglior acque alza le vele omai la navicella del mio ingegno, che lascia dietro a sé mar sì crudele
Translate: The ship of my ingenuity, by now, raises sails to travel better waters and leaves behind the cruel sea of Hell

Original: e canterò di quel secondo regno dove l’umano spirito si purga e di salire al ciel diventa degno
Translate: and I will sing of that second kingdom in which the human soul is purified and becomes worthy to ascend to heaven

Original: Ma qui la morta poesì resurga, o sante Muse, poi che vostro sono
Translate: But here the dead poetry rises, O holy Muse, since I am consecrated to you

Original: e qui Calïopè alquanto surga, seguitando il mio canto con quel suono di cui le Piche misere sentiro lo colpo tal, che disperar perdono
Translate: And here Calliope rose up somewhat, witnessing my song with the sound of which the wretched gazzes heard such a blow that they despaired to be forgiven.

Original: Dolce color d’orïental zaffiro, che s’accoglieva nel sereno aspetto del mezzo, puro infino al primo giro,
Translate: A sweet oriental sapphire color, which gathered in the serene aspect of pure air to the horizon,

Original: a li occhi miei ricominciò diletto, tosto ch’io usci’ fuor de l’aura morta che m’avea contristati li occhi e ’l petto
Translate: He gave joy to my eyes as soon as I came out of the dead air , which had saddened my eyes and heart

Original: Lo bel pianeto che d’amar conforta faceva tutto rider l’orïente, velando i Pesci ch’erano in sua scorta
Translate: The beautiful planet that pushes to love joyfully illuminated the whole east, clouding with its light the constellation of the Fishes that followed it

Original: I’ mi volsi a man destra, e puosi mente a l’altro polo, e vidi quattro stelle non viste mai fuor ch’a la prima gente
Translate: I turned to my right hand, and saw the southern sky, seeing four stars that no one saw except the first forefathers.

Original: Goder pareva ’l ciel di lor fiammelle
Translate: The sky seemed to enjoy their light

Original: oh settentrïonal vedovo sito, poi che privato se’ di mirar quelle
Translate: or boreal hemisphere, you're really sorry you can't see those stars

Original: Com’ io da loro sguardo fui partito, un poco me volgendo a l ’altro polo, là onde ’l Carro già era sparito,
Translate: As soon as I turned away my gaze from them, turning a little to the northern sky from where by now the Great Bear had set,

Original: vidi presso di me un veglio solo, degno di tanta reverenza in vista, che più non dee a padre alcun figliuolo
Translate: I saw a lonely old man beside me, who looked at him as respectful as what a son owes to his father.

Original: Lunga la barba e di pel bianco mista portava, a’ suoi capelli simigliante, de’ quai cadeva al petto doppia lista
Translate: He wore long beards and with white and black hairs, similar to his hair, of which two long braids fell on his chest.

Original: Li raggi de le quattro luci sante fregiavan sì la sua faccia di lume, ch’i’ ’l vedea come ’l sol fosse davante
Translate: The light of the four holy stars lit his face, to the point that I saw him as if he had the sun in front of him.

Original: «Chi siete voi che contro al cieco fiume fuggita avete la pregione etterna?»,
Translate: "Who are you, who, as you go up the underground river, have fled from the eternal prison?

Original: diss’ el, movendo quelle oneste piume
Translate: He told us, moving that dignified beard

Original: «Chi v’ha guidati, o che vi fu lucerna, uscendo fuor de la profonda notte che sempre nera fa la valle inferna?
Translate: Who has guided you and what has shown you the way, coming out of the deep night that always obscures the hell's chasm?

Original: Son le leggi d’abisso così rotte?
Translate: Are the laws of the abyss so worthless?

Original: o è mutato in ciel novo consiglio, che, dannati, venite a le mie grotte?»
Translate: Or in Heaven has a new law been enacted by which you, damned, come to the rocks that I keep?

Original: Lo duca mio allor mi diè di piglio, e con parole e con mani e con cenni reverenti mi fé le gambe e ’l ciglio
Translate: Then my teacher took hold of me, and with his words, his hands, and his gestures made me kneel down and look down.

Original: Poscia rispuose lui
Translate: Then he answered him

Original: «Da me non venni
Translate: I didn't come here on my own

Original: donna scese del ciel, per li cui prieghi de la mia compagnia costui sovvenni
Translate: A woman came down from Heaven, for whose prayers I helped him with my assistance.

Original: Ma da ch’è tuo voler che più si spieghi di nostra condizion com’ ell’ è vera, esser non puote il mio che a te si nieghi
Translate: But since your wish is that we explain to you in more detail our condition, it is not possible that my desire is different from yours.

Original: Questi non vide mai l’ultima sera
Translate: This one never died.

Original: ma per la sua follia le fu sì presso, che molto poco tempo a volger era
Translate: but for his sin he was so close to being so that it would not be long

Original: Sì com’ io dissi, fui mandato ad esso per lui campare
Translate: Like I said, I was sent to help him.

Original: e non lì era altra via che questa per la quale i’ mi son messo
Translate: And there was no other way but this one for which I went with him.

Original: Mostrata ho lui tutta la gente ria
Translate: I showed him all the damned.

Original: e ora intendo mostrar quelli spirti che purgan sé sotto la tua balìa
Translate: Now I want to show him those souls that purify themselves in your custody.

Original: Com’ io l’ho tratto, saria lungo a dirti
Translate: It would be a long time to explain how I led him here.

Original: de l’alto scende virtù che m’aiuta conducerlo a vederti e a udirti
Translate: From Heaven comes a virtue that helps me to bring him here, to see you and hear you.

Original: Or ti piaccia gradir la sua venuta
Translate: Now please welcome his coming

Original: libertà va cercando, ch’è sì cara, come sa chi per lei vita rifiuta
Translate: is seeking freedom, which is very precious as he knows who in his name renounces his own life

Original: Tu ’l sai, ché non ti fu per lei amara in Utica la morte, ove lasciasti la vesta ch’al gran dì sarà sì chiara
Translate: Thou knowest it well, for thou didst deal with death in Utica for liberty, where thou left the body which the Day of Judgment shall shine.

Original: Non son li editti etterni per noi guasti, ché questi vive e Minòs me non lega
Translate: Eternal edicts are not broken by us, for Dante is alive and Minos has no power over me.

Original: ma son del cerchio ove son li occhi casti di Marzia tua, che ’n vista ancor ti priega, o santo petto, che per tua la tegni
Translate: For I come from the Circle, where your wife's pure eyes are, Martiah, who sees her, seems to be begging you to consider her still yours, O holy breast.

Original: per lo suo amore adunque a noi ti piega
Translate: in the name of his love, therefore, bend to us.

Original: Lasciane andar per li tuoi sette regni
Translate: Let us go for the seven Purgatory Frames

Original: grazie riporterò di te a lei, se d’esser mentovato là giù degni»
Translate: I will thank you in front of her, if you agree to be mentioned there.

Original: «Marzïa piacque tanto a li occhi miei mentre ch’i’ fu’ di là»,
Translate: As long as I was alive, Martiah was so delighted in my eyes

Original: diss’ elli allora,
Translate: He then said,

Original: «che quante grazie volse da me, fei
Translate: that I fulfilled all his desires

Original: Or che di là dal mal fiume dimora, più muover non mi può, per quella legge che fatta fu quando me n’usci’ fora
Translate: Now that he resides beyond the infernal river, he can no longer move me, by virtue of that law which was enacted when I came out of it.

Original: Ma se donna del ciel ti move e regge, come tu di’, non c’è mestier lusinghe
Translate: But if a blessed woman, as you say, moves your steps, you don't need flattery

Original: bastisi ben che per lei mi richegge
Translate: All you have to do is pray to me in his name.

Original: Va dunque, e fa che tu costui ricinghe d’un giunco schietto e che li lavi ’l viso, sì ch’ogne sucidume quindi stinghe
Translate: Go therefore, and make him gird his loins with a smooth bunk, and wash his face, so as to remove from it all filth.

Original: ché non si converria, l’occhio sorpriso d’alcuna nebbia, andar dinanzi al primo ministro, ch’è di quei di paradiso
Translate: In fact it would not be appropriate to appear before the prime minister of Paradise with the eye veiled by some fog

Original: Questa isoletta intorno ad imo ad imo, là giù colà dove la batte l’onda, porta di giunchi sovra ’l molle limo
Translate: This little island, in its lower parts, where it is beaten by the waves, is full of rushes on the mud springs

Original: null’ altra pianta che facesse fronda o indurasse, vi puote aver vita, però ch’a le percosse non seconda
Translate: No other plant that had branches or a rigid trunk can grow there, for it would not bend to the impetus of the waves.

Original: Poscia non sia di qua vostra reddita
Translate: Then your return is not this way

Original: lo sol vi mosterrà, che surge omai, prendere il monte a più lieve salita»
Translate: the sun, which now rises, will show you the direction where to find easy access to the mountain

Original: Così sparì
Translate: So he vanished

Original: e io sù mi levai sanza parlare, e tutto mi ritrassi al duca mio, e li occhi a lui drizzai
Translate: And I rose up without speaking, and drew myself to my guidance, and turned my gaze to him.

Original: El cominciò
Translate: He began

Original: «Figliuol, segui i miei passi
Translate: Son, follow my steps

Original: volgianci in dietro, ché di qua dichina questa pianura a’ suoi termini bassi»
Translate: Let's go back, for from here the plain gently declines towards the lowest point.

Original: L’alba vinceva l’ora mattutina che fuggia innanzi, sì che di lontano conobbi il tremolar de la marina
Translate: The light of dawn was the last hour of the night that fled before her, so that from afar I saw the trembling of the surface of the sea.

Original: Noi andavam per lo solingo piano com’ om che torna a la perduta strada, che ’nfino ad essa li pare ire in vano
Translate: We went along the solitary plain, like someone who found the lost way and who, to it, believed to walk in vain.

Original: Quando noi fummo là ’ve la rugiada pugna col sole, per essere in parte dove, ad orezza, poco si dirada,
Translate: When we were there where the dew fights with the sun, for it is at the point where there is shadow and it evaporates little,

Original: ambo le mani in su l’erbetta sparte soavemente ’l mio maestro pose
Translate: My master laid both hands on the grass, with open palms

Original: ond’ io, che fui accorto di sua arte, porsi ver’ lui le guance lagrimose
Translate: Then I, who had understood what he wanted to do, set my cheeks against him still stained with weeping.

Original: ivi mi fece tutto discoverto quel color che l’inferno mi nascose
Translate: He discovered the color of my face that Hell had hidden

Original: Venimmo poi in sul lito diserto, che mai non vide navicar sue acque omo, che di tornar sia poscia esperto
Translate: Then we came to the desert shore, which never saw anyone sailing, who was able to go back.

Original: Quivi mi cinse sì com’ altrui piacque
Translate: Here Virgil girded me as Cato had told him

Original: oh maraviglia
Translate: What a wonder

Original: ché qual elli scelse l’umile pianta, cotal si rinacque subitamente là onde l’avelse
Translate: For after he had torn the humble plant which he had chosen, it was immediately reborn as it was in the same place.

Original: Già era ’l sole a l’orizzonte giunto lo cui meridïan cerchio coverchia Ierusalèm col suo più alto punto
Translate: The sun had already arrived on the horizon whose meridian surpasses Jerusalem with its highest point

Original: e la notte, che opposita a lui cerchia, uscia di Gange fuor con le Bilance, che le caggion di man quando soverchia
Translate: And the night, which rotates in the opposite position of the sun, came out of the Ganges in conjunction with the Libra, and it is not so when its duration exceeds that of the day.

Original: sì che le bianche e le vermiglie guance, là dov’ i’ era, de la bella Aurora per troppa etate divenivan rance
Translate: So the white and red cheeks of the beautiful Aurora, where I was, for the passing of time became orange

Original: Noi eravam lunghesso mare ancora, come gente che pensa a suo cammino, che va col cuore e col corpo dimora
Translate: We were still on the shore, as someone who thinks of the path he must take and is ready with desire, but hesitates with the body

Original: Ed ecco, qual, sorpreso dal mattino, per li grossi vapor Marte rosseggia giù nel ponente sovra ’l suol marino,
Translate: And behold, as when Mars, clouded by the morning, reddened by thick vapors to the west on the surface of the sea,

Original: cotal m’apparve, s’io ancor lo veggia, un lume per lo mar venir sì ratto, che ’l muover suo nessun volar pareggia
Translate: So there appeared to me a light that came from the sea, so fast that no bird moved as quickly

Original: Dal qual com’ io un poco ebbi ritratto l’occhio per domandar lo duca mio, rividil più lucente e maggior fatto
Translate: As soon as I turned away a little look from it to ask my teacher, I saw it brighter and bigger

Original: Poi d’ogne lato ad esso m’appario un non sapeva che bianco, e di sotto a poco a poco un altro a lui uscìo
Translate: Then on every side of it it seemed to me to see a whiteness indefinite, and little by little underneath it appeared another.

Original: Lo mio maestro ancor non facea motto, mentre che i primi bianchi apparver ali
Translate: My teacher said nothing, until it appeared that the first white was wings.

Original: allor che ben conobbe il galeotto, gridò
Translate: When he knew that knucklehead, he cried to me,

Original: «Fa, fa che le ginocchia cali
Translate: Up, up, bend your knees

Original: Ecco l’angel di Dio
Translate: Here is the angel of God

Original: piega le mani
Translate: Put your hands together

Original: omai vedrai di sì fatti officiali
Translate: You'll see ministers of this kind by now.

Original: Vedi che sdegna li argomenti umani, sì che remo non vuol, né altro velo che l’ali sue, tra liti sì lontani
Translate: See how he rejects human instruments, so that he doesn't want oars, or other sails that aren't his wings, even in places so far away

Original: Vedi come l’ha dritte verso ’l cielo, trattando l’aere con l’etterne penne, che non si mutan come mortal pelo»
Translate: See how he holds them straight to the sky, slitting the air with eternal feathers that do not fall like deadly feathers.

Original: Poi, come più e più verso noi venne l’uccel divino, più chiaro appariva
Translate: Then, as soon as the divine bird came toward us, it appeared more clearly

Original: per che l’occhio da presso nol sostenne, ma chinail giuso
Translate: Then my eyes did not look closely, but I was forced to bow them down.

Original: e quei sen venne a riva con un vasello snelletto e leggero, tanto che l’acqua nulla ne ’nghiottiva
Translate: And he came ashore with a narrow, light boat, to the point that he didn't sink in the water at all.

Original: Da poppa stava il celestial nocchiero, tal che faria beato pur descripto
Translate: The divine helmsman stood at the stern, and was such that he would make blessed only to describe him

Original: e più di cento spirti entro sediero
Translate: And in the boat sat more than a hundred spirits.

Original: ‘In exitu Isräel de Aegypto’ cantavan tutti insieme ad una voce con quanto di quel salmo è poscia scripto
Translate: All together they sang the Psalm with one voice in Israel's flight from Egypt, even with the following verses:

Original: Poi fece il segno lor di santa croce
Translate: And he made them the sign of the cross.

Original: ond’ ei si gittar tutti in su la piaggia
Translate: And they all fell on the beach,

Original: ed el sen gì, come venne, veloce
Translate: And he went, as fast as he had come.

Original: La turba che rimase lì, selvaggia parea del loco, rimirando intorno come colui che nove cose assaggia
Translate: The group of souls who stayed there seemed inexperienced of the place, and looked around as the one experiencing new things

Original: Da tutte parti saettava il giorno lo sol, ch’avea con le saette conte di mezzo ’l ciel cacciato Capricorno,
Translate: The sun blew the day from all sides, having already driven the Capricorn from the middle point of the sky with the infallible arrows,

Original: quando la nova gente alzò la fronte ver’ noi, dicendo a noi
Translate: when the newcomers turned to us, saying to us,

Original: «Se voi sapete, mostratene la via di gire al monte»
Translate: If you know it, show us the way to the mountain.

Original: E Virgilio rispuose
Translate: And Virgil answered him, saying,

Original: «Voi credete forse che siamo esperti d’esto loco
Translate: You may believe that we are experts in this place.

Original: ma noi siam peregrin come voi siete
Translate: But we're strangers just like you.

Original: Dianzi venimmo, innanzi a voi un poco, per altra via, che fu sì aspra e forte, che lo salire omai ne parrà gioco»
Translate: We have just arrived, just before you, through another road that was so difficult that the ascent of the mountain in comparison will seem like a joke to us.

Original: L’anime, che si fuor di me accorte, per lo spirare, ch’i’ era ancor vivo, maravigliando diventaro smorte
Translate: The souls, who had realized that I was alive when I was breathing, paled with amazement

Original: E come a messagger che porta ulivo tragge la gente per udir novelle, e di calcar nessun si mostra schivo,
Translate: And as the people crowd around the messenger who brings news of peace, and no one is disobeyed to rush,

Original: così al viso mio s’affisar quelle anime fortunate tutte quante, quasi oblïando d’ire a farsi belle
Translate: So those lucky souls all gathered around my face, almost forgetting to go and purify themselves.

Original: Io vidi una di lor trarresi avante per abbracciarmi con sì grande affetto, che mosse me a far lo somigliante
Translate: I saw one of them coming forward to embrace me, with such great affection that he moved me to do the same

Original: Ohi ombre vane, fuor che ne l’aspetto
Translate: Oh, inconsistent shadows, except in appearance

Original: tre volte dietro a lei le mani avvinsi, e tante mi tornai con esse al petto
Translate: Three times I tried to embrace her with my hands, and I found her empty in my chest.

Original: Di maraviglia, credo, mi dipinsi
Translate: I think I was very surprised.

Original: per che l’ombra sorrise e si ritrasse, e io, seguendo lei, oltre mi pinsi
Translate: Then the shadow smiled and pulled aside, and I followed her and pushed me a little far.

Original: Soavemente disse ch’io posasse
Translate: Gently told me to stop

Original: allor conobbi chi era, e pregai che, per parlarmi, un poco s’arrestasse
Translate: Then I recognized him and begged him to stop a while and talk to me.

Original: Rispuosemi
Translate: He answered me.

Original: «Così com’ io t’amai nel mortal corpo, così t’amo sciolta
Translate: As I have loved you in the mortal body, so I love you now that I am a soul.

Original: però m’arresto
Translate: That's why I'm stopping,

Original: ma tu perché vai?»
Translate: Why are you here?

Original: «Casella mio, per tornar altra volta là dov’ io son, fo io questo vïaggio», diss’ io
Translate: "My house, I make this journey to come back here again where I am" , I said

Original: «ma a te com’ è tanta ora tolta?»
Translate: But how come you only get here now?

Original: Ed elli a me
Translate: And him to me

Original: «Nessun m’è fatto oltraggio, se quei che leva quando e cui li piace, più volte m’ha negato esto passaggio
Translate: "I have not been wronged, if the angel, who takes when and who wills, has denied me many times to bring me here.

Original: ché di giusto voler lo suo si face
Translate: For his will is according to the divine.

Original: veramente da tre mesi elli ha tolto chi ha voluto intrar, con tutta pace
Translate: However, for three months he has welcomed on the boat all those who wanted to get on it, without opposing

Original: Ond’ io, ch’era ora a la marina vòlto dove l’acqua di Tevero s’insala, benignamente fu’ da lui ricolto
Translate: Then I, who turned to the sea where the Tiber flowed, was kindly received by him.

Original: A quella foce ha elli or dritta l’ala, però che sempre quivi si ricoglie qual verso Acheronte non si cala»
Translate: Now he has straightened the wing toward that mouth, since every soul that is not destined to Hell is always gathered there.

Original: E io
Translate: And I...

Original: «Se nuova legge non ti toglie memoria o uso a l’amoroso canto che mi solea quetar tutte mie doglie,
Translate: If a new law does not take away your memory or habit of loving song that used to appease all my desires,

Original: di ciò ti piaccia consolare alquanto l’anima mia, che, con la sua persona venendo qui, è affannata tanto»
Translate: with it please console a little my soul, that coming here with the physical body is so fatigued (Translated with Google Translate)

Original: ‘Amor che ne la mente mi ragiona’ cominciò elli allor sì dolcemente, che la dolcezza ancor dentro mi suona
Translate: And he began to sing, Love that reasoneth me in my mind, so softly, that the sweetness of that song still resoundeth within me.

Original: Lo mio maestro e io e quella gente ch’eran con lui parevan sì contenti, come a nessun toccasse altro la mente
Translate: My teacher and I and those souls who were with him seemed so happy, as if our minds were not touched by any thought.

Original: Noi eravam tutti fissi e attenti a le sue note
Translate: We were all intent on the notes,

Original: ed ecco il veglio onesto gridando
Translate: when the dignified old man came and cried,

Original: «Che è ciò, spiriti lenti?
Translate: What does this mean, slow spirits?

Original: qual negligenza, quale stare è questo?
Translate: What negligence, what delay is this?

Original: Correte al monte a spogliarvi lo scoglio ch’esser non lascia a voi Dio manifesto»
Translate: Run to the mountain and take off the zest that does not allow you to see God.

Original: Come quando, cogliendo biado o loglio, li colombi adunati a la pastura, queti, sanza mostrar l’usato orgoglio,
Translate: As when the doves, catching biada or loaf, gathered for the meal, quiet and without showing the usual pride,

Original: se cosa appare ond’ elli abbian paura, subitamente lasciano star l’esca, perch’ assaliti son da maggior cura
Translate: if something appears that scares them they immediately leave the food because they are attacked by a greater concern

Original: così vid’ io quella masnada fresca lasciar lo canto, e fuggir ver’ la costa, com’ om che va, né sa dove rïesca
Translate: So I saw those souls as soon as you came, leave the song, and run to the mountain like someone who goes without a precise goal.

Original: né la nostra partita fu men tosta
Translate: and our escape was no less hasty

Original: Avvegna che la subitana fuga dispergesse color per la campagna,
Translate: Though the sudden escape had scattered souls along the beach,

Original: rivolti al monte ove ragion ne fruga, i’ mi ristrinsi a la fida compagna
Translate: To the mountain where divine righteousness torments us, I clinged to my trustworthy guidance.

Original: e come sare’ io sanza lui corso? chi m’avria tratto su per la montagna? El mi parea da sé stesso rimorso
Translate: And how would I have gone without him?Who would have made me go up the mountain?He seemed to me to be moved by remorse.

Original: o dignitosa coscïenza e netta, come t’è picciol fallo amaro morso
Translate: O dignified and pure conscience, which bitter torment causes the least error in you.

Original: Quando li piedi suoi lasciar la fretta, che l’onestade ad ogn’ atto dismaga,
Translate: When his feet left the haste that belittles every act of decorum,

Original: la mente mia, che prima era ristretta,
Translate: My mind, which before was fixed on one thought,

Original: lo ’ntento rallargò, sì come vaga, e diedi ’l viso mio incontr’ al poggio che ’nverso ’l ciel più alto si dislaga
Translate: He spread forth as long as he could see anything else, and so I looked up to the mountain that stood in the sky higher than any other.

Original: Lo sol, che dietro fiammeggiava roggio, rotto m’era dinanzi a la figura, ch’avëa in me de’ suoi raggi l’appoggio
Translate: The sun, shining red behind my back, was interrupted in front of me by my body, which stood in the way of its rays.

Original: Io mi volsi dallato con paura d’essere abbandonato, quand’ io vidi solo dinanzi a me la terra oscura
Translate: I turned to the side with fear of being abandoned, when I saw that there was a shadow only before me

Original: e ’l mio conforto
Translate: and my comfort

Original: «Perché pur diffidi?», a dir mi cominciò tutto rivolto
Translate: "Why do you continue to be wary?" he began to tell me with great attention.

Original: «non credi tu me teco e ch’io ti guidi? Vespero è già colà dov’ è sepolto lo corpo dentro al quale io facea ombra
Translate: Don't you think I'm here with you to guide you?It's already evening where the body is buried in which I was shadowing

Original: Napoli l’ha, e da Brandizio è tolto
Translate: is in Naples and has been transferred there by Brindisi

Original: Ora, se innanzi a me nulla s’aombra, non ti maravigliar più che d’i cieli che l’uno a l’altro raggio non ingombra
Translate: Now, if I cast no shadow before me, be no more astonished that the heavens do not hinder the passage of light from one to another.

Original: A sofferir tormenti, caldi e geli simili corpi la Virtù dispone che, come fa, non vuol ch’a noi si sveli
Translate: The divine will causes such bodies to suffer physical torments, heat and frost, and does not want us to know how this is possible

Original: Matto è chi spera che nostra ragione possa trascorrer la infinita via che tiene una sustanza in tre persone
Translate: It is insane to hope that our reason can go the infinite way that holds only one substance in three persons

Original: State contenti, umana gente, al quia
Translate: Be content, men, with this

Original: ché, se potuto aveste veder tutto, mestier non era parturir Maria
Translate: in fact, if you could have seen everything, it would not have been necessary for Mary to give birth to Jesus

Original: e disïar vedeste sanza frutto tai che sarebbe lor disio quetato, ch’etternalmente è dato lor per lutto
Translate: And ye have seen the desire of so deep philosophers in vain, that, if it were possible, they would have fulfilled their desire, which is their eternal punishment.

Original: io dico d’Aristotile e di Plato e di molt’ altri»
Translate: I speak of Aristotle, Plato, and many others.

Original: e qui chinò la fronte, e più non disse, e rimase turbato
Translate: And then he bowed his forehead, and added no more, and was troubled.

Original: Noi divenimmo intanto a piè del monte
Translate: But we had come to the foot of the mountain.

Original: quivi trovammo la roccia sì erta, che ’ndarno vi sarien le gambe pronte
Translate: Here we found the rocky wall so steep that in vain we would try to climb it with our legs

Original: Tra Lerice e Turbìa la più diserta, la più rotta ruina è una scala, verso di quella, agevole e aperta
Translate: The steepest and most rugged rock in Liguria compared to that is an easy-to-access staircase

Original: «Or chi sa da qual man la costa cala»,
Translate: Now who knows from which side the wall is less steep?

Original: disse ’l maestro mio fermando ’l passo,
Translate: Says my teacher, stopping the pace

Original: «sì che possa salir chi va sanz’ ala?»
Translate: So that those who have no wings can climb up?

Original: E mentre ch’e’ tenendo ’l viso basso essaminava del cammin la mente, e io mirava suso intorno al sasso,
Translate: And while he, looking down on the ground, reflected on the path to be taken, and I looked up around the rock,

Original: da man sinistra m’apparì una gente d’anime, che movieno i piè ver’ noi, e non pareva, sì venïan lente
Translate: I saw from the left coming a group of souls walking toward us, and it didn't even seem so slowly proceeding.

Original: «Leva», diss’ io, «maestro, li occhi tuoi
Translate: I said, "Master, look up.

Original: ecco di qua chi ne darà consiglio, se tu da te medesmo aver nol puoi»
Translate: That's who will give us directions, if you can't find them yourself.

Original: Guardò allora, e con libero piglio rispuose
Translate: Then he looked, and looked calmly, and answered.

Original: «Andiamo in là, ch’ei vegnon piano
Translate: "Let's go that way, for they are coming slowly toward us.

Original: e tu ferma la spene, dolce figlio»
Translate: and you strengthen your hope, sweet son

Original: Ancora era quel popol di lontano, i’ dico dopo i nostri mille passi, quanto un buon gittator trarria con mano,
Translate: After we had walked a thousand steps, that line was still the space that a good pitcher would cover by throwing a rock with his hand,

Original: quando si strinser tutti ai duri massi de l’alta ripa, e stetter fermi e stretti com’ a guardar, chi va dubbiando, stassi
Translate: And when they all stood on the rocky wall of the mountain, and stood there, as they stood, and looked upon him that went, and was in doubt.

Original: «O ben finiti, o già spiriti eletti», Virgilio incominciò,
Translate: Virgil began "O dead spirits in the grace of God and chosen for salvation,

Original: «per quella pace ch’i’ credo che per voi tutti s’aspetti, ditene dove la montagna giace, sì che possibil sia l’andare in suso
Translate: in the name of that peace which I believe you all await, tell us where the mountain is less steep, so that it is possible to ascend.

Original: ché perder tempo a chi più sa più spiace»
Translate: In fact, the more one knows, the more sorry he is to lag behind.

Original: Come le pecorelle escon del chiuso a una, a due, a tre, e l’altre stanno timidette atterrando l’occhio e ’l muso
Translate: As the sheep come out of the fold, to one, to two, to three, and the others stand back fearful and hold the snout and the eye down

Original: e ciò che fa la prima, e l’altre fanno, addossandosi a lei, s’ella s’arresta, semplici e quete, e lo ’mperché non sanno
Translate: and what the former does also do the others, leaning on her if she stops, simple and meek, and they do not know the reason

Original: sì vid’ io muovere a venir la testa di quella mandra fortunata allotta, pudica in faccia e ne l’andare onesta
Translate: So I saw the head of that host of lucky souls moving toward us, modest in appearance and dignified in movement.

Original: Come color dinanzi vider rotta la luce in terra dal mio destro canto, sì che l’ombra era da me a la grotta,
Translate: As soon as they saw that I cast a shadow to my right hand, from me to the rocky wall,

Original: restaro, e trasser sé in dietro alquanto, e tutti li altri che venieno appresso, non sappiendo ’l perché, fenno altrettanto
Translate: They stopped and pulled back a little, and all the other spirits who came after them, though they did not know why, did the same.

Original: «Sanza vostra domanda io vi confesso che questo è corpo uman che voi vedete
Translate: "Without you asking, I tell you immediately that this body you see is of flesh and bones.

Original: per che ’l lume del sole in terra è fesso
Translate: Therefore the light of the sun is cut off from him, on the ground.

Original: Non vi maravigliate, ma credete che non sanza virtù che da ciel vegna cerchi di soverchiar questa parete»
Translate: Don't be surprised, but believe that Dante doesn't try to climb this wall without the help of a virtue that comes from Heaven.

Original: Così ’l maestro
Translate: That's what the teacher said.

Original: e quella gente degna «Tornate», disse, «intrate innanzi dunque», coi dossi de le man faccendo insegna
Translate: And those worthy souls said, Return upon your steps, and mark them with the back of their hands.

Original: E un di loro incominciò
Translate: And one of them started

Original: «Chiunque tu se’, così andando, volgi ’l viso
Translate: "Whoever you are, as you keep walking, turn to me

Original: pon mente se di là mi vedesti unque»
Translate: and tell me if you've ever seen me on Earth.

Original: Io mi volsi ver’ lui e guardail fiso
Translate: I turned to him and looked at him carefully.

Original: biondo era e bello e di gentile aspetto, ma l’un de’ cigli un colpo avea diviso
Translate: He was blond, handsome and noble, but one of the eyebrows was divided by a blow.

Original: Quand’ io mi fui umilmente disdetto d’averlo visto mai, el disse
Translate: When I humbly told him that I had never seen him, he fought back.

Original: «Or vedi»
Translate: "Now watch"

Original: e mostrommi una piaga a sommo ’l petto
Translate: And he showed me a sore on my chest.

Original: Poi sorridendo disse
Translate: Then he smiled and said,

Original: «Io son Manfredi, nepote di Costanza imperadrice
Translate: I am Manfredi, grandson of Empress Constance

Original: ond’ io ti priego che, quando tu riedi, vadi a mia bella figlia, genitrice de l’onor di Cicilia e d’Aragona,
Translate: Then I beg you, when you return to Earth, to go to my beautiful daughter, mother of the two heirs of the crown of Sicily and Aragon,

Original: e dichi ’l vero a lei, s’altro si dice
Translate: and tell her the truth about me, if you tell her anything else about my afterlife.

Original: Poscia ch’io ebbi rotta la persona di due punte mortali, io mi rendei, piangendo, a quei che volontier perdona
Translate: After I received two mortal wounds, I turned to Him in repentance and tears who gladly forgave Him.

Original: Orribil furon li peccati miei
Translate: My sins were horrible,

Original: ma la bontà infinita ha sì gran braccia, che prende ciò che si rivolge a lei
Translate: but the divine goodness has such broad arms that it welcomes all those who turn to her

Original: Se ’l pastor di Cosenza, che a la caccia di me fu messo per Clemente allora, avesse in Dio ben letta questa faccia,
Translate: If the bishop of Cosenza, who was then incited against me by Pope Clement fourth, had read this face of God's forgiveness,

Original: l’ossa del corpo mio sarieno ancora in co del ponte presso a Benevento, sotto la guardia de la grave mora
Translate: The bones of my body would still be buried under the pile of stones at the head of the bridge, at Benevento.

Original: Or le bagna la pioggia e move il vento di fuor dal regno, quasi lungo ’l Verde, dov’ e’ le trasmutò a lume spento
Translate: But now the rain bathes her, and the wind scatters her out of the kingdom of Naples, almost along the river Liri, where he caused them to be turned off by light.

Original: Per lor maladizion sì non si perde, che non possa tornar, l’etterno amore, mentre che la speranza ha fior del verde
Translate: For the curse of the Church the eternal divine love is not lost to the point that it cannot return, as long as there is some hope

Original: Vero è che quale in contumacia more di Santa Chiesa, ancor ch’al fin si penta, star li convien da questa ripa in fore,
Translate: It is true that those who die in absentia of the Holy Church, even if they repent at the point of death,

Original: per ognun tempo ch’elli è stato, trenta, in sua presunzïon, se tal decreto più corto per buon prieghi non diventa
Translate: The time he spent in his rebellion must be thirty times in Antipurgatory, if this decree is not shortened by good prayers.

Original: Vedi oggimai se tu mi puoi far lieto, revelando a la mia buona Costanza come m’hai visto, e anco esto divieto
Translate: See now if you can make me happy, revealing to my good Constance how you saw me and also this ban

Original: ché qui per quei di là molto s’avanza»
Translate: Here, in fact, they derive great benefits thanks to the prayers of the living

Original: Quando per dilettanze o ver per doglie, che alcuna virtù nostra comprenda, l’anima bene ad essa si raccoglie, par ch’a nulla potenza più intenda
Translate: When the soul, because of a joy or a pain that draws upon itself one of our virtues, focuses all on it, it seems that it exerts no other power.

Original: e questo è contra quello error che crede ch’un’anima sovr’ altra in noi s’accenda
Translate: And this contradicts the error of those who believe that there are many souls in us.

Original: E però, quando s’ode cosa o vede che tegna forte a sé l’anima volta, vassene ’l tempo e l’uom non se n’avvede
Translate: And therefore, when one hears or sees a thing that absorbs all the attention of the soul, time runs and man does not notice

Original: ch’altra potenza è quella che l’ascolta, e altra è quella c’ha l’anima intera
Translate: in fact, the power that perceives the flow of time is one, while the power that possesses the whole soul is another

Original: questa è quasi legata e quella è sciolta
Translate: the latter is almost tied, while the former is free

Original: Di ciò ebb’ io esperïenza vera, udendo quello spirto e ammirando
Translate: Of this I had a direct confirmation, listening to that spirit full of astonishment.

Original: ché ben cinquanta gradi salito era lo sole, e io non m’era accorto, quando venimmo ove quell’ anime ad una gridaro a noi
Translate: For the sun ascended into heaven fifty degrees, and I did not see it, when we came to the place where those souls spoke with one voice.

Original: «Qui è vostro dimando»
Translate: This is the place you asked for.

Original: Maggiore aperta molte volte impruna con una forcatella di sue spine l’uom de la villa quando l’uva imbruna,
Translate: Many times the farmer, when the grape is ripe, obstructs with a small amount of thorns an opening

Original: che non era la calla onde salìne lo duca mio, e io appresso, soli, come da noi la schiera si partìne
Translate: Greater than the path whereon my teacher went up, and I behind him alone, as soon as the host of souls went away.

Original: Vassi in Sanleo e discendesi in Noli, montasi su in Bismantova e ’n Cacume con esso i piè
Translate: Continue in Sanleo and go down to Noli, climb on the Bismantova and on Mount Cacume only with your feet

Original: ma qui convien ch’om voli
Translate: But there it is necessary to fly

Original: dico con l’ale snelle e con le piume del gran disio, di retro a quel condotto che speranza mi dava e facea lume
Translate: flying, I mean, with the light wings and the feathers of the great desire, behind that guide that gave me hope and made way

Original: Noi salavam per entro ’l sasso rotto, e d’ogne lato ne stringea lo stremo, e piedi e man volea il suol di sotto
Translate: We climbed into the path dug into the rock, and the ends held us from every side, and we had to help ourselves with hands and feet.

Original: Poi che noi fummo in su l’orlo suppremo de l’alta ripa, a la scoperta piaggia,
Translate: When we reached the upper edge of the high wall, where the slope was more spacious,

Original: «Maestro mio», diss’ io, «che via faremo?»
Translate: I said, "My master, now what way will we take?"

Original: Ed elli a me
Translate: And him to me

Original: «Nessun tuo passo caggia
Translate: ♪ No step of yours goes down ♪

Original: pur su al monte dietro a me acquista, fin che n’appaia alcuna scorta saggia»
Translate: continue always high behind me, until there appears to us someone to give us directions.

Original: Lo sommo er’ alto che vincea la vista, e la costa superba più assai che da mezzo quadrante a centro lista
Translate: The top was so high that you couldn't see it, and the steepest slope of the rod in the middle of the quadrant

Original: Io era lasso, quando cominciai
Translate: I was tired when I said,

Original: «O dolce padre, volgiti, e rimira com’ io rimango sol, se non restai»
Translate: "Sweet father, turn around and see how I am left alone, if you don't stop."

Original: «Figliuol mio», disse, «infin quivi ti tira», additandomi un balzo poco in sùe che da quel lato il poggio tutto gira
Translate: He said, "My son, try to get here," pointing to a little higher shelf that surrounds the whole mountain on that side.

Original: Sì mi spronaron le parole sue, ch’i’ mi sforzai carpando appresso lui, tanto che ’l cinghio sotto i piè mi fue
Translate: His words spurred me to such an extent that I strove, walking behind him, until I came upon that shelf.

Original: A seder ci ponemmo ivi ambedui vòlti a levante ond’ eravam saliti, che suole a riguardar giovare altrui
Translate: We both sat there, facing eastwards in the direction from which we had ascended, which is usually pleasurable to watch.

Original: Li occhi prima drizzai ai bassi liti
Translate: At first I looked down,

Original: poscia li alzai al sole, e ammirava che da sinistra n’eravam feriti
Translate: Then I looked up at the sun, and I was amazed that it hit us from the left.

Original: Ben s’avvide il poeta ch’ïo stava stupido tutto al carro de la luce, ove tra noi e Aquilone intrava
Translate: Virgil understood that I looked marveled at the chariot of light, at the point where it was advancing between us and the north.

Original: Ond’ elli a me
Translate: Then he said to me,

Original: «Se Castore e Poluce fossero in compagnia di quello specchio che sù e giù del suo lume conduce,
Translate: If the constellation of the Twins were combined with that mirror that makes the light go up and down,

Original: tu vedresti il Zodïaco rubecchio ancora a l’Orse più stretto rotare, se non uscisse fuor del cammin vecchio
Translate: You'd see the reddish Zodiac rotate even closer to the north, unless he came out of his usual path.

Original: Come ciò sia, se ’l vuoi poter pensare, dentro raccolto, imagina Sïòn con questo monte in su la terra stare sì,
Translate: If you want to understand how this is possible, imagine with great concentration that Jerusalem and Purgatory are on Earth,

Original: ch’amendue hanno un solo orizzòn e diversi emisperi
Translate: in such a way that both have a single horizon, but different hemispheres

Original: onde la strada che mal non seppe carreggiar Fetòn, vedrai come a costui convien che vada da l’un,
Translate: Wherefore thou shalt see that the way of the sun shall go one way for him that is in Jerusalem.

Original: quando a colui da l’altro fianco, se lo ’ntelletto tuo ben chiaro bada»
Translate: And on the other hand for those who are here, if your intellect understands clearly, I said,

Original: «Certo, maestro mio,» diss’ io, «unquanco non vid’ io chiaro sì com’ io discerno là dove mio ingegno parea manco,
Translate: "Of course, my master, I said, "I have never seen so clearly how I now understand what I used to struggle to comprehend,

Original: che ’l mezzo cerchio del moto superno, che si chiama Equatore in alcun’ arte,
Translate: that the meridian circle of the Primo Mobile, which is called the Equator in astronomical art,

Original: e che sempre riman tra ’l sole e ’l verno, per la ragion che di’, quinci si parte verso settentrïon, quanto li Ebrei vedevan lui verso la calda parte
Translate: and that is always halfway between the sun and the winter, for the reason that you explained it is from here to the north as much as the Jews saw it lying from them to the south

Original: Ma se a te piace, volontier saprei quanto avemo ad andar
Translate: But if you agree, I'd like to know how long we still have to go,

Original: ché ’l poggio sale più che salir non posson li occhi miei»
Translate: For the mountain is higher than where my eyes reach.

Original: Ed elli a me
Translate: And him to me

Original: «Questa montagna è tale, che sempre al cominciar di sotto è grave
Translate: This mountain is such that in the beginning the ascent is always very tiring

Original: e quant’ om più va sù, e men fa male
Translate: The more you go up, the less difficult it is

Original: Però, quand’ ella ti parrà soave tanto, che sù andar ti fia leggero com’ a seconda giù andar per nave,
Translate: Therefore, when it seems so sweet to you that the ascent will be as easy for you as the stream of a river,

Original: allor sarai al fin d’esto sentiero
Translate: Then you will be at the end of this path

Original: quivi di riposar l’affanno aspetta
Translate: Wait and rest here

Original: Più non rispondo, e questo so per vero»
Translate: That's all I'm saying, and I know that's true.

Original: E com’ elli ebbe sua parola detta, una voce di presso sonò
Translate: And when Virgil had finished speaking, there was a voice nearby.

Original: «Forse che di sedere in pria avrai distretta»
Translate: Maybe you'll need to sit down first.

Original: Al suon di lei ciascun di noi si torse, e vedemmo a mancina un gran petrone, del qual né io né ei prima s’accorse
Translate: At the sound of that voice we both turned and saw to our left a great rock, which neither of us had noticed before.

Original: Là ci traemmo
Translate: We went there

Original: e ivi eran persone che si stavano a l’ombra dietro al sasso come l’uom per negghienza a star si pone
Translate: And we found souls in the shadows behind the rock, as some resting negligent.

Original: E un di lor, che mi sembiava lasso, sedeva e abbracciava le ginocchia, tenendo ’l viso giù tra esse basso
Translate: And one of them, who seemed tired to me, sat and embraced his knees, holding his head to the ground between his legs.

Original: «O dolce segnor mio», diss’ io, «adocchia colui che mostra sé più negligente che se pigrizia fosse sua serocchia»
Translate: I said, "O sweet master, look at that soul that seems more negligent than if laziness were his sister."

Original: Allor si volse a noi e puose mente, movendo ’l viso pur su per la coscia, e disse
Translate: Then he turned his attention to us, moving only his gaze down his thigh, and said,

Original: «Or va tu sù, che se’ valente»
Translate: Try to climb, since you're good at it.

Original: Conobbi allor chi era, e quella angoscia che m’avacciava un poco ancor la lena, non m’impedì l’andare a lui
Translate: Then I recognized him, and that trouble which weary me a little while more breath did not stop me from going to him.

Original: e poscia ch’a lui fu’ giunto, alzò la testa a pena, dicendo
Translate: And when he had reached him, he barely lifted up his head, saying unto me,

Original: «Hai ben veduto come ’l sole da l’omero sinistro il carro mena?»
Translate: Have you seen how the sun walks its way from the left side?

Original: Li atti suoi pigri e le corte parole mosser le labbra mie un poco a riso
Translate: His lazy attitudes and brief words moved me to laugh a little

Original: poi cominciai
Translate: then I started

Original: «Belacqua, a me non dole di te omai
Translate: "Belacqua, I'm no longer in pain for you.

Original: ma dimmi
Translate: But tell me

Original: perché assiso quiritto se’? attendi tu iscorta, o pur lo modo usato t’ha’ ripriso?»
Translate: Why are you sitting here? Are you waiting for a guide, or have you regained your old habits?

Original: Ed elli
Translate: And him

Original: «O frate, andar in sù che porta? ché non mi lascerebbe ire a’ martìri l’angel di Dio che siede in su la porta
Translate: "Brother, what do you want me to do to go up?" the angel of God guarding the door would not let me enter the pains

Original: Prima convien che tanto il ciel m’aggiri di fuor da essa, quanto fece in vita, per ch’io ’ndugiai al fine i buon sospiri,
Translate: Since I lingered to repent until the last, first it is necessary that the sky rotates around me in the Antipurgatory as much as it did in life,

Original: se orazïone in prima non m’aita che surga sù di cuor che in grazia viva
Translate: If first does not help me a good prayer that rises from a heart in the grace of God

Original: l’altra che val, che ’n ciel non è udita?»
Translate: another would serve nothing, for in heaven it would not be heard.

Original: E già il poeta innanzi mi saliva, e dicea
Translate: And Virgilio went up before me, and said,

Original: «Vienne omai
Translate: it's coming now

Original: vedi ch’è tocco meridïan dal sole e a la riva cuopre la notte già col piè Morrocco»
Translate: You see that the sun has reached the meridian, and the night already covers the shore of Morocco with its foot.

Original: Io era già da quell’ ombre partito, e seguitava l’orme del mio duca, quando di retro a me, drizzando ’l dito, una gridò
Translate: I had already departed from those souls and followed the steps of my guidance, when behind me, straightening his finger, one of them cried out.

Original: «Ve’ che non par che luca lo raggio da sinistra a quel di sotto, e come vivo par che si conduca»
Translate: "You see that the ray of the sun from the left does not seem to cross what follows, which seems to project a shadow like a living"

Original: Li occhi rivolsi al suon di questo motto, e vidile guardar per maraviglia pur me, pur me, e ’l lume ch’era rotto
Translate: I looked at the sound of these words and saw those souls that marveled at me, just me, and the light of the sun interrupted by my body

Original: «Perché l’animo tuo tanto s’impiglia», disse ’l maestro, «che l’andare allenti?
Translate: The teacher told me "Why does your soul let itself be distracted to the point of slowing down the path?

Original: che ti fa ciò che quivi si pispiglia? Vien dietro a me, e lascia dir le genti
Translate: Why do you care what you murmur here?Follow me and let people talk

Original: sta come torre ferma, che non crolla già mai la cima per soffiar di venti
Translate: stand like a firm tower, that never sways its top as much as the winds sigh

Original: ché sempre l’omo in cui pensier rampolla sovra pensier, da sé dilunga il segno, perché la foga l’un de l’altro insolla»
Translate: In fact, the man in whom one thought brings forth another takes away his own goal from himself, because the strength of one weakens that of the other.

Original: Che potea io ridir, se non «Io vegno»? Dissilo, alquanto del color consperso che fa l’uom di perdon talvolta degno
Translate: What could I say, if I didn't follow you? I said it, rather sprinkled with the redness that sometimes makes man worthy to be forgiven.

Original: E ’ntanto per la costa di traverso venivan genti innanzi a noi un poco, cantando ‘Miserere’ a verso a verso
Translate: And in the meantime, on a rocky shelf that cut the mountain across, there came to us souls not far off, singing the Psalm 'Miserere' to alternate verses.

Original: Quando s’accorser ch’i’ non dava loco per lo mio corpo al trapassar d’i raggi, mutar lor canto in un «oh»
Translate: When they saw that I, with my body, did not allow the rays of the sun to pass by, they changed their song into a "oh"

Original: lungo e roco
Translate: long and dim

Original: e due di loro, in forma di messaggi, corsero incontr’ a noi e dimandarne
Translate: And two of them, as messengers, ran to us, and asked us, saying,

Original: «Di vostra condizion fatene saggi»
Translate: Please inform us of your condition.

Original: E ’l mio maestro
Translate: And my teacher

Original: «Voi potete andarne e ritrarre a color che vi mandaro che ’l corpo di costui è vera carne
Translate: "You can turn back and report to those who sent you here that the body of this man is in the flesh.

Original: Se per veder la sua ombra restaro, com’ io avviso, assai è lor risposto
Translate: If they, as I think, have stopped for having seen his shadow, I have told you enough

Original: fàccianli onore, ed esser può lor caro»
Translate: Let them receive him kindly, and this may be useful to them.

Original: Vapori accesi non vid’ io sì tosto di prima notte mai fender sereno, né, sol calando, nuvole d’agosto, che color non tornasser suso in meno
Translate: I have never seen fallen stars slit the sky at the beginning of the night, nor lightning torn the clouds of August at sunset, as quickly as those souls returned to high

Original: e, giunti là, con li altri a noi dier volta, come schiera che scorre sanza freno
Translate: And they came there, and ran to us with the others like an unbridled host.

Original: «Questa gente che preme a noi è molta, e vegnonti a pregar», disse ’l poeta
Translate: Virgil said, "These people who gather around us are many, and they come to pray to you.

Original: «però pur va, e in andando ascolta»
Translate: so keep walking and listen as you proceed

Original: «O anima che vai per esser lieta con quelle membra con le quai nascesti», venian gridando, «un poco il passo queta
Translate: They came screaming "O soul that you go to be happy, with that body with which you were born, slows down the pace a little

Original: Guarda s’alcun di noi unqua vedesti, sì che di lui di là novella porti
Translate: See if you've ever seen any of us in the world so that you can bring her news to Earth.

Original: deh, perché vai? deh, perché non t’arresti? Noi fummo tutti già per forza morti, e peccatori infino a l’ultima ora
Translate: Come on, why do you keep walking? Come on, why don't you stop?We were all violently killed and we were sinners until the last hour

Original: quivi lume del ciel ne fece accorti, sì che, pentendo e perdonando, fora di vita uscimmo a Dio pacificati,
Translate: at the point of death a light of heaven enlightened our minds, so that, repenting and forgiving, we came out of life in the grace of God,

Original: che del disio di sé veder n’accora»
Translate: who grieves us in the desire to see him

Original: E io
Translate: And I

Original: «Perché ne’ vostri visi guati, non riconosco alcun
Translate: "As much as I look at your faces, I don't recognize any of them.

Original: ma s’a voi piace cosa ch’io possa, spiriti ben nati, voi dite, e io farò
Translate: But if you want something in my power, lucky spirits, say it and I will,

Original: per quella pace che, dietro a’ piedi di sì fatta guida, di mondo in mondo cercar mi si face»
Translate: in the name of that peace which I, following the footsteps of this guide, seek in the kingdoms of the Underworld.

Original: E uno incominciò
Translate: And one started

Original: «Ciascun si fida del beneficio tuo sanza giurarlo, pur che ’l voler nonpossa non ricida
Translate: Each one trusts your promise without the need of oaths, as long as the impossibility does not prevent your will.

Original: Ond’ io, che solo innanzi a li altri parlo, ti priego, se mai vedi quel paese che siede tra Romagna e quel di Carlo,
Translate: Therefore I, who speak alone before others, I pray thee, if thou shalt ever go into that land which is between the Romagna and the reign of Charles of Anjou,

Original: che tu mi sie di tuoi prieghi cortese in Fano, sì che ben per me s’adori pur ch’i’ possa purgar le gravi offese
Translate: that thou prayest to my brethren at Fano, that they may pray for me, and allow me to atone for my sins.

Original: Quindi fu’ io
Translate: I was originally from Fano,

Original: ma li profondi fóri ond’ uscì ’l sangue in sul quale io sedea, fatti mi fuoro in grembo a li Antenori,
Translate: but the deep wounds from which the blood from which my soul resided came out, I was inflicted in the territory of Padua,

Original: là dov’ io più sicuro esser credea
Translate: Where I thought I was safe

Original: quel da Esti il fé far, che m’avea in ira assai più là che dritto non volea
Translate: And Azzo the eighth of Este, who hated me much more than he was right.

Original: Ma s’io fosse fuggito inver’ la Mira, quando fu’ sovragiunto ad Orïaco, ancor sarei di là dove si spira
Translate: But if I had fled to the village of Mira, when I was reached by my assassins in Oriago, I would still be in the world of the living.

Original: Corsi al palude, e le cannucce e ’l braco m’impigliar sì ch’i’ caddi
Translate: But I ran to the swamp, and the reeds and the mud drove me to the point that I fell.

Original: e lì vid’ io de le mie vene farsi in terra laco»
Translate: And there I saw the blood that came out of my veins, and formed a lake on the ground.

Original: Poi disse un altro
Translate: Then another said,

Original: «Deh, se quel disio si compia che ti tragge a l’alto monte,
Translate: "Orsu, I hope that the desire that goes up to the high mountain will be fulfilled.

Original: con buona pïetate aiuta il mio
Translate: You with good mercy help mine

Original: Io fui di Montefeltro, io son Bonconte
Translate: I was one of Montefeltro and my name is Bonconte

Original: Giovanna o altri non ha di me cura
Translate: neither my widow Joan nor my other companions take care of me,

Original: per ch’io vo tra costor con bassa fronte»
Translate: for which I am ashamed among these souls.

Original: E io a lui
Translate: And I to him

Original: «Qual forza o qual ventura ti travïò sì fuor di Campaldino, che non si seppe mai tua sepultura?»
Translate: What force or fortuitous case did he drag you out of Campaldino, so that your body was never found?

Original: «Oh», rispuos’ elli,
Translate: "Oh , he answered ,

Original: «a piè del Casentino traversa un’acqua c’ha nome l’Archiano, che sovra l’Ermo nasce in Apennino
Translate: At the foot of the Casentino flows a stream called Archiano, which was born in Apennines near the Hermitage of Camaldoli

Original: Là ’ve ’l vocabol suo diventa vano, arriva’ io forato ne la gola, fuggendo a piede e sanguinando il piano
Translate: At the point where he throws himself into the Arno and loses his name, I came with my throat pierced, fleeing on foot and bleeding the plain

Original: Quivi perdei la vista e la parola
Translate: Here I lost my sight and my word

Original: nel nome di Maria fini’, e quivi caddi, e rimase la mia carne sola
Translate: I died saying the name of Mary, and fell, and only my body remained.

Original: Io dirò vero, e tu ’l ridì tra ’ vivi
Translate: Now I will tell thee the truth, and thou shalt tell it unto the living.

Original: l’angel di Dio mi prese, e quel d’inferno gridava
Translate: the angel of God took me, and the angel of hell cried out.

Original: “O tu del ciel, perché mi privi? Tu te ne porti di costui l’etterno per una lagrimetta che ’l mi toglie
Translate: "O you of heaven, why do you take away from me what is due to me?You take away the eternal part of him for a little tear that takes it away from me.

Original: ma io farò de l’altro altro governo”
Translate: but I will give much more treatment to the body."

Original: Ben sai come ne l’aere si raccoglie quell’ umido vapor che in acqua riede, tosto che sale dove ’l freddo il coglie
Translate: You know how in the atmosphere you collect that humid steam that becomes water again, as soon as it goes up where it's colder

Original: Giunse quel mal voler che pur mal chiede con lo ’ntelletto, e mosse il fummo e ’l vento per la virtù che sua natura diede
Translate: The devil united his evil will, which seeks only evil, with understanding, and stirs up smoke and wind through the power that nature has given him.

Original: Indi la valle, come ’l dì fu spento, da Pratomagno al gran giogo coperse di nebbia
Translate: And when the sun went down, he covered all the plain from Pratomagno with mist, even unto the high peaks of the Apennines.

Original: e ’l ciel di sopra fece intento, sì che ’l pregno aere in acqua si converse
Translate: And made the sky above, full of moisture, so that it turned into rain.

Original: la pioggia cadde, e a’ fossati venne di lei ciò che la terra non sofferse
Translate: It fell, and that which the earth could not absorb filled the ditches.

Original: e come ai rivi grandi si convenne, ver’ lo fiume real tanto veloce si ruinò, che nulla la ritenne
Translate: And when he came to the streams, he poured himself into the Arno, so quickly that nothing could stop it.

Original: Lo corpo mio gelato in su la foce trovò l’Archian rubesto
Translate: The robbing Archian found my dead body at the mouth

Original: e quel sospinse ne l’Arno, e sciolse al mio petto la croce ch’i’ fe’ di me quando ’l dolor mi vinse
Translate: And he drove him into the Arno, and loosened the cross that I had made on my breast with his arms when I was come to an end.

Original: voltòmmi per le ripe e per lo fondo, poi di sua preda mi coperse e cinse»
Translate: And he rolled me by the banks, and by the sea, and buried me with the debris which he had dragged.

Original: «Deh, quando tu sarai tornato al mondo e riposato de la lunga via», seguitò ’l terzo spirito al secondo,
Translate: Upon your return to Earth and resting on the long way, a third spirit went on after the second,

Original: «ricorditi di me, che son la Pia
Translate: Remember me, that I am Pia

Original: Siena mi fé, disfecemi Maremma
Translate: I was born in Siena and was killed in Maremma

Original: salsi colui che ’nnanellata pria disposando m’avea con la sua gemma»
Translate: He who, having asked me to marry, had given me the wedding ring, knows it well.

Original: Quando si parte il gioco de la zara, colui che perde si riman dolente, repetendo le volte, e tristo impara
Translate: When the game of zara ends, what he lost remains alone and grieved, while rethinking the games made and learning sadly

Original: con l’altro se ne va tutta la gente
Translate: All people follow the winner

Original: qual va dinanzi, e qual di dietro il prende, e qual dallato li si reca a mente
Translate: one puts himself in front of him, another pulls him from behind, another follows him side by side

Original: el non s’arresta, e questo e quello intende
Translate: that doesn't stop and listens to each other

Original: a cui porge la man, più non fa pressa
Translate: Tip one, and it doesn't bother him anymore.

Original: e così da la calca si difende
Translate: and so to defend from the mold

Original: Tal era io in quella turba spessa, volgendo a loro, e qua e là, la faccia, e promettendo mi sciogliea da essa
Translate: So I did in the midst of that multitude of souls, turning my face to them here and there, and promising myself to depart from the chasm.

Original: Quiv’ era l’Aretin che da le braccia fiere di Ghin di Tacco ebbe la morte, e l’altro ch’annegò correndo in caccia
Translate: Here was the Aretinus who was killed by the fierce arms of Ghino di Tacco, and the other who drowned while he was being chased.

Original: Quivi pregava con le mani sporte Federigo Novello, e quel da Pisa che fé parer lo buon Marzucco forte
Translate: Here Frederick Novello prayed with his hands, and the Pisan who made the good Marzucco, his father, appear strong.

Original: Vidi conte Orso e l’anima divisa dal corpo suo per astio e per inveggia, com’ e’ dicea, non per colpa commisa
Translate: I saw the Count Bear and the soul divided by his body for anger and envy, not for committing a sin, as he said.

Original: Pier da la Broccia dico
Translate: I mean Pierre de la Brosse.

Original: e qui proveggia, mentr’ è di qua, la donna di Brabante, sì che però non sia di peggior greggia
Translate: And in this regard Mary of Brabant, as long as she is alive, would do well to repent, not to end up in a worse flock.

Original: Come libero fui da tutte quante quell’ ombre che pregar pur ch’altri prieghi, sì che s’avacci lor divenir sante, io cominciai
Translate: As soon as I was freed from all those souls who prayed for others to pray to allow them to purify themselves more quickly, I began

Original: «El par che tu mi nieghi, o luce mia, espresso in alcun testo che decreto del cielo orazion pieghi
Translate: It seems to me that you deny, O my teacher, expressly in your work, that a prayer may bend a divine decision

Original: e questa gente prega pur di questo
Translate: and these souls pray precisely for this

Original: sarebbe dunque loro speme vana, o non m’è ’l detto tuo ben manifesto?»
Translate: So their hope is vain, or are your words not clear to me?

Original: Ed elli a me
Translate: And him to me

Original: «La mia scrittura è piana
Translate: My words are clear

Original: e la speranza di costor non falla, se ben si guarda con la mente sana
Translate: And the hope of them is well-placed, if you look carefully and with an intellect of integrity.

Original: ché cima di giudicio non s’avvalla perché foco d’amor compia in un punto ciò che de’ sodisfar chi qui s’astalla
Translate: For the height of divine judgment is not diminished if the ardour of charity does in an instant what must be atoned by those who hold back here

Original: e là dov’ io fermai cotesto punto, non s’ammendava, per pregar, difetto, perché ’l priego da Dio era disgiunto
Translate: and at the point where I said this, guilt was not wiped out through prayer, and then prayer was not addressed to God

Original: Veramente a così alto sospetto non ti fermar, se quella nol ti dice che lume fia tra ’l vero e lo ’ntelletto
Translate: But do not stop yourself in the face of such a deep doubt, before she speaks to you, who will be light between the truth and your intellect.

Original: Non so se ’ntendi
Translate: I don't know if you understand,

Original: io dico di Beatrice
Translate: I'm talking about Beatrice.

Original: tu la vedrai di sopra, in su la vetta di questo monte, ridere e felice»
Translate: You will see her laughing happily on the top of this mountain.

Original: E io
Translate: And I...

Original: «Segnore, andiamo a maggior fretta, ché già non m’affatico come dianzi, e vedi omai che ’l poggio l’ombra getta»
Translate: "Lord, let's go faster, since I'm not as tired as before and, as you can see, the mountain already casts shadow."

Original: «Noi anderem con questo giorno innanzi», rispuose, «quanto più potremo omai
Translate: He said "We will proceed on this day as much as we can

Original: ma ’l fatto è d’altra forma che non stanzi
Translate: But things are different from what you think.

Original: Prima che sie là sù, tornar vedrai colui che già si cuopre de la costa, sì che ’ suoi raggi tu romper non fai
Translate: Before you get up there, you'll see the sun rising behind the mountain, so that you don't shadow anymore.

Original: Ma vedi là un’anima che, posta sola soletta, inverso noi riguarda
Translate: But you see a soul there, all alone, looking towards us.

Original: quella ne ’nsegnerà la via più tosta»
Translate: that will show us the most expedited route

Original: Venimmo a lei
Translate: We reached her

Original: o anima lombarda, come ti stavi altera e disdegnosa e nel mover de li occhi onesta e tarda
Translate: O Lombard soul, as thou wast haughty and disdainful, and full of dignity in moving thy eyes slowly.

Original: Ella non ci dicëa alcuna cosa, ma lasciavane gir, solo sguardando a guisa di leon quando si posa
Translate: She didn't tell us anything, but she would let us get close, just looking at how the lion does when he's waiting.

Original: Pur Virgilio si trasse a lei, pregando che ne mostrasse la miglior salita
Translate: However, Virgil approached her, praying that she would show us the best place to go up.

Original: e quella non rispuose al suo dimando, ma di nostro paese e de la vita ci ’nchiese
Translate: And she answered not the question, but asked us of the land where we came from, and of our life.

Original: e ’l dolce duca incominciava «Mantüa»,
Translate: and the sweet master began to say "Mantova"

Original: e l’ombra, tutta in sé romita, surse ver’ lui del loco ove pria stava, dicendo
Translate: And that shadow, which stood alone, rose up from the place where he was saying,

Original: «O Mantoano, io son Sordello de la tua terra»
Translate: "O Mantovano, I am Sordello, of your land."

Original: e l’un l’altro abbracciava
Translate: and embraced each other

Original: Ahi serva Italia, di dolore ostello, nave sanza nocchiere in gran tempesta, non donna di province, ma bordello
Translate: Alas, Italy slave, seat of pain, ship without helmsman in a great storm, no longer lady of the provinces but brothel

Original: Quell’ anima gentil fu così presta, sol per lo dolce suon de la sua terra, di fare al cittadin suo quivi festa
Translate: That noble soul was so excited to celebrate its fellow citizen, only for the sweet sound of his land,

Original: e ora in te non stanno sanza guerra li vivi tuoi, e l’un l’altro si rode di quei ch’un muro e una fossa serra
Translate: And now thy living inhabitants shall not cease to wage war: and they that dwell in the same city shall eat one another.

Original: Cerca, misera, intorno da le prode le tue marine, e poi ti guarda in seno, s’alcuna parte in te di pace gode
Translate: Seek, O miserable one, round about thy coasts, and look inward, if any part of thee be at peace.

Original: Che val perché ti racconciasse il freno Iustinïano, se la sella è vòta? Sanz’ esso fora la vergogna meno
Translate: What good was it for Justinian to fix your brake, if the saddle is empty? Without it the shame would be less

Original: Ahi gente che dovresti esser devota, e lasciar seder Cesare in la sella, se bene intendi ciò che Dio ti nota,
Translate: Oh people, that you should be devoted and let Caesar sit on the saddle, if you understand the word of God well,

Original: guarda come esta fiera è fatta fella per non esser corretta da li sproni, poi che ponesti mano a la predella
Translate: Look how rebellious this beast has become, that she may not be kept at bay by the spurs, for she is led by hand by the bridles.

Original: O Alberto tedesco ch’abbandoni costei ch’è fatta indomita e selvaggia, e dovresti inforcar li suoi arcioni,
Translate: O Albert of Habsburg, who abandons this beast which has become indomitable and wild, while you should infiltrate its arches,

Original: giusto giudicio da le stelle caggia sovra ’l tuo sangue, e sia novo e aperto, tal che ’l tuo successor temenza n’aggia
Translate: may a righteous punishment fall from heaven against you and your family, and be extraordinary and evident, so that your successor may be afraid of it.

Original: Ch’avete tu e ’l tuo padre sofferto, per cupidigia di costà distretti, che ’l giardin de lo ’mperio sia diserto
Translate: For you and your father have left the garden of the Empire forsaken, remaining in Germany for greed.

Original: Vieni a veder Montecchi e Cappelletti, Monaldi e Filippeschi, uom sanza cura
Translate: Come and see the Montague and the Cappelletti, the Monaldi and the Philippians, negligent man,

Original: color già tristi, e questi con sospetti
Translate: the first already in ruins and the others on the verge of falling

Original: Vien, crudel, vieni, e vedi la pressura d’i tuoi gentili, e cura lor magagne
Translate: Come, you cruel man, and see the oppressions of your feudal men, and take care of their sins.

Original: e vedrai Santafior com’ è oscura
Translate: and you'll see how dark Santa Fiora is

Original: Vieni a veder la tua Roma che piagne vedova e sola, e dì e notte chiama
Translate: Come and see your city of Rome weeping, widowed and forsaken, and day and night crying

Original: «Cesare mio, perché non m’accompagne?»
Translate: My Caesar, why do you not have your home here?

Original: Vieni a veder la gente quanto s’ama
Translate: Come and see how much you love Italians

Original: e se nulla di noi pietà ti move, a vergognar ti vien de la tua fama
Translate: And if you have no mercy on us, at least come and be ashamed of your reputation.

Original: E se licito m’è, o sommo Giove che fosti in terra per noi crucifisso, son li giusti occhi tuoi rivolti altrove?
Translate: And if I may, O Most High Jupiter, that you were crucified for us on Earth, are your righteous eyes turned elsewhere?

Original: O è preparazion che ne l’abisso del tuo consiglio fai per alcun bene in tutto de l’accorger nostro scisso?
Translate: Or in the abyss of your wisdom are you preparing a good that we cannot realize?

Original: Ché le città d’Italia tutte piene son di tiranni, e un Marcel diventa ogne villan che parteggiando viene
Translate: In fact, all Italian cities are full of tyrants, and every farmer who leads a political faction becomes a Marcello

Original: Fiorenza mia, ben puoi esser contenta di questa digression che non ti tocca, mercé del popol tuo che si argomenta
Translate: Firenze mia, you can be truly pleased that this digression does not touch you, thanks to your people who are ingenious

Original: Molti han giustizia in cuore, e tardi scocca per non venir sanza consiglio a l’arco
Translate: Many have justice in their hearts, but this is expressed late with words so as not to risk not being considered.

Original: ma il popol tuo l’ha in sommo de la bocca
Translate: but your people always fill their mouths

Original: Molti rifiutan lo comune incarco
Translate: Many refuse public office,

Original: ma il popol tuo solicito risponde sanza chiamare, e grida
Translate: but your people answer without being called, and cry out,

Original: «I’ mi sobbarco»
Translate: I'm gonna be in charge of it.

Original: Or ti fa lieta, ché tu hai ben onde
Translate: Now rejoice, for you have reason.

Original: tu ricca, tu con pace e tu con senno
Translate: You're rich, you're at peace, you're at ease.

Original: S’io dico ’l ver, l’effetto nol nasconde
Translate: If I tell the truth, the facts don't hide it.

Original: Atene e Lacedemona, che fenno l’antiche leggi e furon sì civili, fecero al viver bene un picciol cenno verso di te,
Translate: Athens and Sparta, who wrote the ancient laws and were so civilized, made a small contribution to justice in comparison with you,

Original: che fai tanto sottili provedimenti, ch’a mezzo novembre non giugne quel che tu d’ottobre fili
Translate: that such subtle measures emerge that those issued in October do not arrive in mid-November

Original: Quante volte, del tempo che rimembre, legge, moneta, officio e costume hai tu mutato, e rinovate membre
Translate: How many times, in memory of man, have you changed laws, coins and customs, and renewed the population

Original: E se ben ti ricordi e vedi lume, vedrai te somigliante a quella inferma che non può trovar posa in su le piume,
Translate: And if you remember and see clearly, you will know that you are like that sick woman who cannot find rest in the bed,

Original: ma con dar volta suo dolore scherma
Translate: but turning around constantly tries to relieve the pain

Original: Poscia che l’accoglienze oneste e liete furo iterate tre e quattro volte, Sordel si trasse, e disse
Translate: After the congratulations were repeated several times, Sordello pulled back and said,

Original: «Voi, chi siete?»
Translate: Who are you?

Original: «Anzi che a questo monte fosser volte l’anime degne di salire a Dio, fur l’ossa mie per Ottavian sepolte
Translate: Before the souls worthy to go up to God were sent to this mountain, my bones were buried by the command of Octavian.

Original: Io son Virgilio
Translate: I'm Virgilio.

Original: e per null’ altro rio lo ciel perdei che per non aver fé»
Translate: And I have lost my salvation for no other fault except that I had no faith.

Original: Così rispuose allora il duca mio
Translate: And my teacher answered him, saying,

Original: Qual è colui che cosa innanzi sé sùbita vede ond’ e’ si maraviglia, che crede e non, dicendo
Translate: Like the one who suddenly sees before him a thing that arouses his wonder, so he believes and does not believe, saying to himself,

Original: «Ella è...non è...»,
Translate: That's true... that's not true...

Original: tal parve quelli
Translate: So it seemed to me Sordello

Original: e poi chinò le ciglia, e umilmente ritornò ver’ lui, e abbracciòl là ’ve ’l minor s’appiglia
Translate: And he bowed down his eyes, and went with humility to Virgil, and embraced him there, where he that is inferior is able to do it.

Original: «O gloria di Latin», disse, «per cui mostrò ciò che potea la lingua nostra,
Translate: He said "O glory of the Italians, through whom our language showed its possibilities,

Original: o pregio etterno del loco ond’ io fui, qual merito o qual grazia mi ti mostra?
Translate: or eternal value of the place from which I am originally, for what merit or grace are you shown to me?

Original: S’io son d’udir le tue parole degno, dimmi se vien d’inferno, e di qual chiostra»
Translate: If I am worthy to hear your words, tell me if you come from Hell, and from what circle.

Original: «Per tutt’ i cerchi del dolente regno», rispuose lui, «son io di qua venuto
Translate: Virgil answered him, "I have come here through all the Circles of the Kingdom of Pain."

Original: virtù del ciel mi mosse, e con lei vegno
Translate: a virtue has moved me from Heaven and I am accompanied by her

Original: Non per far, ma per non fare ho perduto a veder l’alto Sol che tu disiri e che fu tardi per me conosciuto
Translate: I have lost the chance to see the high sun that you desire, and that I have known too late, not for what I have done, but for what I have not done.

Original: Luogo è là giù non tristo di martìri, ma di tenebre solo, ove i lamenti non suonan come guai, ma son sospiri
Translate: In Hell there is a place not afflicted by pain but only surrounded by darkness, where the lamentations do not resound like groans of sorrow but are sighs

Original: Quivi sto io coi pargoli innocenti dai denti morsi de la morte avante che fosser da l’umana colpa essenti
Translate: Here I lie with the innocent children that death took away before they were washed away by original sin

Original: quivi sto io con quei che le tre sante virtù non si vestiro, e sanza vizio conobber l’altre e seguir tutte quante
Translate: Here I reside with those who did not know the three theological virtues, and they knew and followed without fault all the others.

Original: Ma se tu sai e puoi, alcuno indizio dà noi per che venir possiam più tosto là dove purgatorio ha dritto inizio»
Translate: If you are aware of this and can do so, give us directions to allow us to reach as soon as possible where the Purgatory begins.

Original: Rispuose
Translate: He answered us.

Original: «Loco certo non c’è posto
Translate: We are not assigned any designated location.

Original: licito m’è andar suso e intorno
Translate: I'm allowed to go here and there.

Original: per quanto ir posso, a guida mi t’accosto
Translate: I'll guide you as far as I can go

Original: Ma vedi già come dichina il giorno, e andar sù di notte non si puote
Translate: But see how the sun is setting, and going up at night is impossible.

Original: però è buon pensar di bel soggiorno
Translate: So we'll have to think about where to spend the night.

Original: Anime sono a destra qua remote
Translate: There are souls, separated here on the right

Original: se mi consenti, io ti merrò ad esse, e non sanza diletto ti fier note»
Translate: If you agree, I will lead you to them, and I will show you not without your satisfaction.

Original: «Com’ è ciò?», fu risposto
Translate: Virgil answered him, "How is this possible?

Original: «Chi volesse salir di notte, fora elli impedito d’altrui, o non sarria ché non potesse?»
Translate: Who wants to go up at night would be prevented by something, or simply couldn't do so?

Original: E ’l buon Sordello in terra fregò ’l dito, dicendo
Translate: And the good Sordello drew a line on the ground, saying,

Original: «Vedi? sola questa riga non varcheresti dopo ’l sol partito
Translate: You see, after sunset, you couldn't even cross this line.

Original: non però ch’altra cosa desse briga, che la notturna tenebra, ad ir suso
Translate: Not because it would prevent you from anything but the darkness of the night.

Original: quella col nonpoder la voglia intriga
Translate: is that to prevent your will, generating the impossibility
