Original: Ben si poria con lei tornare in giuso e passeggiar la costa intorno errando, mentre che l’orizzonte il dì tien chiuso»
Translate: In the dark one could even go down and walk at this same height, as long as the sun is behind the horizon.

Original: Allora il mio segnor, quasi ammirando, «Menane», disse, «dunque là ’ve dici ch’aver si può diletto dimorando»
Translate: Then my master, astonished, said, "Take us therefore where you say that you can stay with delight."

Original: Poco allungati c’eravam di lici, quand’ io m’accorsi che ’l monte era scemo, a guisa che i vallon li sceman quici
Translate: We had just gotten away from where we were, when I realized that the mountain was hollowed, just like the valleys plowed the mountains on Earth.

Original: «Colà», disse quell’ ombra, «n’anderemo dove la costa face di sé grembo
Translate: That shadow said, "We'll go there where the wall falls down, forming a womb."

Original: e là il novo giorno attenderemo»
Translate: We'll wait there for the new day.

Original: Tra erto e piano era un sentiero schembo, che ne condusse in fianco de la lacca,
Translate: There was an oblique path between the wall of the mountain and the plain, which led us to the side of the valley,

Original: là dove più ch’a mezzo muore il lembo
Translate: at the point where the embankment sloped more than half of its height

Original: Oro e argento fine, cocco e biacca, indaco, legno lucido e sereno, fresco smeraldo in l’ora che si fiacca,
Translate: The gold and the fine silver, the carmine and the zinc white, the indigo and the polished and polished wood, the vivid emerald as when it breaks,

Original: da l’erba e da li fior, dentr’ a quel seno posti, ciascun saria di color vinto, come dal suo maggiore è vinto il meno
Translate: All these colors, placed inside that little valley, would be won by grass and flowers, as the lesser is won by the greater

Original: Non avea pur natura ivi dipinto, ma di soavità di mille odori vi facea uno incognito e indistinto
Translate: Nature had not only painted there, but mixed a thousand sweet scents that formed an odor impossible to define.

Original: ‘Salve, Regina’ in sul verde e ’n su’ fiori quindi seder cantando anime vidi, che per la valle non parean di fuori
Translate: From there I saw souls sitting on grass and flowers, singing with a voice 'Hello, Queen' and not visible from outside the valley.

Original: «Prima che ’l poco sole omai s’annidi», cominciò ’l Mantoan che ci avea vòlti, «tra color non vogliate ch’io vi guidi
Translate: The Mantovanus who had led us there said, "Before the sun, already low, sunsets completely, do not ask me to bring you down among those souls."

Original: Di questo balzo meglio li atti e ’ volti conoscerete voi di tutti quanti, che ne la lama giù tra essi accolti
Translate: You will see better the gestures and faces of all of them from this embankment, than going down into the valley.

Original: Colui che più siede alto e fa sembianti d’aver negletto ciò che far dovea,
Translate: He who sits higher and shows that he has neglected his duty,

Original: e che non move bocca a li altrui canti, Rodolfo imperador fu, che potea sanar le piaghe c’hanno Italia morta,
Translate: and who does not participate in the song of prayer, was Emperor Rodolfo first, who could heal the plagues that afflict Italy,

Original: sì che tardi per altri si ricrea
Translate: so that now others lately try to do the same

Original: L’altro che ne la vista lui conforta, resse la terra dove l’acqua nasce che Molta in Albia, e Albia in mar ne porta
Translate: The other, who seems to comfort him, ruled the land where the water that the Vltava brings to Elba was born and which the Elbe leads to the sea.

Original: Ottacchero ebbe nome, e ne le fasce fu meglio assai che Vincislao suo figlio barbuto, cui lussuria e ozio pasce
Translate: He was named Ottocarus II and as a child he was much better than his son Wenceslas II as an adult, who lives in idleness and lust.

Original: E quel nasetto che stretto a consiglio par con colui c’ha sì benigno aspetto, morì fuggendo e disfiorando il giglio
Translate: And the one with the little nose, which seems so united to the other with the benevolent aspect, died on the run and making the lily of France touch

Original: guardate là come si batte il petto
Translate: Look there, how you beat your chest

Original: L’altro vedete c’ha fatto a la guancia de la sua palma, sospirando, letto
Translate: And you see the other one who, in his sighs, leans his cheek on the palm of his hand

Original: Padre e suocero son del mal di Francia
Translate: I am respectively father and father-in-law of the evil of France

Original: sanno la vita sua viziata e lorda, e quindi viene il duol che sì li lancia
Translate: know his life full of sins and vices, and hence comes the pain that torments them so

Original: Quel che par sì membruto e che s’accorda, cantando, con colui dal maschio naso, d’ogne valor portò cinta la corda
Translate: What looks so robust and that accords its song with that other with a prominent nose was filled with every value

Original: e se re dopo lui fosse rimaso lo giovanetto che retro a lui siede, ben andava il valor di vaso in vaso,
Translate: And if after him had remained as his successor the young man who sits behind him, the value would have passed from father to son,

Original: che non si puote dir de l’altre rede
Translate: while this cannot be said of the other heirs

Original: Iacomo e Federigo hanno i reami del retaggio miglior nessun possiede
Translate: James and Frederick have his domains, and neither has inherited the value from his father.

Original: Rade volte risurge per li rami l’umana probitate
Translate: It rarely happens that human virtue is transmitted from father to son,

Original: e questo vole quei che la dà, perché da lui si chiami
Translate: and this is willed by God to grant it, that it may be asked of Him.

Original: Anche al nasuto vanno mie parole non men ch’a l’altro, Pier, che con lui canta, onde Puglia e Proenza già si dole
Translate: My words are also addressed to the Nasute, no less than to the other, Peter, who sings with him, for the kingdom of Naples and Provence are already woeful of his heir

Original: Tant’ è del seme suo minor la pianta, quanto, più che Beatrice e Margherita, Costanza di marito ancor si vanta
Translate: The plant is inferior to its seed, more than Beatrice and Margaret can boast of their husband than Constance

Original: Vedete il re de la semplice vita seder là solo, Arrigo d’Inghilterra
Translate: You see the king from the simple life, Henry the third of England, sitting there apart

Original: questi ha ne’ rami suoi migliore uscita
Translate: he left better heirs

Original: Quel che più basso tra costor s’atterra, guardando in suso, è Guiglielmo marchese,
Translate: And what sits lower than all of them, looking up, is Marquis William VII of Monferrato,

Original: per cui e Alessandria e la sua guerra fa pianger Monferrato e Canavese»
Translate: for which Alexandria with her war make the Monferrato and the Canavese weep

Original: Era già l’ora che volge il disio ai navicanti e ’ntenerisce il core lo dì c’han detto ai dolci amici addio
Translate: It was already the time that nostalgia reawakened in the sailors, the day when they said goodbye to the sweet friends,

Original: e che lo novo peregrin d’amore punge, se ode squilla di lontano che paia il giorno pianger che si more
Translate: and in which love stings the heart of those who are recently on the road, if they hear in the distance the sound of the bells that seem to weep the death of the day

Original: quand’ io incominciai a render vano l’udire e a mirare una de l’alme surta, che l’ascoltar chiedea con mano
Translate: when I began not to listen with attention and to observe one of the souls that had risen and that asked to listen with the nod of hands

Original: Ella giunse e levò ambo le palme, ficcando li occhi verso l’orïente, come dicesse a Dio
Translate: She joined and lifted up both her palms, staring at the east, and seemed to say to God,

Original: ‘D’altro non calme’
Translate: "I don't care about anything else."

Original: ‘Te lucis ante’ sì devotamente le uscìo di bocca e con sì dolci note, che fece me a me uscir di mente
Translate: The hymn Te lucis ante came out of her mouth with so much devotion and with so sweet notes, that it absorbed all my attention

Original: e l’altre poi dolcemente e devote seguitar lei per tutto l’inno intero, avendo li occhi a le superne rote
Translate: And the other souls also followed her with devotion and sweetness throughout the time of the hymn, staring at heaven.

Original: Aguzza qui, lettor, ben li occhi al vero, ché ’l velo è ora ben tanto sottile, certo che ’l trapassar dentro è leggero
Translate: O reader, sharpen your gaze carefully to the true, for the allegorical veil is here so thin that it is easy to pass through it

Original: Io vidi quello essercito gentile tacito poscia riguardare in sùe, quasi aspettando, palido e umìle
Translate: I saw that noble host of souls, afterward, looking upward as in expectation, pale and humble

Original: e vidi uscir de l’alto e scender giùe due angeli con due spade affocate, tronche e private de le punte sue
Translate: And I saw two angels coming down out of heaven with flaming swords, and with torches, and without tips.

Original: Verdi come fogliette pur mo nate erano in veste, che da verdi penne percosse traean dietro e ventilate
Translate: They wore green robes like freshly born leaves, which they carried behind and ventilated with green feathers.

Original: L’un poco sovra noi a star si venne, e l’altro scese in l’opposita sponda, sì che la gente in mezzo si contenne
Translate: One settled upon us, and the other went down to the opposite side, so that the souls gathered themselves together in the middle.

Original: Ben discernëa in lor la testa bionda
Translate: I could see their blond hair well,

Original: ma ne la faccia l’occhio si smarria, come virtù ch’a troppo si confonda
Translate: But my gaze was lost in their faces, as when the visual power is overwhelmed by something too superior

Original: «Ambo vegnon del grembo di Maria», disse Sordello, «a guardia de la valle, per lo serpente che verrà vie via»
Translate: Sordello said "Both come from the womb of Mary, to guard the valley from the serpent that will arrive shortly"

Original: Ond’ io, che non sapeva per qual calle, mi volsi intorno, e stretto m’accostai, tutto gelato, a le fidate spalle
Translate: Then I, who didn't know which way he was coming, looked around me and held on to my trusted guide, all frozen up.

Original: E Sordello anco
Translate: And Sordello went on

Original: «Or avvalliamo omai tra le grandi ombre, e parleremo ad esse
Translate: Now we can go down into the valley among the great shadows, and we will speak to them.

Original: grazïoso fia lor vedervi assai»
Translate: It will be pleasant to meet you.

Original: Solo tre passi credo ch’i’ scendesse, e fui di sotto,
Translate: I think I just went down three steps, and I was downstairs.

Original: e vidi un che mirava pur me, come conoscer mi volesse
Translate: I saw a spirit looking at me with insistence, as if it wanted to recognize me.

Original: Temp’ era già che l’aere s’annerava, ma non sì che tra li occhi suoi e ’ miei non dichiarisse ciò che pria serrava
Translate: By now the air was darkened, but not to the point that between our mutual gaze it did not become manifest what was previously hidden

Original: Ver’ me si fece, e io ver’ lui mi fei
Translate: And he came to meet me, and I came near.

Original: giudice Nin gentil, quanto mi piacque quando ti vidi non esser tra ’ rei
Translate: O noble judge Nino , how glad I was to see that you were not among the damned

Original: Nullo bel salutar tra noi si tacque
Translate: We greeted each other with great courtesy,

Original: poi dimandò
Translate: then he asked

Original: «Quant’ è che tu venisti a piè del monte per le lontane acque?»
Translate: How long have you been at the foot of the mountain through distant waters?

Original: «Oh», diss’ io lui,
Translate: Oh, I answered him,

Original: «per entro i luoghi tristi venni stamane, e sono in prima vita, ancor che l’altra, sì andando, acquisti»
Translate: "I arrived this morning through Hell and I am still alive, although on this journey I purchase the eternal one"

Original: E come fu la mia risposta udita, Sordello ed elli in dietro si raccolse come gente di sùbito smarrita
Translate: And as soon as my answer was heard, he and Sordello pulled back as people suddenly lost

Original: L’uno a Virgilio e l’altro a un si volse che sedea lì, gridando
Translate: Sordello turned to Virgilio, and Nino to a soul sitting next to him, crying out.

Original: «Sù, Currado
Translate: Up, Corrado

Original: vieni a veder che Dio per grazia volse»
Translate: Come and see what God has permitted for his grace.

Original: Poi, vòlto a me
Translate: Then, turning to me, he said,

Original: «Per quel singular grado che tu dei a colui che sì nasconde lo suo primo perché, che non lì è guado,
Translate: In the name of that particular gratitude which you owe to God, who hides our reason before his work and does not allow us to know her,

Original: quando sarai di là da le larghe onde, dì a Giovanna mia che per me chiami là dove a li ’nnocenti si risponde
Translate: When you return to Earth, tell my daughter Joan to pray for me where you answer the innocent.

Original: Non credo che la sua madre più m’ami, poscia che trasmutò le bianche bende, le quai convien che, misera,
Translate: I don't think his mother loves me anymore, ever since he changed the white bandages of mourning and that, poor thing,

Original: ancor brami
Translate: will have to regret

Original: Per lei assai di lieve si comprende quanto in femmina foco d’amor dura, se l’occhio o ’l tatto spesso non l’accende
Translate: With his example you can easily understand how little the fire of love lasts in a woman, if the sight or touch does not raise him often

Original: Non le farà sì bella sepultura la vipera che Melanesi accampa, com’ avria fatto il gallo di Gallura»
Translate: The viper who constitutes the coat of arms of the Milanese will not bear his sepulchre as well, as the Gallura's rooster would have done.

Original: Così dicea, segnato de la stampa, nel suo aspetto, di quel dritto zelo che misuratamente in core avvampa
Translate: So he said, with an expression that showed the righteous indignation which burned with measure in his heart.

Original: Li occhi miei ghiotti andavan pur al cielo, pur là dove le stelle son più tarde, sì come rota più presso a lo stelo
Translate: My greedy eyes went continually to the sky, where the stars rotate slower, as does a wheel closer to its axis.

Original: E ’l duca mio
Translate: And my teacher

Original: «Figliuol, che là sù guarde?»
Translate: Son, what are you looking at up there?

Original: E io a lui
Translate: And I to him

Original: «A quelle tre facelle di che ’l polo di qua tutto quanto arde»
Translate: Those three stars that shine with their splendour all the southern sky.

Original: Ond’ elli a me
Translate: Then he said to me,

Original: «Le quattro chiare stelle che vedevi staman, son di là basse, e queste son salite ov’ eran quelle»
Translate: The four shining stars that you saw this morning fell behind the mountain, and these arose in their place.

Original: Com’ ei parlava, e Sordello a sé il trasse dicendo
Translate: As he spoke, Sordello drew him to himself and said,

Original: «Vedi là ’l nostro avversaro»
Translate: Look at our opponent there.

Original: e drizzò il dito perché ’n là guardasse
Translate: and pointed his finger at him to show him

Original: Da quella parte onde non ha riparo la picciola vallea, era una biscia, forse qual diede ad Eva il cibo amaro
Translate: On that side from which the little valley had no defense, there was a very similar kiss, perhaps, to the one that gave Eve the forbidden fruit.

Original: Tra l’erba e ’ fior venìa la mala striscia, volgendo ad ora ad or la testa, e ’l dosso leccando come bestia che si liscia
Translate: The evil serpent crawled between the grass and the flowers, sometimes turning back his head and licking his back like a beast when he smoothed his skin or hair

Original: Io non vidi, e però dicer non posso, come mosser li astor celestïali
Translate: I didn't see, so I can't report how the celestial scatterers moved.

Original: ma vidi bene e l’uno e l’altro mosso
Translate: But I saw clearly that both of them had moved.

Original: Sentendo fender l’aere a le verdi ali, fuggì ’l serpente, e li angeli dier volta, suso a le poste rivolando iguali
Translate: Hearing that the green wings were breaking the air, the serpent fled, and the angels went away, flying with their seats.

Original: L’ombra che s’era al giudice raccolta quando chiamò, per tutto quello assalto punto non fu da me guardare sciolta
Translate: The soul that approached Judge Nino when he called her, during all that assault, never stopped looking at me

Original: «Se la lucerna che ti mena in alto truovi nel tuo arbitrio tanta cera quant’ è mestiere infino al sommo smalto», cominciò ella,
Translate: Then began the torch that leads you up to find so much wax in your will, how much it will take to take you to the enameled top of the mountain

Original: «se novella vera di Val di Magra o di parte vicina sai, dillo a me, che già grande là era
Translate: If you have heard of Val di Magra or a place nearby, tell me, for I was there a mighty man.

Original: Fui chiamato Currado Malaspina
Translate: I was called Corrado Malaspina

Original: non son l’antico, ma di lui discesi
Translate: Not the Elder, though I am his descendant.

Original: a’ miei portai l’amor che qui raffina»
Translate: I loved my family with an excessive love, which is purified here.

Original: «Oh», diss’ io lui,
Translate: 'Oh,' I answered,

Original: «per li vostri paesi già mai non fui
Translate: I have never been in your lands,

Original: ma dove si dimora per tutta Europa ch’ei non sien palesi?
Translate: But where can we go across Europe without them being known?

Original: La fama che la vostra casa onora, grida i segnori e grida la contrada, sì che ne sa chi non vi fu ancora
Translate: The fame that honors your house is celebrated by the lords and the people, so that even those who have not been there are aware of it.

Original: e io vi giuro, s’io di sopra vada, che vostra gente onrata non si sfregia del pregio de la borsa e de la spada
Translate: And I swear to you that your honored people have never lost the value of their purse and sword.

Original: Uso e natura sì la privilegia, che, perché il capo reo il mondo torca, sola va dritta e ’l mal cammin dispregia»
Translate: Cavalry's custom and natural qualities favour it to such an extent that even if the world continues to turn its head to evil, it alone goes straight and despises every evil way.

Original: Ed elli
Translate: And him

Original: «Or va
Translate: "Now go."

Original: che ’l sol non si ricorca sette volte nel letto che ’l Montone con tutti e quattro i piè cuopre e inforca,
Translate: the sun will not be joined seven more times with the constellation of the ram in which it is now fully found,

Original: che cotesta cortese oppinïone ti fia chiavata in mezzo de la testa con maggior chiovi che d’altrui sermone,
Translate: before this courteous opinion nailed you to the center of your head with more effective arguments than other people's speeches,

Original: se corso di giudicio non s’arresta»
Translate: if the divine decrees will not change

Original: La concubina di Titone antico già s’imbiancava al balco d’orïente, fuor de le braccia del suo dolce amico
Translate: The bride of the old Titone already looked pale on the east balcony, out of the embrace of her sweet lover

Original: di gemme la sua fronte era lucente, poste in figura del freddo animale che con la coda percuote la gente
Translate: His forehead shone with gems, set to form the figure of the cold animal that strikes people with the tail

Original: e la notte, de’ passi con che sale, fatti avea due nel loco ov’ eravamo, e ’l terzo già chinava in giuso l’ale
Translate: and the night had taken two of the steps with which he went up, in the place where we were, and the third was almost finished.

Original: quand’ io, che meco avea di quel d’Adamo, vinto dal sonno, in su l’erba inchinai là ’ve già tutti e cinque sedavamo
Translate: When I, who had a body in the flesh, was overcome by sleep, lay on the grass where all five of us were already sitting.

Original: Ne l’ora che comincia i tristi lai la rondinella presso a la mattina, forse a memoria de’ suo’ primi guai,
Translate: At the hour when the swallow, near the dawn, begins its sad scream, perhaps remembering its first pains,

Original: e che la mente nostra, peregrina più da la carne e men da’ pensier presa, a le sue visïon quasi è divina,
Translate: and in which our mind, detached from the body and less grasped by thoughts, makes dreams revealing,

Original: in sogno mi parea veder sospesa un’aguglia nel ciel con penne d’oro, con l’ali aperte e a calare intesa
Translate: I thought I saw in my dream an eagle with golden feathers, flying in the sky with her wings spread out and coming down

Original: ed esser mi parea là dove fuoro abbandonati i suoi da Ganimede, quando fu ratto al sommo consistoro
Translate: And it seemed to me to be there where Ganymede left his companions, when he was kidnapped to the supreme council of the gods.

Original: Fra me pensava
Translate: Between me I thought

Original: ‘Forse questa fiede pur qui per uso, e forse d’altro loco disdegna di portarne suso in piede’
Translate: 'Perhaps this eagle usually strikes here, and perhaps disdains to guard its prey elsewhere'

Original: Poi mi parea che, poi rotata un poco, terribil come folgor discendesse, e me rapisse suso infino al foco
Translate: Then it seemed to me that, after a little wandering, it would come down like lightning and snatch me to the sphere of fire.

Original: Ivi parea che ella e io ardesse
Translate: There I felt like I was burning with her.

Original: e sì lo ’ncendio imaginato cosse, che convenne che ’l sonno si rompesse
Translate: And that dreamed fire burned me to such an extent that it was inevitable that the dream would end.

Original: Non altrimenti Achille si riscosse, li occhi svegliati rivolgendo in giro e non sappiendo là dove si fosse,
Translate: Achilles did not raise up differently, turning his eyes around and not knowing where he was,

Original: quando la madre da Chirón a Schiro trafuggò lui dormendo in le sue braccia, là onde poi li Greci il dipartiro
Translate: When his mother took him away from Chiron, taking him to Shirus in her arms, where the Greeks took him away.

Original: che mi scoss’ io, sì come da la faccia mi fuggì ’l sonno, e diventa’ ismorto, come fa l’uom che, spaventato, agghiaccia
Translate: So I took myself, as soon as the sleep escaped from my face, and paled, as the frightened man that froze.

Original: Dallato m’era solo il mio conforto, e ’l sole er’ alto già più che due ore, e ’l viso m’era a la marina torto
Translate: There was only Virgil beside me, and the sun was already high for more than two hours, and my gaze was toward the sea.

Original: «Non aver tema», disse il mio segnore
Translate: My teacher said, "Don't be afraid,"

Original: «fatti sicur, ché noi semo a buon punto
Translate: Reinsured, in fact we are well on track

Original: non stringer, ma rallarga ogne vigore
Translate: do not brake, but rather strengthen all your energy

Original: Tu se’ omai al purgatorio giunto
Translate: You've come to Purgatory by now.

Original: vedi là il balzo che ’l chiude dintorno
Translate: See there the rocky wall that surrounds it all around

Original: vedi l’entrata là ’ve par digiunto
Translate: You see the entrance, where it seems to be split.

Original: Dianzi, ne l’alba che procede al giorno, quando l’anima tua dentro dormia, sovra li fiori ond’ è là giù addorno venne una donna, -
Translate: A little while ago, on the dawn before the day, when you were deeply asleep, a woman came to that place adorned with flowers.

Original: e disse
Translate: and said,

Original: “I’ son Lucia
Translate: "I am Lucia

Original: lasciatemi pigliar costui che dorme
Translate: Let me take him who sleeps

Original: sì l’agevolerò per la sua via”
Translate: I will help him to make his way."

Original: Sordel rimase e l’altre genti forme
Translate: Sordello and the other noble souls remained there

Original: ella ti tolse, e come ’l dì fu chiaro, sen venne suso
Translate: She took you, and as soon as it was day, she came up here.

Original: e io per le sue orme
Translate: and I followed her

Original: Qui ti posò, ma pria mi dimostraro li occhi suoi belli quella intrata aperta
Translate: He laid you down here, but first his beautiful eyes showed me that entrance.

Original: poi ella e ’l sonno ad una se n’andaro»
Translate: Then he went away with your sleep.

Original: A guisa d’uom che ’n dubbio si raccerta e che muta in conforto sua paura, poi che la verità li è discoperta, mi cambia’ io
Translate: As a man who, in doubt, reassures himself and turns his fear into comfort, after the truth has been revealed to him, so I became

Original: e come sanza cura vide me ’l duca mio, su per lo balzo si mosse, e io di rietro inver’ l’altura
Translate: And as soon as the master saw me without worry, he went to the rocky wall, and I followed him up.

Original: Lettor, tu vedi ben com’ io innalzo la mia matera, e però con più arte non ti maravigliar s’io la rincalzo
Translate: O reader, you see well how I raise the matter of my song, so don't be surprised if I strengthen it with a more refined art

Original: Noi ci appressammo, ed eravamo in parte che là dove pareami prima rotto,
Translate: We approached and we were at the point where where the wall seemed to be broken before,

Original: pur come un fesso che muro diparte, vidi una porta, e tre gradi di sotto per gire ad essa, di color diversi,
Translate: Just like a wall crossed by a crack, I saw a door, and under it three steps to go up to it, of different colors,

Original: e un portier ch’ancor non facea motto
Translate: and a guardian angel who said nothing

Translate: My teacher answered him, "A woman in heaven, an expert on these things, said to us a little while ago.

Translate: The courteous guardian filmed "Ed ella can help you to continue happily

Translate: He told us "Every time one of these keys doesn't work and doesn't turn properly in the patch,

Translate: And he told me that I should be wrong to open the door, rather than to keep it closed, as long as the penitent throw themselves at my feet.

Translate: Then he pushed the door of the sacred door, saying,

Translate: Entrance

Translate: There were sculptures of white marble and finely carved, so that not only Polyclete, but nature itself would be won

Translate: God, who never saw anything new, produced these dialogues perceptible with sight, which seems incredible to us as here, on Earth, does not exist.

Translate: While I was pleased to observe the image of so many examples of humility, precious to the artist who produced them,

Translate: My eyes, which were glad to observe to see new things of which they were eager, were not slow to turn toward him.

Translate: "Master, what I see moving toward us does not seem to me human souls, and I don't know what it is, so I don't distinguish well with my sight"

Translate: And him to me

Translate: The grave condition of their punishment makes them bend to the ground, so that even my gaze before was uncertain

Translate: But look carefully in there, and with eyes separates what lies beneath the boulders above

Translate: As your angels make sacrifice to you of their will, singing 'Hannah', so do the men of their

Translate: tormented to a different extent, all in the round and prostrate along the I Frame, purging the traces of their earthly sins

Translate: show us which way you go faster to the scale

Translate: It was not clear from whom the words that were given in response to these spoken by my teacher came

Translate: Come with us to the right along the wall, and you will find the passageway to a living person

Translate: I would look at him who is still alive and does not say his name, to see if I know him and make him pitiful of my torment.

Original: Io fui latino e nato d’un gran Tosco

Original: non so se ’l nome suo già mai fu vosco

Original: come i Sanesi sanno, e sallo in Campagnatico ogne fante
Translate: as the Sienese well know, and as every child knows at Campagnatico

Translate: And pride doth not harm me only, because it hath involved all my brethren in his evil.

Original: E qui convien ch’io questo peso porti per lei, tanto che a Dio si sodisfaccia, poi ch’io nol fe’ tra ’ vivi, qui tra ’ morti»
Translate: And it is necessary that I bear this burden because of him, until God will please, here among the dead, for I did not do it among the living.

Original: Ascoltando chinai in giù la faccia
Translate: As I listened, I bowed down my face.

Translate: And having hard eyes fixed upon me, that I went with them all bowed down.

Translate: "Oh, I told him,

Translate: Are you not Oderisi, the honor of Gubbio and that art that is called 'enluminer' in Paris?

Original: «Frate», diss’ elli, «più ridon le carte che pennelleggia Franco Bolognese
Translate: "Brother," he said, "the codes that decorate Franco Bolognese are more appreciated."

Original: l’onore è tutto or suo, e mio in parte
Translate: the honor is all yours and mine only in part

Original: Ben non sare’ io stato sì cortese mentre ch’io vissi, per lo gran disio de l’eccellenza ove mio core intese
Translate: Surely I would not have been so courteous when I was alive, for the great desire of excellence which my heart was stretched out.

Original: Di tal superbia qui si paga il fio

Translate: And I wouldn't be here if I hadn't turned to God when I could still sin.

Original: Oh vana gloria de l’umane posse
Translate: Oh vain glory of human abilities

Original: com’ poco verde in su la cima dura, se non è giunta da l’etati grosse
Translate: how little remains green on the branch, if it is not followed by decadent age

Original: Credette Cimabue ne la pittura tener lo campo, e ora ha Giotto il grido, sì che la fama di colui è scura
Translate: Cimabue believed to excel in painting, while Giotto is now the master and has obscured his fame

Original: Così ha tolto l’uno a l’altro Guido la gloria de la lingua
Translate: In the same way Guido took away the glory of the tongue from the other Guido,

Original: e forse è nato chi l’uno e l’altro caccerà del nido
Translate: And maybe it's already born who will win them both

Original: Non è il mondan romore altro ch’un fiato di vento, ch’or vien quinci e or vien quindi, e muta nome perché muta lato
Translate: The earthly fame is nothing but a breath of wind, which now blows on one side and now on the other, and changes its name according to the direction

Original: Che voce avrai tu più, se vecchia scindi da te la carne, che se fossi morto anzi che tu lasciassi il ‘pappo’ e ’l ‘dindi’, pria che passin mill’ anni? ch’è più corto spazio a l’etterno, ch’un muover di ciglia al cerchio che più tardi in cielo è torto
Translate: Do you think you have a greater fame if you die as an old man, instead of being dead when you were still speaking in a childish way, before a thousand years have passed? This is a very short time compared to eternity, shorter than a blink of an eye compared to the movement of the sky that moves more slowly

Original: Colui che del cammin sì poco piglia dinanzi a me, Toscana sonò tutta
Translate: He who walks in slow steps before me was once known throughout Tuscany.

Original: e ora a pena in Siena sen pispiglia, ond’ era sire quando fu distrutta la rabbia fiorentina, che superba fu a quel tempo sì com’ ora è putta
Translate: Now his name is hardly whispered in Siena, of which he was lord when the Florentine rage was destroyed, which at that time was superb as it is now turned to corruption

Original: La vostra nominanza è color d’erba, che viene e va, e quei la discolora per cui ella esce de la terra acerba»
Translate: Your fame is like the green of the grass, which goes and comes, and is wiped out by the sun that makes the grass itself grow from the earth.

Original: E io a lui
Translate: And I to him

Original: «Tuo vero dir m’incora bona umiltà, e gran tumor m’appiani
Translate: Your true words inspire me good humility, and lower my great pride.

Original: ma chi è quei di cui tu parlavi ora?»
Translate: But who's the one you were talking about just now?

Original: «Quelli è», rispuose, «Provenzan Salvani
Translate: He said "That's Provenzan Salvani."

Original: ed è qui perché fu presuntüoso a recar Siena tutta a le sue mani
Translate: and is here because he had the presumption to reduce Siena to his power

Original: Ito è così e va, sanza riposo, poi che morì
Translate: Since he died he has walked like this and continues without rest

Original: cotal moneta rende a sodisfar chi è di là troppo oso»
Translate: the one who has dared too much on Earth is serving this penalty.

Original: E io
Translate: And I...

Original: «Se quello spirito ch’attende, pria che si penta, l’orlo de la vita, qua giù dimora e qua sù non ascende,
Translate: If that spirit that waits to repent at the point of death, must rest in the Antipurgatory and not go up to Purgatory for all the time that lasted his life,

Original: se buona orazïon lui non aita, prima che passi tempo quanto visse, come fu la venuta lui largita?»
Translate: unless a good prayer helps him, how was he allowed to come here?

Original: «Quando vivea più glorïoso», disse, «liberamente nel Campo di Siena, ogne vergogna diposta, s’affisse
Translate: When he was at the height of power, he said, "Freely he set himself in Piazza del Campo in Siena, put aside every shame."

Original: e lì, per trar l’amico suo di pena, ch’e’ sostenea ne la prigion di Carlo, si condusse a tremar per ogne vena
Translate: And there, to redeem his friend who had been captured by Charles of Anjou from captivity, he subjected himself to a terrible humiliation.

Original: Più non dirò, e scuro so che parlo
Translate: I won't say more and I know I'm talking in a dark way

Original: ma poco tempo andrà, che ’ tuoi vicini faranno sì che tu potrai chiosarlo
Translate: But it will be a short time before your fellow citizens make sure that you can experience it in person.

Original: Quest’ opera li tolse quei confini»
Translate: That action allowed him to access the Frame immediately.

Original: Di pari, come buoi che vanno a giogo, m’andava io con quell’ anima carca, fin che ’l sofferse il dolce pedagogo
Translate: I went on side by side with that soul bent under the weight of the boulder, like two oxen yoked, until Virgil tolerated it.

Original: Ma quando disse
Translate: But when he said,

Original: «Lascia lui e varca
Translate: Leave it and move on

Original: ché qui è buono con l’ali e coi remi, quantunque può, ciascun pinger sua barca»
Translate: For here it is good for everyone to push his boat, as best he can, with sails and oars.

Original: dritto sì come andar vuolsi rife’mi con la persona, avvegna che i pensieri mi rimanessero e chinati e scemi
Translate: And I went back to straighten up my figure as when walking, even though my thoughts were humble and prostrated.

Original: Io m’era mosso, e seguia volontieri del mio maestro i passi, e amendue già mostravam com’ eravam leggeri
Translate: I had moved, and I gladly followed the steps of my master, and we both showed that we were being sent.

Original: ed el mi disse
Translate: And he said to me,

Original: «Volgi li occhi in giùe
Translate: Lower your eyes to the ground

Original: buon ti sarà, per tranquillar la via, veder lo letto de le piante tue»
Translate: It will be good for you to see where your feet stand, so that you can calm your path.

Original: Come, perché di lor memoria sia, sovra i sepolti le tombe terragne portan segnato quel ch’elli eran pria,
Translate: As the graves dug on the ground carry over the buried lids with the effigy of the dead, to remember them,

Original: onde lì molte volte si ripiagne per la puntura de la rimembranza, che solo a’ pïi dà de le calcagne
Translate: for which there is often nostalgia of one's loved ones for the pain of remembrance that stimulates only godly men

Original: sì vid’ io lì, ma di miglior sembianza secondo l’artificio, figurato quanto per via di fuor del monte avanza
Translate: So I saw the floor of the Frame carved out of the mountain, but in a more refined way because it was the work of God.

Original: Vedea colui che fu nobil creato più ch’altra creatura, giù dal cielo folgoreggiando scender, da l’un lato
Translate: On the one hand I saw the one who was created nobler than any other creature, who fell down from Heaven struck by lightning.

Original: Vedëa Brïareo fitto dal telo celestïal giacer, da l’altra parte, grave a la terra per lo mortal gelo
Translate: I saw Briareus lying on the other side after he was struck by the lightning of Jupiter, heavy on the ground and ice cream from death.

Original: Vedea Timbreo, vedea Pallade e Marte, armati ancora, intorno al padre loro, mirar le membra d’i Giganti sparte
Translate: I saw Apollos, Athena, Mars, still armed, and around their father Jupiter, watching the scattered members of the giants.

Original: Vedea Nembròt a piè del gran lavoro quasi smarrito, e riguardar le genti che ’n Sennaàr con lui superbi fuoro
Translate: I saw Nembrod at the foot of the great work that was almost lost, looking at the people who were proud with him at Sennaar.

Original: O Nïobè, con che occhi dolenti vedea io te segnata in su la strada, tra sette e sette tuoi figliuoli spenti
Translate: O Niobe, with whose sorrowful eyes I saw you sculpted on the road, among your fourteen sons slain.

Original: O Saùl, come in su la propria spada quivi parevi morto in Gelboè, che poi non sentì pioggia né rugiada
Translate: O Saul, as you seemed to be dead, there in the sculpture, on your sword at Gelboah, where no rain or dew fell afterwards.

Original: O folle Aragne, sì vedea io te già mezza ragna, trista in su li stracci de l’opera che mal per te si fé
Translate: O mad Aracnes, I saw you half-turned into a spider, sad about the rags of the work which thou didst produce to thy injury.

Original: O Roboàm, già non par che minacci quivi ’l tuo segno
Translate: O Rehoboam, here your image does not seem to threaten,

Original: ma pien di spavento nel porta un carro, sanza ch’altri il cacci
Translate: but it appears full of fear and carried away by a chariot, without anyone chasing it.

Original: Mostrava ancor lo duro pavimento come Almeon a sua madre fé caro parer lo sventurato addornamento
Translate: The hard floor still showed how Alcmeone made his mother look precious to the wretched jewelry

Original: Mostrava come i figli si gittaro sovra Sennacherìb dentro dal tempio, e come, morto lui, quivi il lasciaro
Translate: He showed how his sons hurled themselves against Sennacherib in the temple, and how they left him here after they killed him.

Original: Mostrava la ruina e ’l crudo scempio che fé Tamiri, quando disse a Ciro
Translate: He showed the ruin and cruel destruction that Tamiri made of Cyrus, when he said to him,

Original: «Sangue sitisti, e io di sangue t’empio»
Translate: You've had a thirst for blood, and I'll fill you with blood.

Original: Mostrava come in rotta si fuggiro li Assiri, poi che fu morto Oloferne, e anche le reliquie del martiro
Translate: He showed how the Assyrians fled in course, after Holofernes was killed, and also what was left of his beheaded trunk.

Original: Vedeva Troia in cenere e in caverne
Translate: I saw Troy reduced to ashes and ruins

Original: o Ilïón, come te basso e vile mostrava il segno che lì si discerne
Translate: O Ilio, as he showed you low and vile the sculpture that you see there

Original: Qual di pennel fu maestro o di stile che ritraesse l’ombre e ’ tratti ch’ivi mirar farieno uno ingegno sottile?
Translate: What master of painting or drawing was there ever, capable of portraying the figures and traits that there, in Purgatory, would amaze a refined ingenuity?

Original: Morti li morti e i vivi parean vivi
Translate: The dead seemed dead, and the living seemed alive.

Original: non vide mei di me chi vide il vero, quant’ io calcai, fin che chinato givi
Translate: He who saw the royal scene saw no better than me, until I looked down at the carved scenes that I was treading.

Original: Or superbite, e via col viso altero, figliuoli d’Eva, e non chinate il volto sì che veggiate il vostro mal sentero
Translate: Then exalt yourselves, the children of Eve, and go forward with your face high, and bow not your eyes to see your way evil.

Original: Più era già per noi del monte vòlto e del cammin del sole assai più speso che non stimava l’animo non sciolto,
Translate: We had traveled a greater part of the mountain and spent a larger part of the day than my concentrated soul did,

Original: quando colui che sempre innanzi atteso andava, cominciò
Translate: When he who went on always attentive, said to me,

Original: «Drizza la testa
Translate: Raise your head

Original: non è più tempo di gir sì sospeso
Translate: It is no longer time to walk with your gaze on the ground

Original: Vedi colà un angel che s’appresta per venir verso noi
Translate: See there an angel coming to us

Original: vedi che torna dal servigio del dì l’ancella sesta
Translate: See that the sixth hour returns after performing his service a day

Original: Di reverenza il viso e li atti addorna, sì che i diletti lo ’nvïarci in suso
Translate: Make your face and gestures reverent, so that he willingly addresses us upwards

Original: pensa che questo dì mai non raggiorna»
Translate: thinks that this day will never come back

Original: Io era ben del suo ammonir uso pur di non perder tempo, sì che ’n quella materia non potea parlarmi chiuso
Translate: I was accustomed to these admonitions so as not to waste time, so that on that subject he could not speak to me in a dark way.

Original: A noi venìa la creatura bella, biancovestito e ne la faccia quale par tremolando mattutina stella
Translate: The beautiful creature came to us, clothed in white, and with her face shining like the morning star.

Original: Le braccia aperse, e indi aperse l’ale
Translate: He opened his arms, and opened his wings wide.

Original: disse
Translate: said

Original: «Venite
Translate: Come on

Original: qui son presso i gradi, e agevolemente omai si sale
Translate: the steps are near here, and now you climb easily

Original: A questo invito vegnon molto radi
Translate: Few souls gather this invitation

Original: o gente umana, per volar sù nata, perché a poco vento così cadi?»
Translate: or men, born to fly high, why do you fall low for any breath of wind?

Original: Menocci ove la roccia era tagliata
Translate: He led us to where the rock was cut.

Original: quivi mi batté l’ali per la fronte
Translate: Here he struck my forehead with wings

Original: poi mi promise sicura l’andata
Translate: Then he promised me a safe path

Original: Come a man destra, per salire al monte dove siede la chiesa che soggioga la ben guidata sopra Rubaconte,
Translate: As on the right side, to climb to the mountain where stands the church that dominates the well-governed city above Rubaconte,

Original: si rompe del montar l’ardita foga per le scalee che si fero ad etade ch’era sicuro il quaderno e la doga
Translate: the steep wall becomes lighter thanks to stairs that were built at a time when the notebook and customs were safer

Original: così s’allenta la ripa che cade quivi ben ratta da l’altro girone
Translate: So the wall of the mountain, which falls steeply from the other frame, becomes sweeter,

Original: ma quinci e quindi l’alta pietra rade
Translate: But the high rock holds it on one side and on the other.

Original: Noi volgendo ivi le nostre persone, ‘Beati pauperes spiritu’ voci cantaron sì, che nol diria sermone
Translate: As we were about to climb up, voices sang 'Blessed are the poor of spirit', so sweet that it would be impossible to describe it in words

Original: Ahi quanto son diverse quelle foci da l’infernali
Translate: Ah, how different are those accesses from those of Hell?

Original: ché quivi per canti s’entra, e là giù per lamenti feroci
Translate: in fact here you enter greeted by songs, there by ferocious laments

Original: Già montavam su per li scaglion santi, ed esser mi parea troppo più lieve che per lo pian non mi parea davanti
Translate: Now we went up those holy stairs, and it seemed to me that I was lighter aces than I was before when I walked down the plain.

Original: Ond’ io
Translate: Then I said,

Original: «Maestro, dì,
Translate: Master, tell me

Original: qual cosa greve levata s’è da me, che nulla quasi per me fatica, andando, si riceve?»
Translate: What weight has been lifted from me, so that as I proceed I feel almost no fatigue?

Original: Rispuose
Translate: He answered me.

Original: «Quando i P che son rimasi ancor nel volto tuo presso che stinti, saranno, com’ è l’un, del tutto rasi,
Translate: When the Ps that are still on your forehead, even if faded, will be erased as was the first,

Original: fier li tuoi piè dal buon voler sì vinti, che non pur non fatica sentiranno, ma fia diletto loro esser sù pinti»
Translate: Your feet will be overcome by good will to the point that not only will they not feel fatigue, but they will be pleased to be pushed up.

Original: Allor fec’ io come color che vanno con cosa in capo non da lor saputa, se non che ’ cenni altrui sospecciar fanno
Translate: Then I did as those who go with something in their heads that they don't know, except because others do gestures that make them imagine

Original: per che la mano ad accertar s’aiuta, e cerca e truova e quello officio adempie che non si può fornir per la veduta
Translate: so that the hand will check and seek and find and carry out that task which cannot be accomplished by sight

Original: e con le dita de la destra scempie trovai pur sei le lettere che ’ncise quel da le chiavi a me sovra le tempie
Translate: And with the fingers of my right hand cut off from one another I found only six of the letters that the guardian angel had engraved on my temples.

Original: a che guardando, il mio duca sorrise
Translate: And when he saw all this, my teacher smiled,

Original: Noi eravamo al sommo de la scala, dove secondamente si risega lo monte che salendo altrui dismala
Translate: We were at the top of the ladder where the mountain, which, as it ascends, purifies from sins, is cut off for the second time.

Original: Ivi così una cornice lega dintorno il poggio, come la primaia
Translate: There a frame surrounds the mountain as the first,

Original: se non che l’arco suo più tosto piega
Translate: unless its circumference is smaller

Original: Ombra non lì è né segno che si paia
Translate: There is no image there, no sculpture

Original: parsi la ripa e parsi la via schietta col livido color de la petraia
Translate: the wall of the mountain and the road are smooth, of the color livid of the stone

Original: «Se qui per dimandar gente s’aspetta», ragionava il poeta, «io temo forse che troppo avrà d’indugio nostra eletta»
Translate: If we wait here for someone to ask, Virgil reflected, I think that perhaps our choice will make us linger too much.

Original: Poi fisamente al sole li occhi porse
Translate: Then he looked intensely at the sun

Original: fece del destro lato a muover centro, e la sinistra parte di sé torse
Translate: he made a pin on his right foot, and tormented the left side of his body.

Original: «O dolce lume a cui fidanza i’ entro per lo novo cammin, tu ne conduci», dicea, «come condur si vuol quinc’ entro
Translate: "O sweet light, trusting in which I take the new path, you guide us," he said, "how it is to be done in this place."

Original: Tu scaldi il mondo, tu sovr’ esso luci
Translate: You warm the world and enlighten it

Original: s’altra ragione in contrario non ponta, esser dien sempre li tuoi raggi duci»
Translate: If there is no reason openly contrary, your rays must always be guided.

Original: Quanto di qua per un migliaio si conta, tanto di là eravam noi già iti, con poco tempo, per la voglia pronta
Translate: We had moved from there as much as it corresponds here on Earth a mile, in a short time for the burning desire

Original: e verso noi volar furon sentiti, non però visti, spiriti parlando a la mensa d’amor cortesi inviti
Translate: And, behold, we heard, without seeing them, spirits flying and speaking kindly invitations to the table of charity.

Original: La prima voce che passò volando ‘Vinum non habent’ altamente disse,
Translate: The first voice that flew by said, crying 'They have no wine',

Original: e dietro a noi l’andò reïterando
Translate: and continued to repeat it behind us

Original: E prima che del tutto non si udisse per allungarsi, un’altra ‘I’ sono Oreste’ passò gridando,
Translate: And before she vanished completely for the distance, another went by shouting 'I am Oreste',

Original: e anco non s’affisse
Translate: and this also did not stop

Original: «Oh», diss’ io,
Translate: I said, "Oh"

Original: «padre, che voci son queste?»
Translate: Father, what are these voices?

Original: E com’ io domandai, ecco la terza dicendo
Translate: And as soon as I asked, here's the third one that said,

Original: ‘Amate da cui male aveste’
Translate: "Love those who have harmed you"

Original: E ’l buon maestro
Translate: And the good teacher said,

Original: «Questo cinghio sferza la colpa de la invidia, e però sono tratte d’amor le corde de la ferza
Translate: This frame punishes the sin of envy, and therefore the strings of the whip are drawn from love.

Original: Lo fren vuol esser del contrario suono
Translate: The brake will instead be a reverse sign

Original: credo che l’udirai, per mio avviso, prima che giunghi al passo del perdono
Translate: I think you'll hear them before you get to the passage of forgiveness.

Original: Ma ficca li occhi per l’aere ben fiso, e vedrai gente innanzi a noi sedersi, e ciascun è lungo la grotta assiso»
Translate: But look carefully into the air and you will see souls sitting before us, each leaning along the wall.

Original: Allora più che prima li occhi apersi
Translate: Then I opened my eyes more than before

Original: guarda’mi innanzi, e vidi ombre con manti al color de la pietra non diversi
Translate: I looked in front of myself, and I saw souls wearing robes of a stone-like color.

Original: E poi che fummo un poco più avanti, udia gridar
Translate: And when we were advanced a little, I heard shouting.

Original: ‘Maria, òra per noi’
Translate: 'Mary, pray for us'

Original: gridar ‘Michele’ e ‘Pietro’ e ‘Tutti santi’
Translate: and then 'Michele', 'Peter' and 'All the saints'

Original: Non credo che per terra vada ancoi omo sì duro, che non fosse punto per compassion di quel ch’i’ vidi poi
Translate: I don't think there's such a cruel man on Earth that I don't feel compassion for what I then saw.

Original: ché, quando fui sì presso di lor giunto, che li atti loro a me venivan certi, per li occhi fui di grave dolor munto
Translate: For when I came near those souls, that I could see their deeds well, I shed tears of sorrow from my eyes.

Original: Di vil ciliccio mi parean coperti, e l’un sofferia l’altro con la spalla, e tutti da la ripa eran sofferti
Translate: They seemed to me covered in a vile cilicium, and one supported the other with his shoulder, and they were all leaning on the wall of the mountain.

Original: Così li ciechi a cui la roba falla, stanno a’ perdoni a chieder lor bisogna,
Translate: Thus the blind, deprived of sustenance, stand before the churches in the days of indulgences asking for alms,

Original: e l’uno il capo sopra l’altro avvalla, perché ’n altrui pietà tosto si pogna,
Translate: and one sustains the other's head, that he may soon stir up the mercy of others,

Original: non pur per lo sonar de le parole, ma per la vista che non meno agogna
Translate: not only with the sound of words but also with the sight that causes no less compassion

Original: E come a li orbi non approda il sole, così a l’ombre quivi, ond’ io parlo ora, luce del ciel di sé largir non vole
Translate: And just as the light of the sun doesn't come to the blind, so does those souls in the Frame, which I'm talking about, the sky doesn't want to give its light.

Original: ché a tutti un fil di ferro i cigli fóra e cusce sì, come a sparvier selvaggio si fa però che queto non dimora
Translate: For a wire of iron passes through all their lashes and sews them, just as it is done to a wild sparrow when it is not quiet

Original: A me pareva, andando, fare oltraggio, veggendo altrui, non essendo veduto
Translate: To me it seemed, walking, to commit an outrage by seeing others and not being seen

Original: per ch’io mi volsi al mio consiglio saggio
Translate: Then I turned to my wise counselor.

Original: Ben sapev’ ei che volea dir lo muto
Translate: He knew what I meant, even though I didn't speak.

Original: e però non attese mia dimanda, ma disse
Translate: So you didn't wait for my question, but you said,

Original: «Parla, e sie breve e arguto»
Translate: Speak, and be brief and concise.

Original: Virgilio mi venìa da quella banda de la cornice onde cader si puote, perché da nulla sponda s’inghirlanda
Translate: Virgil was next to me, on the side of the frame from which you can fall into the void, because there is no embankment

Original: da l’altra parte m’eran le divote ombre, che per l’orribile costura premevan sì, che bagnavan le gote
Translate: On the other side were the godly souls, which brought forth tears through the horrible seam, soaking the cheeks.

Original: Volsimi a loro e «O gente sicura», incominciai,
Translate: I turned to them and started "O safe souls"

Original: «di veder l’alto lume che ’l disio vostro solo ha in sua cura,
Translate: to see the high light that is the only object of your desire,

Original: se tosto grazia resolva le schiume di vostra coscïenza sì che chiaro per essa scenda de la mente il fiume,
Translate: may grace quickly remove the foams of your conscience, so that the river of memory descends from it with clear waters.

Original: ditemi, ché mi fia grazioso e caro, s’anima è qui tra voi che sia latina
Translate: Tell me, because I will be very pleased, if there is a soul among you that is Italian

Original: e forse lei sarà buon s’i’ l’apparo»
Translate: And perhaps it will be of use to her if I learn it.

Original: «O frate mio, ciascuna è cittadina d’una vera città
Translate: My brother, every one of us is a town of a true city.

Original: ma tu vuo’ dire che vivesse in Italia peregrina»
Translate: but you mean that she lived as a foreigner in Italy.

Original: Questo mi parve per risposta udire più innanzi alquanto che là dov’ io stava, ond’ io mi feci ancor più là sentire
Translate: This seemed to me to hear as an answer, a little further than where I was, so I felt even closer.

Original: Tra l’altre vidi un’ombra ch’aspettava in vista
Translate: Among other shadows I saw one that looked like it was waiting.

Original: e se volesse alcun dir ‘Come?’, lo mento a guisa d’orbo in sù levava
Translate: And if anyone wants to ask 'How?', know that he was lifting his chin like the blind do.

Original: «Spirto», diss’ io, «che per salir ti dome, se tu se’ quelli che mi rispondesti, fammiti conto o per luogo o per nome»
Translate: I said, "Spirit, that in order to ascend the mountain you will be mortified, if you are the one who answered me, make clear the place where you came from, or your name."

Original: «Io fui sanese», rispuose, «e con questi altri rimendo qui la vita ria, lagrimando a colui che sé ne presti
Translate: He said, "I was Sienese, and I cleanse my sinful life with these others, weeping to him that he might lend himself to us.

Original: Savia non fui, avvegna che Sapìa fossi chiamata, e fui de li altrui danni più lieta assai che di ventura mia
Translate: I was not wise, though I was called Sapia, and I was much more pleased with the misfortunes of others than with my fortune.

Original: E perché tu non creda ch’io t’inganni, odi s’i’ fui, com’ io ti dico, folle, già discendendo l’arco d’i miei anni
Translate: And so that you don't believe I'm fooling you, feel if I was crazy, as I tell you, when I was now in the final phase of my life

Original: Eran li cittadin miei presso a Colle in campo giunti co’ loro avversari, e io pregava Iddio di quel ch’e’ volle
Translate: My fellow citizens had come into battle with their enemies at Colle Val d'Elsa, and I prayed to God for what he wanted.

Original: Rotti fuor quivi e vòlti ne li amari passi di fuga
Translate: Here the Sienese were defeated and forced to a bitter escape

Original: e veggendo la caccia, letizia presi a tutte altre dispari, tanto ch’io volsi in sù l’ardita faccia, gridando a Dio
Translate: And when I saw that course, I rejoiced more than any other, so that I turned my bold face to heaven, crying out to God.

Original: “Omai più non ti temo”,
Translate: "I'm not afraid of you anymore,"

Original: come fé ’l merlo per poca bonaccia
Translate: how he made the blackbird for a short day of sunshine

Original: Pace volli con Dio in su lo stremo de la mia vita
Translate: I asked God for forgiveness at the end of my days

Original: e ancor non sarebbe lo mio dover per penitenza scemo,
Translate: and my duty to do penance would still be whole,

Original: se ciò non fosse, ch’a memoria m’ebbe Pier Pettinaio in sue sante orazioni, a cui di me per caritate increbbe
Translate: if it were not for Pier Pettinaio who remembered me in his holy prayers, and to whom he would call me for his charity

Original: Ma tu chi se’, che nostre condizioni vai dimandando, e porti li occhi sciolti, sì com’ io credo, e spirando ragioni?»
Translate: But who are you, asking about our condition and your eyes are free, as I believe, and you speak by breathing?

Original: «Li occhi», diss’ io, «mi fieno ancor qui tolti, ma picciol tempo, ché poca è l’offesa fatta per esser con invidia vòlti
Translate: I said, "The eyes will be sewn into this frame, but for a short time, for I have sinned slightly, turning them with envy.

Original: Troppa è più la paura ond’ è sospesa l’anima mia del tormento di sotto, che già lo ’ncarco di là giù mi pesa»
Translate: My soul is much more afraid of the torment of the Frame below, so much so that the load of the boulder over there already weighs on my shoulders.

Original: Ed ella a me
Translate: And her to me

Original: «Chi t’ha dunque condotto qua sù tra noi, se giù ritornar credi?»
Translate: So who drove you up here between us, since you think you're going back to Earth?

Original: E io
Translate: And I

Original: «Costui ch’è meco e non fa motto
Translate: He, who is with me and remains silent

Original: E vivo sono
Translate: And I'm alive.

Original: e però mi richiedi, spirito eletto, se tu vuo’ ch’i’ mova di là per te ancor li mortai piedi»
Translate: Therefore, chosen spirit, ask me if you want me, on earth, to move my mortal feet for you.

Original: «Oh, questa è a udir sì cosa nuova», rispuose, «che gran segno è che Dio t’ami
Translate: He said, "Oh, this is such a novelty that it is a sign of God's love for you."

Original: però col priego tuo talor mi giova
Translate: so sometimes remind me in your prayers

Original: E cheggioti, per quel che tu più brami, se mai calchi la terra di Toscana, che a’ miei propinqui tu ben mi rinfami
Translate: And I ask you, in the name of what you desire most, if you ever go to Tuscany, that you repair my reputation to my relatives.

Original: Tu li vedrai tra quella gente vana che spera in Talamone, e perderagli più di speranza ch’a trovar la Diana
Translate: You will find them among the vain people, who hope in Talamone and will lose more money than in the hope of finding the river of Diana.

Original: ma più vi perderanno li ammiragli»
Translate: but to lose more will be the contractors

Original: «Chi è costui che ’l nostro monte cerchia prima che morte li abbia dato il volo, e apre li occhi a sua voglia e coverchia?»
Translate: Who is this who goes up to our mountain before he is dead, and opens and closes his eyes as he pleases?

Original: «Non so chi sia, ma so ch’e’ non è solo
Translate: I don't know who he is, but I know he's not alone.

Original: domandal tu che più li t’avvicini, e dolcemente, sì che parli, acco’lo»
Translate: ask him that thou art nearest, and embrace him kindly, that thou mayest cause him to speak.

Original: Così due spirti, l’uno a l’altro chini, ragionavan di me ivi a man dritta
Translate: So two spirits bowed down to one another, and spoke of me at my right hand.

Original: poi fer li visi, per dirmi, supini
Translate: Then they lifted up their faces, as if to speak to me.

Original: e disse l’uno
Translate: And one of them said,

Original: «O anima che fitta nel corpo ancora inver’ lo ciel ten vai, per carità ne consola e ne ditta onde vieni e chi se’
Translate: "O soul that you go to heaven when you are still in the body, in the name of charity console us and tell us where you come from and who you are."

Original: ché tu ne fai tanto maravigliar de la tua grazia, quanto vuol cosa che non fu più mai»
Translate: For with the grace of which thou art the object thou makest us to be astonished at a thing which never hath happened.

Original: E io
Translate: And I...

Original: «Per mezza Toscana si spazia un fiumicel che nasce in Falterona, e cento miglia di corso nol sazia
Translate: In the central part of Tuscany flows a small river that comes from Falterona, and its course extends for more than a hundred miles

Original: Di sovr’ esso rech’ io questa persona
Translate: I come from his valley

Original: dirvi ch’i’ sia, saria parlare indarno, ché ’l nome mio ancor molto non suona»
Translate: If I told you my name I would speak vainly, for it is not yet very famous.

Original: «Se ben lo ’ntendimento tuo accarno con lo ’ntelletto», allora mi rispuose quei che diceva pria, «tu parli d’Arno»
Translate: And what he spake before said unto me, If my understanding understandeth well what thou wilt say, thou speakest of the river Arno.

Original: E l’altro disse lui
Translate: And the other one asked

Original: «Perché nascose questi il vocabol di quella riviera, pur com’ om fa de l’orribili cose?»
Translate: Why did he fail to pronounce the name of that river, as it is done with the horrible things?

Original: E l’ombra che di ciò domandata era, si sdebitò così
Translate: And the soul to whom he was asked answered, saying,

Original: «Non so
Translate: I don't know.

Original: ma degno ben è che ’l nome di tal valle pèra
Translate: But of course it is right that the name of that valley disappears

Original: ché dal principio suo, ov’ è sì pregno l’alpestro monte ond’ è tronco Peloro, che ’n pochi luoghi passa oltra quel segno,
Translate: in fact from the source of that river, where the Apennines that is separated from the Peloro is so massive that in a few other places it is more,

Original: infin là ’ve si rende per ristoro di quel che ’l ciel de la marina asciuga, ond’ hanno i fiumi ciò che va con loro,
Translate: to the mouth where it returns to the sea the water which evaporates from it and feeds the river through rains and snows,

Original: vertù così per nimica si fuga da tutti come biscia, o per sventura del luogo, o per mal uso che li fruga
Translate: Everyone flees virtue like a kiss, or for the misfortune of the place or for a bad habit that induces them to this

Original: ond’ hanno sì mutata lor natura li abitator de la misera valle, che par che Circe li avesse in pastura
Translate: So the inhabitants of the poor valley have changed their nature, so that it seems that Circe has turned them into beasts.

Original: Tra brutti porci, più degni di galle che d’altro cibo fatto in uman uso, dirizza prima il suo povero calle
Translate: The valley of the Arno first directs its small course among filthy pigs, more worthy of eating acorns than other food for men

Original: Botoli trova poi, venendo giuso, ringhiosi più che non chiede lor possa, e da lor disdegnosa torce il muso
Translate: Then, flowing down, he finds hatches that growl more than their strength permits, and deviates its disdainful course from them

Original: Vassi caggendo e quant’ ella più ’ngrossa, tanto più trova di can farsi lupi la maladetta e sventurata fossa
Translate: The cursed and wretched valley descends even lower and the more it widens, the more it finds dogs become wolves

Original: Discesa poi per più pelaghi cupi, trova le volpi sì piene di froda, che non temono ingegno che le occùpi
Translate: Descent into deep basins, he finds foxes so devoted to fraud that they fear no cunning that can capture them

Original: Né lascerò di dir perch’ altri m’oda
Translate: And I won't stop talking because someone listens to me

Original: e buon sarà costui, s’ancor s’ammenta di ciò che vero spirto mi disnoda
Translate: And it shall be profitable for him, if the true prophecy that I am about to make be remembered.

Original: Io veggio tuo nepote che diventa cacciator di quei lupi in su la riva del fiero fiume, e tutti li sgomenta
Translate: I see your nephew as the hunter of those wolves on the banks of the fierce river, and he terrorizes them all.

Original: Vende la carne loro essendo viva
Translate: He sells their flesh when they're still alive.

Original: poscia li ancide come antica belva
Translate: Then he kills them like an ancient beast

Original: molti di vita e sé di pregio priva
Translate: deprives many of life and himself of honor

Original: Sanguinoso esce de la trista selva
Translate: It comes out of the sad forest all bloody

Original: lasciala tal, che di qui a mille anni ne lo stato primaio non si rinselva»
Translate: leaves it in that state, which will take more than a thousand years for it to return to its initial conditions.

Original: Com’ a l’annunzio di dogliosi danni si turba il viso di colui ch’ascolta, da qual che parte il periglio l’assanni,
Translate: As to the announcement of grievous things, the face of the listener is troubled, wherever the danger strikes him,

Original: così vid’ io l’altr’ anima, che volta stava a udir, turbarsi e farsi trista, poi ch’ebbe la parola a sé raccolta
Translate: So I saw the other soul, who listened carefully, and was troubled and saddened, after he had heard those words.

Original: Lo dir de l’una e de l’altra la vista mi fer voglioso di saper lor nomi, e dimanda ne fei con prieghi mista
Translate: The words of one and the appearance of the other made me eager to know their names, which I asked with prayers.

Original: per che lo spirto che di pria parlòmi ricominciò
Translate: Then the spirit that had spoken to me before began again.

Original: «Tu vuo’ ch’io mi deduca nel fare a te ciò che tu far non vuo’mi
Translate: You want me to lead you to do what you deny me.

Original: Ma da che Dio in te vuol che traluca tanto sua grazia, non ti sarò scarso
Translate: But since God wants his grace to shine through you so much, I will not refuse your question.

Original: però sappi ch’io fui Guido del Duca
Translate: Know therefore that I was Guido of the Duke

Original: Fu il sangue mio d’invidia sì rïarso, che se veduto avesse uom farsi lieto, visto m’avresti di livore sparso
Translate: My blood was so full of envy, that if I had seen a man rejoice, you would see me become bruised.

Original: Di mia semente cotal paglia mieto
Translate: From that seed I gather this straw

Original: o gente umana, perché poni ’l core là ’v’ è mestier di consorte divieto?
Translate: or human people, why do you desire those goods whose possession excludes sharing?

Original: Questi è Rinier
Translate: This is Rinieri.

Original: questi è ’l pregio e l’onore de la casa da Calboli, ove nullo fatto s’è reda poi del suo valore
Translate: This is the merit and honour of the family from Calboli, where no one has collected the inheritance of its value.

Original: E non pur lo suo sangue è fatto brullo, tra ’l Po e ’l monte e la marina e ’l Reno, del ben richesto al vero e al trastullo
Translate: And between the Po, the mountains, the Adriatic Sea and the Rhine is not only its line that has abandoned the virtues necessary for the true and the courteous pleasures

Original: ché dentro a questi termini è ripieno di venenosi sterpi, sì che tardi per coltivare omai verrebber meno
Translate: in fact within these geographical limits is full of poisonous dung, to the point that it would be late to eradicate them to cultivate the land

Original: Ov’ è ’l buon Lizio e Arrigo Mainardi? Pier Traversaro e Guido di Carpigna? Oh Romagnuoli tornati in bastardi
Translate: Where are the good Lizio and Arrigo Mainardi? And Pier Traversaro and Guido di Carpegna? Oh, Romagnoli bastarditi

Original: Quando in Bologna un Fabbro si ralligna? quando in Faenza un Bernardin di Fosco, verga gentil di picciola gramigna?
Translate: When can a Lambertazzi Fabbro ever be reborn in Bologna? and in Faenza a Bernardino di Fosco, noble branch of humble origins?

Original: Non ti maravigliar s’io piango, Tosco, quando rimembro, con Guido da Prata, Ugolin d’Azzo che vivette nosco, Federigo Tignoso e sua brigata,
Translate: Don't be surprised, Tuscany, if I cry when I remember Guido da Prata, Ugolino d'Azzo who lived with us, Federigo Tignoso and his brigade,

Original: la casa Traversara e li Anastagi (e l’una gente e l’altra è diretata), le donne e ’ cavalier,
Translate: the family of the Traversaries and Anastasians, the ladies and the knights,

Original: li affanni e li agi che ne ’nvogliava amore e cortesia là dove i cuor son fatti sì malvagi
Translate: the military labors and the lordly pleasures that love and courtesy led us to pursue, while now there hearts are wicked

Original: O Bretinoro, ché non fuggi via, poi che gita se n’è la tua famiglia e molta gente per non esser ria?
Translate: O Bertinor, why don't you run away now that your house has gone away with many people, so as not to be evil?

Original: Ben fa Bagnacaval, che non rifiglia
Translate: well Bagnacavallo not to leave heirs,

Original: e mal fa Castrocaro, e peggio Conio, che di figliar tai conti più s’impiglia
Translate: while Castrocaro hurts and even worse Conio, who continue to generate such evil accounts

Original: Ben faranno i Pagan, da che ’l demonio lor sen girà
Translate: The Pagans will do well, after their devil goes away.

Original: ma non però che puro già mai rimagna d’essi testimonio
Translate: but not to the point that the memory of him is not preserved

Original: O Ugolin de’ Fantolin, sicuro è ’l nome tuo, da che più non s’aspetta chi far lo possa, tralignando, scuro
Translate: O Ugolino of the Fantolini, your name is sure since, having no degenerate heirs, it does not fear to become dark

Original: Ma va via, Tosco, omai
Translate: But now go away, Tuscany,

Original: ch’or mi diletta troppo di pianger più che di parlare, sì m’ha nostra ragion la mente stretta»
Translate: because I feel too much like weeping rather than talking, to this point our speech has afflicted me.

Original: Noi sapavam che quell’ anime care ci sentivano andar
Translate: We knew those lucky souls would hear us leave.

Original: però, tacendo, facëan noi del cammin confidare
Translate: Therefore, keeping silent, they made us trust in our way.

Original: Poi fummo fatti soli procedendo, folgore parve quando l’aere fende, voce che giunse di contra dicendo
Translate: And it came to pass, when we went forward, that we were alone, that there came to us a voice, which seemed like lightning when the air was broken, saying,

Original: ‘Anciderammi qualunque m’apprende’
Translate: "Whoever meets me will kill me."

Original: e fuggì come tuon che si dilegua, se sùbito la nuvola scoscende
Translate: And he went as the thunder that faded away, and cut off the cloud immediately.

Original: Come da lei l’udir nostro ebbe triegua, ed ecco l’altra con sì gran fracasso, che somigliò tonar che tosto segua
Translate: As soon as we heard it, behold, another voice that made a great noise, like a thunder that followed another said,

Original: «Io sono Aglauro che divenni sasso»
Translate: "I am Aglaur who became stone"

Original: e allor, per ristrignermi al poeta, in destro feci, e non innanzi, il passo
Translate: Then, to approach Virgil, I went to the right hand, and not to the front.

Original: Già era l’aura d’ogne parte queta
Translate: The air was quiet again

Original: ed el mi disse
Translate: and he said to me,

Original: «Quel fu ’l duro camo che dovria l’uom tener dentro a sua meta
Translate: That was the hard brake that should keep man within his limits

Original: Ma voi prendete l’esca, sì che l’amo de l’antico avversaro a sé vi tira
Translate: But you take the bait, so that the love of the devil draws you to Him.

Original: e però poco val freno o richiamo
Translate: and therefore they are of little use to the brake or the call.

Original: Chiamavi ’l cielo e ’ntorno vi si gira, mostrandovi le sue bellezze etterne, e l’occhio vostro pur a terra mira
Translate: Heaven calls you and turns around you, showing you its eternal attractions, and your gaze is always turned to the ground

Original: onde vi batte chi tutto discerne»
Translate: That is why he that seeth all things chastises you.

Original: Quanto tra l’ultimar de l’ora terza e ’l principio del dì par de la spera che sempre a guisa di fanciullo scherza,
Translate: How much is the space traveled by the sun, like a child playing, from the beginning of the day until the end of the third hour,

Original: tanto pareva già inver’ la sera essere al sol del suo corso rimaso
Translate: He still had to walk until the beginning of the evening.

Original: vespero là, e qui mezza notte era
Translate: in Purgatory was the vesper, while in Italy it was midnight

Original: E i raggi ne ferien per mezzo ’l naso, perché per noi girato era sì ’l monte, che già dritti andavamo inver’ l’occaso,
Translate: And the sun's rays struck us in the face, for we turned round about the mountain, and went toward the west,

Original: quand’ io senti’ a me gravar la fronte a lo splendore assai più che di prima, e stupor m’eran le cose non conte
Translate: when I felt dazzled by a much more intense splendor than before and was amazed by that phenomenon that I didn't explain myself

Original: ond’ io levai le mani inver’ la cima de le mie ciglia, e fecimi ’l solecchio, che del soverchio visibile lima
Translate: Then I lifted my hands above my eyelashes, protecting my eyes from excessive light compared to the ability of my sight.

Original: Come quando da l’acqua o da lo specchio salta lo raggio a l’opposita parte, salendo su per lo modo parecchio a quel che scende,
Translate: As when the light beam is reflected by water or a mirror, so that the beam rising forms an angle identical to that of the beam descending from the vertical to the plane,

Original: e tanto si diparte dal cader de la pietra in igual tratta, sì come mostra esperïenza e arte
Translate: according to what experience and science demonstrate

Original: così mi parve da luce rifratta quivi dinanzi a me esser percosso
Translate: So it seemed to me that I was struck at that point by a reflected light,

Original: per che a fuggir la mia vista fu ratta
Translate: which moved me to look away quickly

Original: «Che è quel, dolce padre, a che non posso schermar lo viso tanto che mi vaglia», diss’ io, «e pare inver’ noi esser mosso?»
Translate: I said, "What is that, sweet father, before whom I cannot protect my sight without being dazzled, and who seems to move toward us?"

Original: «Non ti maravigliar s’ancor t’abbaglia la famiglia del cielo», a me rispuose
Translate: He said, "Don't be surprised if the angels still dazzle you."

Original: «messo è che viene ad invitar ch’om saglia
Translate: That is a heavenly messenger who comes to invite us up.

Original: Tosto sarà ch’a veder queste cose non ti fia grave, ma fieti diletto quanto natura a sentir ti dispuose»
Translate: Soon to see certain things not only will it not bother you, but it will bring you joy as much as nature has prepared you for it.

Original: Poi giunti fummo a l’angel benedetto, con lieta voce disse
Translate: After we reached the blessed angel, he said with a glad voice,

Original: «Intrate quinci ad un scaleo vie men che li altri eretto»
Translate: Access here to a ladder, less steep than the other ladders

Original: Noi montavam, già partiti di linci, e ‘Beati misericordes’ fue cantato retro, e ‘Godi tu che vinci’
Translate: We ascended away from that point, and behind us was sung 'Blessed are the merciful', and 'Enjoy who wins'

Original: Lo mio maestro e io soli amendue suso andavamo
Translate: My teacher and I, alone, both climbed up.

Original: e io pensai, andando, prode acquistar ne le parole sue
Translate: And I thought, as I ascended, to gain advantage through his words,

Original: e dirizza’mi a lui sì dimandando
Translate: And I turned to him, asking him so.

Original: «Che volse dir lo spirto di Romagna, e ‘divieto’ e ‘consorte’ menzionando?»
Translate: What did the spirit of Romagna mean by 'exclusion' and 'compañeros'?

Original: Per ch’elli a me
Translate: Then he answered me.

Original: «Di sua maggior magagna conosce il danno
Translate: He knows the damage of his greatest sin

Original: e però non s’ammiri se ne riprende perché men si piagna
Translate: Therefore it is not to be astonished if he rebukes him, that he should not be grieved.

Original: Perché s’appuntano i vostri disiri dove per compagnia parte si scema, invidia move il mantaco a’ sospiri
Translate: Envy moves you to sigh because your desires focus on those possessions whose possession diminishes, the more those who possess them

Original: Ma se l’amor de la spera supprema torcesse in suso il disiderio vostro, non vi sarebbe al petto quella tema
Translate: But if the love of the Empire directed your desire upward, the breast would not have that fear.

Original: ché, per quanti si dice più lì ‘nostro’, tanto possiede più di ben ciascuno, e più di caritate arde in quel chiostro»
Translate: For in Heaven, the more numerous are those who enjoy good, the greater is the good possessed, and the more charity burns in that sacred place.

Original: «Io son d’esser contento più digiuno», diss’ io, «che se mi fosse pria taciuto, e più di dubbio ne la mente aduno
Translate: I said "I am farther from being satisfied than if I had asked you anything, and in my mind I have even more doubts

Original: Com’ esser puote ch’un ben, distributo in più posseditor, faccia più ricchi di sé che se da pochi è posseduto?»
Translate: How can it be that a good, distributed among more possessors, makes those richer of themselves than if it were enjoyed by a few?

Original: Ed elli a me
Translate: And him to me

Original: «Però che tu rificchi la mente pur a le cose terrene, di vera luce tenebre dispicchi
Translate: "Because you think only of earthly goods, the proceeds of darkness from the true light

Original: Quello infinito e ineffabil bene che là sù è, così corre ad amore com’ a lucido corpo raggio vene
Translate: That infinite and inexpressible good that is up there in Heaven, runs to love just as the light beam goes towards a shiny body

Original: Tanto si dà quanto trova d’ardore
