Translate: He grants himself all the more, the more he finds the ardour of charity

Original: sì che, quantunque carità si stende, cresce sovr’ essa l’etterno valore
Translate: so that, how much the charity of each one extends, the more it increases in him the eternal good

Original: E quanta gente più là sù s’intende, più v’è da bene amare, e più vi s’ama, e come specchio l’uno a l’altro rende
Translate: And the more people you love up there, the better there is to love and the more you love, and love is reflected from one to the other as the light from a mirror

Original: E se la mia ragion non ti disfama, vedrai Beatrice, ed ella pienamente ti torrà questa e ciascun’ altra brama
Translate: And if my reasoning does not satisfy you, you will see Beatrice and she will fully satisfy you with this and other desires.

Original: Procaccia pur che tosto sieno spente, come son già le due, le cinque piaghe, che si richiudon per esser dolente»
Translate: Hurry then to delete the other five Ps as they are already the first two, which disappear thanks to your repentance.

Original: Com’ io voleva dicer ‘Tu m’appaghe’, vidimi giunto in su l’altro girone, sì che tacer mi fer le luci vaghe
Translate: While I wanted to say 'I'm satisfied', I saw myself in the other frame, so that my eager eyes silenced me.

Original: Ivi mi parve in una visïone estatica di sùbito esser tratto, e vedere in un tempio più persone
Translate: There it seemed to me to be abducted into an ecstatic vision, and to see many people in a temple

Original: e una donna, in su l’entrar, con atto dolce di madre dicer
Translate: And I saw a woman on the door, saying with the sweet attitude of a mother.

Original: «Figliuol mio, perché hai tu così verso noi fatto? Ecco, dolenti, lo tuo padre e io ti cercavamo»
Translate: My son, why have you done this to us? Behold, your father and I were looking for you to be grieved.

Original: E come qui si tacque, ciò che pareva prima, dispario
Translate: And as soon as he was silent, the contents of that vision vanished.

Original: Indi m’apparve un’altra con quell’ acque giù per le gote che ’l dolor distilla quando di gran dispetto in altrui nacque, e dir
Translate: Then there appeared to me another woman, with her face drawn by tears caused by the pain generated by a great anger towards someone, who said,

Original: «Se tu se’ sire de la villa del cui nome ne’ dèi fu tanta lite, e onde ogne scïenza disfavilla,
Translate: If thou art lord of the city whose name was a great quarrel among the gods, and out of which all knowledge is derived,

Original: vendica te di quelle braccia ardite ch’abbracciar nostra figlia, o Pisistràto»
Translate: Avenged of those bold arms that embraced our daughter, O Pisistrato.

Original: E ’l segnor mi parea, benigno e mite, risponder lei con viso temperato
Translate: And it seemed to me that the gentleman, kind and mild, answered her with a balanced face.

Original: «Che farem noi a chi mal ne disira, se quei che ci ama è per noi condannato?»,
Translate: "What will we do to those who want us badly, if we condemn those who love us?"

Original: Poi vidi genti accese in foco d’ira con pietre un giovinetto ancider, forte gridando a sé pur
Translate: Then I saw people burning with the fire of anger, killing a young man by stoning him, crying loudly to one another.

Original: «Martira, martira»
Translate: Martyr, martyr

Original: E lui vedea chinarsi, per la morte che l’aggravava già, inver’ la terra, ma de li occhi facea sempre al ciel porte,
Translate: And I saw him bowing to the ground almost dying, but turning his eyes to heaven and praying to the Lord,

Original: orando a l’alto Sire, in tanta guerra, che perdonasse a’ suoi persecutori, con quello aspetto che pietà diserra
Translate: Despite so much violence, to forgive his persecutors, with that aspect that generates piety

Original: Quando l’anima mia tornò di fori a le cose che son fuor di lei vere, io riconobbi i miei non falsi errori
Translate: When my soul came to mind and perceived the real things outside, I recognized that I had visions of truthful content.

Original: Lo duca mio, che mi potea vedere far sì com’ om che dal sonno si slega, disse
Translate: My teacher, who saw me as a man who came out of his sleep little by little, said,

Original: «Che hai che non ti puoi tenere, ma se’ venuto più che mezza lega velando li occhi e con le gambe avvolte, a guisa di cui vino o sonno piega?»
Translate: "What have you got, that you can't stand and walk for more than half a league with veiled eyes and clumsy legs, like someone burdened by wine or sleep?"

Original: «O dolce padre mio, se tu m’ascolte, io ti dirò», diss’ io, «ciò che m’apparve quando le gambe mi furon sì tolte»
Translate: I said, "O sweet father, if you listen to me, I will tell you what appeared to me when my legs did not hold me."

Original: Ed ei
Translate: And him

Original: «Se tu avessi cento larve sovra la faccia, non mi sarian chiuse le tue cogitazion, quantunque parve
Translate: ♪ If you had a hundred masks on your face, your thoughts, no matter how small, wouldn't have hidden me

Original: Ciò che vedesti fu perché non scuse d’aprir lo core a l’acque de la pace che da l’etterno fonte son diffuse
Translate: What you have seen was to cause you not to refuse to open your heart to the waters of peace, which are poured out from the eternal fountain.

Original: Non dimandai “Che hai?” per quel che face chi guarda pur con l’occhio che non vede, quando disanimato il corpo giace
Translate: I didn't ask you what I had like what you look at with your body eye that you don't see, when your body lies exanimous.

Original: ma dimandai per darti forza al piede
Translate: But I asked you to speed up your step.

Original: così frugar conviensi i pigri, lenti ad usar lor vigilia quando riede»
Translate: So you have to bite the lazy, slow to move when they come back awake.

Original: Noi andavam per lo vespero, attenti oltre quanto potean li occhi allungarsi contra i raggi serotini e lucenti
Translate: We walked in the drowsy, staring at the eyes before us as far as the rays of the sun allowed us, low and bright

Original: Ed ecco a poco a poco un fummo farsi verso di noi come la notte oscuro
Translate: And behold, a smoke, as dark as the night, is coming towards us,

Original: né da quello era loco da cansarsi
Translate: from which it was not possible to escape

Original: Questo ne tolse li occhi e l’aere puro
Translate: This blinded us and took away the pure air

Original: Buio d’inferno e di notte privata d’ogne pianeto, sotto pover cielo, quant’ esser può di nuvol tenebrata,
Translate: The darkness of Hell, or of a night without any star, under a dark sky how much can be that of a night covered by clouds,

Original: non fece al viso mio sì grosso velo come quel fummo ch’ivi ci coperse, né a sentir di così aspro pelo, che l’occhio stare aperto non sofferse
Translate: He didn't reveal my sight like the smoke that surrounded us, nor did he irritate my eyes to the point that I couldn't keep them open.

Original: onde la scorta mia saputa e fida mi s’accostò e l’omero m’offerse
Translate: Then my wise guidance came to me, and offered me his arm.

Original: Sì come cieco va dietro a sua guida per non smarrirsi e per non dar di cozzo in cosa che ’l molesti, o forse ancida,
Translate: As the blind man follows his guidance so that he doesn't get lost and bump into something that hurts him or maybe kills him,

Original: m’andava io per l’aere amaro e sozzo, ascoltando il mio duca che diceva pur
Translate: So I proceeded in that bitter and dark air, listening to my teacher who said to me all the time.

Original: «Guarda che da me tu non sia mozzo»
Translate: Make sure you don't part with me.

Original: Io sentia voci, e ciascuna pareva pregar per pace e per misericordia l’Agnel di Dio che le peccata leva
Translate: I heard voices, and each one seemed to pray for peace and mercy to the Lamb of God, who took away sins from the world.

Original: Pur ‘Agnus Dei’ eran le loro essordia
Translate: The opening words were always 'Agnus Dei'

Original: una parola in tutte era e un modo, sì che parea tra esse ogne concordia
Translate: Everyone said the same thing and in such a way that there seemed to be total harmony

Original: «Quei sono spirti, maestro, ch’i’ odo?», diss’ io
Translate: I said, "Master, are those spirits I hear?"

Original: Ed elli a me
Translate: And him to me

Original: «Tu vero apprendi, e d’iracundia van solvendo il nodo»
Translate: "Tell the truth, and they serve the penalty for their anger."

Original: «Or tu chi se’ che ’l nostro fummo fendi, e di noi parli pur come se tue partissi ancor lo tempo per calendi?»
Translate: And who are you, that walks through the smoke of our Frame and speaks of us as if you still divide time?

Original: Così per una voce detto fue
Translate: So it was said by a voice

Original: onde ’l maestro mio disse
Translate: Then my teacher said,

Original: «Rispondi, e domanda se quinci si va sùe»
Translate: "Answer, and ask if you go up this way"

Original: E io
Translate: And I...

Original: «O creatura che ti mondi per tornar bella a colui che ti fece, maraviglia udirai, se mi secondi»
Translate: "O soul that purifies you, to return beautiful to the One who created you, if you follow me you will feel something extraordinary."

Original: «Io ti seguiterò quanto mi lece», rispuose
Translate: He said, "I will follow you as long as I am allowed."

Original: «e se veder fummo non lascia, l’udir ci terrà giunti in quella vece»
Translate: And if smoke doesn't allow us to see each other, the sound of words will keep us together.

Original: Allora incominciai
Translate: So I started.

Original: «Con quella fascia che la morte dissolve men vo suso, e venni qui per l’infernale ambascia
Translate: I'm going up with that envelope that death dissolves, and I came here through hell.

Original: E se Dio m’ha in sua grazia rinchiuso, tanto che vuol ch’i’ veggia la sua corte per modo tutto fuor del moderno uso,
Translate: And if God has received me in his grace, to the point that he wants to show me his kingdom in a way entirely different from modern use,

Original: non mi celar chi fosti anzi la morte, ma dilmi, e dimmi s’i’ vo bene al varco
Translate: Don't hide your name from me before your death, but tell me, and tell me if I'm going in the right direction to the next Frame

Original: e tue parole fier le nostre scorte»
Translate: and your words will be our guide.

Original: «Lombardo fui, e fu’ chiamato Marco
Translate: I was Lombard, and my name was Mark.

Original: del mondo seppi, e quel valore amai al quale ha or ciascun disteso l’arco
Translate: I knew the world, and I loved that courteous virtue to which everyone has stretched out the bow today.

Original: Per montar sù dirittamente vai»
Translate: To climb up, go in the right direction.

Original: Così rispuose, e soggiunse
Translate: So he answered, and added,

Original: «I’ ti prego che per me prieghi quando sù sarai»
Translate: "I beg you to pray for me, when you are in Heaven."

Original: E io a lui
Translate: And I to him

Original: «Per fede mi ti lego di far ciò che mi chiedi
Translate: "I promise you that I will do what you ask of me."

Original: ma io scoppio dentro ad un dubbio, s’io non me ne spiego
Translate: But I burst if I can't get rid of a doubt that annoys me

Original: Prima era scempio, e ora è fatto doppio ne la sentenza tua, che mi fa certo qui, e altrove, quello ov’ io l’accoppio
Translate: It was a simple doubt before, but now it has doubled because of your words, which confirm to me, here and elsewhere, what I have already heard.

Original: Lo mondo è ben così tutto diserto d’ogne virtute, come tu mi sone, e di malizia gravido e coverto
Translate: The world is completely devoid of all kind virtues, as you say to me, and full of all malice.

Original: ma priego che m’addite la cagione, sì ch’i’ la veggia e ch’i’ la mostri altrui
Translate: But I beg you to point out the cause of it, so that I may understand it and show it to others.

Original: ché nel cielo uno, e un qua giù la pone»
Translate: In fact, some place it in celestial influences, others in human behavior.

Original: Alto sospir, che duolo strinse in «uhi», mise fuor prima
Translate: At first he gave out a deep sigh, which then became "uhi"

Original: e poi cominciò
Translate: then it started

Original: «Frate, lo mondo è cieco, e tu vien ben da lui
Translate: Brother, the world is blind, and you prove yourself to come from there.

Original: Voi che vivete ogne cagion recate pur suso al cielo, pur come se tutto movesse seco di necessitate
Translate: You who are alive bring back the cause of everything to Heaven, as if it determined everything necessarily

Original: Se così fosse, in voi fora distrutto libero arbitrio, e non fora giustizia per ben letizia, e per male aver lutto
Translate: If so, there would be no free will in you, and it would not be right to be rewarded for virtue, and to be punished for guilt.

Original: Lo cielo i vostri movimenti inizia
Translate: Heaven begins your movements, and not even all

Original: non dico tutti, ma, posto ch’i’ ’l dica, lume v’è dato a bene e a malizia, e libero voler
Translate: But even by admitting this, you are able to distinguish good from evil, and you have free will.

Original: che, se fatica ne le prime battaglie col ciel dura, poi vince tutto, se ben si notrica
Translate: who, even if he encounters difficulties in the first battles with the astral influences, then wins everything, as long as it is well fed

Original: A maggior forza e a miglior natura liberi soggiacete
Translate: You are subject, free, to a greater force and a better nature.

Original: e quella cria la mente in voi, che ’l ciel non ha in sua cura
Translate: And it creates in you the intellect, which heaven has not in its power.

Original: Però, se ’l mondo presente disvia, in voi è la cagione, in voi si cheggia
Translate: Therefore, if the present world sins, reason is in you, and to you it must be ascribed.

Original: e io te ne sarò or vera spia
Translate: And now I'm going to prove it to you.

Original: Esce di mano a lui che la vagheggia prima che sia, a guisa di fanciulla che piangendo e ridendo pargoleggia, l’anima semplicetta che sa nulla,
Translate: The simple soul, who knows nothing, comes out of the hands of the One who loves her, before being formed, like a girl, who weeps and laughs without knowing the reason,

Original: salvo che, mossa da lieto fattore, volontier torna a ciò che la trastulla
Translate: unless, moved by a happy Creator, he willingly returns to what pleases him

Original: Di picciol bene in pria sente sapore
Translate: At first he feels the taste of the goods of little importance

Original: quivi s’inganna, e dietro ad esso corre, se guida o fren non torce suo amore
Translate: Here he deceives himself and runs after them, unless a guide or a brake distracts his misplaced love.

Original: Onde convenne legge per fren porre
Translate: For this reason it was necessary to put brakes with the laws

Original: convenne rege aver, che discernesse de la vera cittade almen la torre
Translate: It was necessary to have a king to distinguish at least the tower of the true city

Original: Le leggi son, ma chi pon mano ad esse? Nullo, però che ’l pastor che procede, rugumar può, ma non ha l’unghie fesse
Translate: The laws are there, but who enforces them? No one, since the shepherd who guides the flock can ruminate, but has no broken nails.

Original: per che la gente, che sua guida vede pur a quel ben fedire ond’ ella è ghiotta, di quel si pasce, e più oltre non chiede
Translate: Therefore the people, who see his guidance, seek out those earthly goods of which he is enjoined, and feed on them, and ask nothing else.

Original: Ben puoi veder che la mala condotta è la cagion che ’l mondo ha fatto reo, e non natura che ’n voi sia corrotta
Translate: You can well understand that the bad leadership of the pontiffs is the reason that corrupted the world, certainly not your nature influenced by Heaven

Original: Soleva Roma, che ’l buon mondo feo, due soli aver, che l’una e l’altra strada facean vedere, e del mondo e di Deo
Translate: Rome, who built the virtuous world, used to have two suns, indicating both ways, of the world and of God.

Original: L’un l’altro ha spento
Translate: One turned off the other.

Original: ed è giunta la spada col pasturale, e l’un con l’altro insieme per viva forza mal convien che vada
Translate: and the sword is joined to the pastoral, and it is inevitable that the two things be evil together, united in a forced manner.

Original: però che, giunti, l’un l’altro non teme
Translate: For, united, one power feareth not the other.

Original: se non mi credi, pon mente a la spiga, ch’ogn’ erba si conosce per lo seme
Translate: If you don't believe me, think of the ear, for every plant is recognized by its seed.

Original: In sul paese ch’Adice e Po riga, solea valore e cortesia trovarsi, prima che Federigo avesse briga
Translate: In the village that is crossed by Adige and Po, value and courtesy used to be present, before Frederick II was hindered

Original: or può sicuramente indi passarsi per qualunque lasciasse, per vergogna di ragionar coi buoni o d’appressarsi
Translate: Now he can pass by without fear, whosoever will not speak with righteous men, or come near to them, out of shame.

Original: Ben v’èn tre vecchi ancora in cui rampogna l’antica età la nova, e par lor tardo che Dio a miglior vita li ripogna
Translate: There are still three old men in whom the old age reproaches the new, and they hope that God will soon make them pass to better life.

Original: Currado da Palazzo e ’l buon Gherardo e Guido da Castel, che mei si noma, francescamente, il semplice Lombardo
Translate: Corrado da Palazzo, the good Gherardo and Guido da Castello, which the French indicated as the simple Lombardo

Original: Dì oggimai che la Chiesa di Roma, per confondere in sé due reggimenti, cade nel fango, e sé brutta e la soma»
Translate: You conclude that by now the Church of Rome, in order to center the two powers in itself, falls into the mud and dirty itself and its commission.

Original: «O Marco mio», diss’ io, «bene argomenti
Translate: I said, "My Mark, you are right."

Original: e or discerno perché dal retaggio li figli di Levì furono essenti
Translate: And now I understand why the descendants of Levi were excluded from the inheritance of possessions.

Original: Ma qual Gherardo è quel che tu per saggio di’ ch’è rimaso de la gente spenta, in rimprovèro del secol selvaggio?»
Translate: But who is that Gherardo whom you say has remained as an example of the ancient people, as a rebuke of the fallen century?

Original: «O tuo parlar m’inganna, o el mi tenta», rispuose a me
Translate: He said to me, "Your words deceive me or tease me."

Original: «ché, parlandomi tosco, par che del buon Gherardo nulla senta
Translate: In fact, speaking with a Tuscan accent, you seem to know nothing about good Gherardo

Original: Per altro sopranome io nol conosco, s’io nol togliessi da sua figlia Gaia
Translate: I don't know him through another nickname, unless I point at him as Gaia's father.

Original: Dio sia con voi, ché più non vegno vosco
Translate: God be with you, for I can no longer follow you.

Original: Vedi l’albor che per lo fummo raia già biancheggiare, e me convien partirmi (l’angelo è ivi) prima ch’io li paia»
Translate: You see the light that filters through the dark and already whites, and I must separate myself from you before I appear to the angel, who is there.

Original: Così tornò, e più non volle udirmi
Translate: So he left, and he wouldn't listen to me anymore.

Original: Ricorditi, lettor, se mai ne l’alpe ti colse nebbia per la qual vedessi non altrimenti che per pelle talpe,
Translate: Remember, reader, if you've ever been surprised by the fog in the mountains so that you don't see anything like a mole with eyes covered in skin,

Original: come, quando i vapori umidi e spessi a diradar cominciansi, la spera del sol debilemente entra per essi
Translate: how the sun faintly penetrates through the humid and thick vapors when they begin to thin out

Original: e fia la tua imagine leggera in giugnere a veder com’ io rividi lo sole in pria, che già nel corcar era
Translate: and your imagination can easily comprehend how I saw the sun at first, which was now near sunset.

Original: Sì, pareggiando i miei co’ passi fidi del mio maestro, usci’ fuor di tal nube ai raggi morti già ne’ bassi lidi
Translate: So, adapting my steps to those of my master's trust, I came out of that smoke and saw the sun rays, already near the horizon.

Original: O imaginativa che ne rube talvolta sì di fuor, ch’om non s’accorge perché dintorno suonin mille tube, chi move te, se ’l senso non ti porge?
Translate: Or imagination, that sometimes alienates us from what happens around us to the point that one doesn't even notice that they sound a thousand trumpets, who generates you if you don't take origin from a feeling?

Original: Moveti lume che nel ciel s’informa, per sé o per voler che giù lo scorge
Translate: It generates you a light that is born in Heaven, by itself or by the divine will that brings it to Earth.

Original: De l’empiezza di lei che mutò forma ne l’uccel ch’a cantar più si diletta, ne l’imagine mia apparve l’orma
Translate: In my imagination appeared the figure of her, ungodly, who turned into the bird that delights the most to sing

Original: e qui fu la mia mente sì ristretta dentro da sé, che di fuor non venìa cosa che fosse allor da lei ricetta
Translate: and here my mind focused so much that nothing came from the outside that was able to distract me

Original: Poi piovve dentro a l’alta fantasia un crucifisso, dispettoso e fero ne la sua vista, e cotal si moria
Translate: Then in my deep imagination I saw a crucified man, with a look full of bitter disdain, who died in this way.

Original: intorno ad esso era il grande Assüero, Estèr sua sposa e ’l giusto Mardoceo, che fu al dire e al far così intero
Translate: Around him was the great king Ahasuerus, his wife Esther, and the righteous Mordecai, who was so perfect in words and deeds.

Original: E come questa imagine rompeo sé per sé stessa, a guisa d’una bulla cui manca l’acqua sotto qual si feo,
Translate: And as soon as this image faded from itself, like a bubble that faints, because under it there is no more water,

Original: surse in mia visïone una fanciulla piangendo forte, e dicea
Translate: And there appeared in my mind a maiden crying desperately, and saying,

Original: «O regina, perché per ira hai voluto esser nulla? Ancisa t’hai per non perder Lavina
Translate: "O Queen, why did you want to destroy yourself because of your anger? You committed suicide so as not to lose Lavinia."

Original: or m’hai perduta
Translate: Now you've really lost me.

Original: Io son essa che lutto, madre, a la tua pria ch’a l’altrui ruina»
Translate: I am here grieving, Mother, for your ruin before that of others.

Original: Come si frange il sonno ove di butto nova luce percuote il viso chiuso, che fratto guizza pria che muoia tutto
Translate: As sleep stops, when suddenly a light strikes closed eyes, so that it gradually disappears little at a time

Original: così l’imaginar mio cadde giuso tosto che lume il volto mi percosse, maggior assai che quel ch’è in nostro uso
Translate: So my imagination ceased as soon as the face was struck by a light, much more intense than the one we are used to.

Original: I’ mi volgea per veder ov’ io fosse, quando una voce disse
Translate: I turned around to see where I was, when a voice said,

Original: «Qui si monta», che da ogne altro intento mi rimosse
Translate: "Here he goes up and it distracted me from all other intents

Original: e fece la mia voglia tanto pronta di riguardar chi era che parlava, che mai non posa, se non si raffronta
Translate: and filled me with such a desire to see who was speaking, that he would never rest without satisfying him.

Original: Ma come al sol che nostra vista grava e per soverchio sua figura vela, così la mia virtù quivi mancava
Translate: But my visual ability was insufficient to this, as it would be to look at the sun dazzling our eyes and does not allow us to see it for too much luminosity

Original: «Questo è divino spirito, che ne la via da ir sù ne drizza sanza prego, e col suo lume sé medesmo cela
Translate: This is a divine spirit , which without the need to pray to him directs us on the way up and with his brightness conceals its own appearance

Original: Sì fa con noi, come l’uom si fa sego
Translate: He behaves with us as man does with himself

Original: ché quale aspetta prego e l’uopo vede, malignamente già si mette al nego
Translate: For he that seeth the need, and waiteth to be prayed, prepareth wickedly to deny his help.

Original: Or accordiamo a tanto invito il piede
Translate: Now let's hurry up and pick up his invitation.

Original: procacciam di salir pria che s’abbui, ché poi non si poria, se ’l dì non riede»
Translate: Let's try to climb before it gets dark, for after that it would be impossible before the day comes back.

Original: Così disse il mio duca, e io con lui volgemmo i nostri passi ad una scala
Translate: So said my teacher, and with him I turned my steps to a ladder.

Original: e tosto ch’io al primo grado fui, senti’mi presso quasi un muover d’ala e ventarmi nel viso e dir
Translate: And as soon as I was on the first step, I heard a breath of wings and a breath of wind near my face, and a voice said,

Original: ‘Beati pacifici, che son sanz’ ira mala’
Translate: "Blessed are the meek, who are devoid of evil wrath."

Original: Già eran sovra noi tanto levati li ultimi raggi che la notte segue, che le stelle apparivan da più lati
Translate: The last rays of the sun that is followed by the night were so high above us that the stars appeared from many sides

Original: ‘O virtù mia, perché sì ti dilegue?’, fra me stesso dicea,
Translate: I said between me and me 'O my virtue, why forsake me so?',

Original: ché mi sentiva la possa de le gambe posta in triegue
Translate: For I felt the strength of my legs fainted.

Original: Noi eravam dove più non saliva la scala sù, ed eravamo affissi, pur come nave ch’a la piaggia arriva
Translate: We were there where the ladder didn't go any further, and we were standing like a ship that came to the landing place.

Original: E io attesi un poco, s’io udissi alcuna cosa nel novo girone
Translate: I waited a little, to hear something new in that frame.

Original: poi mi volsi al maestro mio, e dissi
Translate: Then I turned back to my teacher and said,

Original: «Dolce mio padre, dì, quale offensione si purga qui nel giro dove semo? Se i piè si stanno, non stea tuo sermone»
Translate: "Dolce my father, tell me, what fault do you take in the Frame where we are? If your feet stand still, do not cease your teaching."

Original: Ed elli a me
Translate: And him to me

Original: «L’amor del bene, scemo del suo dover, quiritta si ristora
Translate: Here one expiates the love of good, when it is missing of his duty

Original: qui si ribatte il mal tardato remo
Translate: Here we rebuke the oar that was too slow in life

Original: Ma perché più aperto intendi ancora, volgi la mente a me, e prenderai alcun buon frutto di nostra dimora»
Translate: But so that you understand even more clearly, turn your attention to me and you will have some good fruit from our rest.

Original: «Né creator né creatura mai», cominciò el, «figliuol, fu sanza amore, o naturale o d’animo
Translate: He began "Neither the Creator, nor any creature, son, was ever without love, either natural or election,

Original: e tu ’l sai
Translate: and you know it well

Original: Lo naturale è sempre sanza errore, ma l’altro puote errar per malo obietto o per troppo o per poco di vigore
Translate: Natural love is always correct, while the other can err because it is addressed to a wrong object, or due to poor or excessive vigor

Original: Mentre ch’elli è nel primo ben diretto, e ne’ secondi sé stesso misura, esser non può cagion di mal diletto
Translate: As long as love is directed toward the first good and is balanced toward others, there can be no sinful pleasure

Original: ma quando al mal si torce, o con più cura o con men che non dee corre nel bene, contra ’l fattore adovra sua fattura
Translate: But when he turns to evil or runs to good with less or more care than he should, then the creature works against his Creator.

Original: Quinci comprender puoi ch’esser convene amor sementa in voi d’ogne virtute e d’ogne operazion che merta pene
Translate: From this you can understand that love necessarily in you is the cause of every virtue and of every action worthy of punishment

Original: Or, perché mai non può da la salute amor del suo subietto volger viso, da l’odio proprio son le cose tute
Translate: Now, since love can never act against the salvation of one's subject, creatures are sure of self - hatred

Original: e perché intender non si può diviso, e per sé stante, alcuno esser dal primo, da quello odiare ogne effetto è deciso
Translate: and since no creature can be separated from God or stand for himself, it is impossible to hate God

Original: Resta, se dividendo bene stimo, che ’l mal che s’ama è del prossimo
Translate: It remains, if my classification is correct, that misdirected love wants the evil of the neighbor

Original: ed esso amor nasce in tre modi in vostro limo
Translate: and this love in your nature is born in three different ways

Original: È chi, per esser suo vicin soppresso, spera eccellenza, e sol per questo brama ch’el sia di sua grandezza in basso messo
Translate: There are those who hope to excel by trampling on their neighbor, and that is the only reason why they want him to lose his greatness.

Original: è chi podere, grazia, onore e fama teme di perder perch’ altri sormonti, onde s’attrista sì che ’l contrario ama
Translate: There is one who fears that he will lose power, favor, honor and fame if another overcomes him, so he grieves to the point of desiring the opposite.

Original: ed è chi per ingiuria par ch’aonti, sì che si fa de la vendetta ghiotto, e tal convien che ’l male altrui impronti
Translate: and there are those who seem to be overshadowed for having received an offense to the point of desiring revenge, and then predisposes the evil of others

Original: Questo triforme amor qua giù di sotto si piange
Translate: This triple love is punished in the underlying Frames

Original: or vo’ che tu de l’altro intende, che corre al ben con ordine corrotto
Translate: Now I want you to think about the other, who runs to good in the wrong way.

Original: Ciascun confusamente un bene apprende nel qual si queti l’animo, e disira
Translate: Everyone conceives in a confused way a supreme good, such as to satisfy the soul, and desires it

Original: per che di giugner lui ciascun contende
Translate: Everyone then tries to reach him

Original: Se lento amore a lui veder vi tira o a lui acquistar, questa cornice, dopo giusto penter, ve ne martira
Translate: If you are led to seek him or to reach him with a love too weak, this Frame makes you pay the right penalty, after repentance

Original: Altro ben è che non fa l’uom felice
Translate: There are other goods that do not make man happy

Original: non è felicità, non è la buona essenza, d’ogne ben frutto e radice
Translate: It is not true happiness; it is not the good essence which is the fruit and root of all good.

Original: L’amor ch’ad esso troppo s’abbandona, di sovr’ a noi si piange per tre cerchi
Translate: Love that abandons itself excessively to these goods is punished in the three Frames above

Original: ma come tripartito si ragiona, tacciolo, acciò che tu per te ne cerchi»
Translate: But I'm not telling you how it's tripartite, so you're looking for it on your own initiative.

Original: Posto avea fine al suo ragionamento l’alto dottore, e attento guardava ne la mia vista s’io parea contento
Translate: The distinguished master had concluded his reasoning and looked intently at me, to see if I was satisfied.

Original: e io, cui nova sete ancor frugava, di fuor tacea, e dentro dicea
Translate: and I, who was still tormented by the thirst to know, externally kept silent, and within me I said,

Original: ‘Forse lo troppo dimandar ch’io fo li grava’
Translate: 'Maybe Virgil will be irritated by my too many questions'

Original: Ma quel padre verace, che s’accorse del timido voler che non s’apriva, parlando, di parlare ardir mi porse
Translate: But that father of truth, who saw my desire that was not manifested out of fear, invited me to speak with his words.

Original: Ond’ io
Translate: Then I said,

Original: «Maestro, il mio veder s’avviva sì nel tuo lume, ch’io discerno chiaro quanto la tua ragion parta o descriva
Translate: Master, my sight is so brightened by your light that I see clearly all that your reasoning separates and analytically exposes

Original: Però ti prego, dolce padre caro, che mi dimostri amore, a cui reduci ogne buono operare e ’l suo contraro»
Translate: Therefore, my dear sweet father, I beg you to explain to me what is the love to which you bring back every virtuous action and its opposite.

Original: «Drizza», disse, «ver’ me l’agute luci de lo ’ntelletto, e fieti manifesto l’error de’ ciechi che si fanno duci
Translate: He said, "Turn to me the sharp eyes of the intellect, and the error of the blind who claim to be the guide will be clear to you.

Original: L’animo, ch’è creato ad amar presto, ad ogne cosa è mobile che piace, tosto che dal piacere in atto è desto
Translate: The soul, which is created with the disposition to love, moves toward everything she likes, as soon as such arrangement is put into effect by the pleasant thing

Original: Vostra apprensiva da esser verace tragge intenzione, e dentro a voi la spiega, sì che l’animo ad essa volger face
Translate: Your cognitive faculty draws the image from a real thing and processes it within you, so that the soul moves towards it

Original: e se, rivolto, inver’ di lei si piega, quel piegare è amor, quell’ è natura che per piacer di novo in voi si lega
Translate: and if the soul, so directed, turns toward that thing, this act is love, it is a natural attitude that primarily binds itself in you for the pleasant thing

Original: Poi, come ’l foco movesi in altura per la sua forma ch’è nata a salire là dove più in sua matera dura,
Translate: Then, as the fire rises upward by its nature, which impels it to go up there where its matter lasts longer,

Original: così l’animo preso entra in disire, ch’è moto spiritale, e mai non posa fin che la cosa amata il fa gioire
Translate: so the soul taken from love nourishes the desire, which is a movement of the spirit, and does not cease for all the time when the beloved thing gives him joy

Original: Or ti puote apparer quant’ è nascosa la veritate a la gente ch’avvera ciascun amore in sé laudabil cosa
Translate: Now you can understand how hidden the truth is to those who claim that every love is praiseworthy of itself

Original: però che forse appar la sua matera sempre esser buona, ma non ciascun segno è buono, ancor che buona sia la cera»
Translate: For perhaps his matter is always good, but every seal is not good, even though the wax is good.

Original: «Le tue parole e ’l mio seguace ingegno», rispuos’ io lui, «m’hanno amor discoverto, ma ciò m’ha fatto di dubbiar più pregno
Translate: I answered him, "Your words and my craving to follow you have explained to me the nature of love, but this moves me even more to doubt.

Original: ché, s’amore è di fuori a noi offerto e l’anima non va con altro piede, se dritta o torta va, non è suo merto»
Translate: In fact, if love is offered to us by external reality and the soul cannot help but be induced by it, it is not his merit or his fault if he acts in a right or wrong way.

Original: Ed elli a me
Translate: And him to me

Original: «Quanto ragion qui vede, dir ti poss’ io
Translate: "I can tell you what human reason understands."

Original: da indi in là t’aspetta pur a Beatrice, ch’è opra di fede
Translate: for all that goes beyond I send you back to Beatrice, for this is a matter of faith.

Original: Ogne forma sustanzïal, che setta è da matera ed è con lei unita, specifica vertute ha in sé colletta,
Translate: Every soul, which is separated from matter and at the same time united with it, has gathered within itself a specific disposition,

Original: la qual sanza operar non è sentita, né si dimostra mai che per effetto, come per verdi fronde in pianta vita
Translate: which is not warned if it does not act, nor is it visible if it does not produce its effects, as life in the plant is seen through the green leaves

Original: Però, là onde vegna lo ’ntelletto de le prime notizie, omo non sape, e de’ primi appetibili l’affetto,
Translate: So man ignores where knowledge of the first notions and love for the first goods comes from,

Original: che sono in voi sì come studio in ape di far lo mele
Translate: who are connatural in you as in the bee the attitude to produce honey

Original: e questa prima voglia merto di lode o di biasmo non cape
Translate: and this first inclination is not worthy of praise or reproach

Original: Or perché a questa ogn’ altra si raccoglia, innata v’è la virtù che consiglia, e de l’assenso de’ tener la soglia
Translate: Now, because all the others conform to this arrangement, a virtue is innate in you that gives advice, that must give or deny consent to act

Original: Quest’ è ’l principio là onde si piglia ragion di meritare in voi, secondo che buoni e rei amori accoglie e viglia
Translate: This is the principle of merit or reproach in you, depending on whether you examine and separate good and bad loves.

Original: Color che ragionando andaro al fondo, s’accorser d’esta innata libertate
Translate: Those who reasoned went to the bottom of the matter realized this innate freedom

Original: però moralità lasciaro al mondo
Translate: That is why they worked out morals for the world.

Original: Onde, poniam che di necessitate surga ogne amor che dentro a voi s’accende, di ritenerlo è in voi la podestate
Translate: Therefore, even admitting that every love is born in you in a necessary way, you have the power to restrain it.

Original: La nobile virtù Beatrice intende per lo libero arbitrio, e però guarda che l’abbi a mente, s’a parlar ten prende»
Translate: Beatrice calls this noble virtue 'free will', and so beware of reminding you, if she should tell you about it.

Original: La luna, quasi a mezza notte tarda, facea le stelle a noi parer più rade, fatta com’ un secchion che tuttor arda
Translate: The moon, when it was now midnight, clouded the stars with its light, like a shining copper cauliflower.

Original: e correa contro ’l ciel per quelle strade che ’l sole infiamma allor che quel da Roma tra ’ Sardi e ’ Corsi il vede quando cade
Translate: and walked across the sky in the opposite direction to that which the sun walked when it sets between Sardinia and Corsica, for those who look from Rome

Original: E quell’ ombra gentil per cui si noma Pietola più che villa mantoana, del mio carcar diposta avea la soma
Translate: And that noble soul, for which Pietole is more famous than any city in the Mantua, was freed from the weight of the explanation that I had imposed on him

Original: per ch’io, che la ragione aperta e piana sovra le mie quistioni avea ricolta, stava com’ om che sonnolento vana
Translate: So I, who had gathered clear ideas in my mind over those matters, was like a man who was sneaking around in his sleep.

Original: Ma questa sonnolenza mi fu tolta subitamente da gente che dopo le nostre spalle a noi era già volta
Translate: But my drowsiness was suddenly interrupted by souls running behind our backs

Original: E quale Ismeno già vide e Asopo lungo di sè di notte furia e calca, pur che i Teban di Bacco avesser uopo,
Translate: And as the rivers Ismenus and Asopus saw by night a crowd running furiously along their course, when the Thebans needed Bacchus,

Original: cotal per quel giron suo passo falca, per quel ch’io vidi di color, venendo, cui buon volere e giusto amor cavalca
Translate: in the same way in that Frame who is ridden by good will and right love turns his own step, as I saw those souls doing

Original: Tosto fur sovr’ a noi, perché correndo si movea tutta quella turba magna
Translate: Soon they were with us, for all that great crowd was running.

Original: e due dinanzi gridavan piangendo
Translate: and two crying in front of the others,

Original: «Maria corse con fretta a la montagna
Translate: maria hurried to the mountain

Original: e Cesare, per soggiogare Ilerda, punse Marsilia e poi corse in Ispagna»
Translate: And Caesar, to subdue Ilerda, struck Marseilles, and then ran to Spain.

Original: «Ratto, ratto, che ’l tempo non si perda per poco amor», gridavan li altri appresso,
Translate: The others behind them shouted "Quickly, quickly, let us not waste time for little love,

Original: «che studio di ben far grazia rinverda»
Translate: Let grace flourish with the commitment to do well.

Original: «O gente in cui fervore aguto adesso ricompie forse negligenza e indugio da voi per tepidezza in ben far messo,
Translate: O people, in whom now a keen fervour, perhaps, compensates for the neglect and indulgence which you, out of lukewarm love, put into doing good,

Original: questi che vive, e certo i’ non vi bugio, vuole andar sù, pur che ’l sol ne riluca
Translate: He who is alive, and certainly I am not lying to you, wants to go up, as soon as the sun shines again.

Original: però ne dite ond’ è presso il pertugio»
Translate: So tell us where the nearest passage is.

Original: Parole furon queste del mio duca
Translate: These were the words of my guidance.

Original: e un di quelli spirti disse
Translate: and one of those spirits said,

Original: «Vieni di retro a noi, e troverai la buca
Translate: "Come behind us and you will find the gap

Original: Noi siam di voglia a muoverci sì pieni, che restar non potem
Translate: We're so excited to move, we can't stop.

Original: però perdona, se villania nostra giustizia tieni
Translate: Forgive us, then, if you think that our righteousness is unkind.

Original: Io fui abate in San Zeno a Verona sotto lo ’mperio del buon Barbarossa, di cui dolente ancor Milan ragiona
Translate: I was the abbot of the basilica of San Zeno in Verona, under the empire of the good Federico Barbarossa, of which Milan still today regrets painful

Original: E tale ha già l’un piè dentro la fossa, che tosto piangerà quel monastero, e tristo fia d’avere avuta possa
Translate: And such one is already almost dying, and will soon regret that monastery, and will be sad to have had power over it

Original: perché suo figlio, mal del corpo intero, e de la mente peggio, e che mal nacque, ha posto in loco di suo pastor vero»
Translate: For he hath laid there as his abbot, in the place of that which was to perform the charge, his son, maimed in body and mind, and born evil:

Original: Io non so se più disse o s’ei si tacque, tant’ era già di là da noi trascorso
Translate: I don't know if he added anything else or kept quiet, so he had already run away from us

Original: ma questo intesi, e ritener mi piacque
Translate: But I heard this, and I wanted to transcribe it.

Original: E quei che m’era ad ogne uopo soccorso disse
Translate: And he that was my help in every circumstance said,

Original: «Volgiti qua
Translate: Turn around this way.

Original: vedine due venir dando a l’accidïa di morso»
Translate: Here are two souls who blame the blame of the sloth

Original: Di retro a tutti dicean
Translate: Behind everyone they said

Original: «Prima fue morta la gente a cui il mar s’aperse, che vedesse Iordan le rede sue
Translate: The people for whom the Red Sea was opened died before the Jordan saw its heirs

Original: E quella che l’affanno non sofferse fino a la fine col figlio d’Anchise, sé stessa a vita sanza gloria offerse»
Translate: And that people who could not bear the troubles of the journey with Anchise to Italy, condemned themselves to a life without glory.

Original: Poi quando fuor da noi tanto divise quell’ ombre, che veder più non potiersi,
Translate: Then, when those souls were so far away from us that they could no longer be heard,

Original: novo pensiero dentro a me si mise, del qual più altri nacquero e diversi
Translate: A new thought was born in my mind, from which more and more were born.

Original: e tanto d’uno in altro vaneggiai, che li occhi per vaghezza ricopersi, e ’l pensamento in sogno trasmutai
Translate: and I wandered from one to the other, so much so that through tiredness I closed my eyes and turned my thoughts into dreams.

Original: Ne l’ora che non può ’l calor dïurno intepidar più ’l freddo de la luna, vinto da terra,
Translate: In the hour when the heat of the day can no longer diminish the cold of the moon rays, extinguished from the cold of the Earth

Original: e talor da Saturno
Translate: and sometimes from that of Saturn,

Original: —quando i geomanti lor Maggior Fortuna veggiono in orïente, innanzi a l’alba, surger per via che poco le sta bruna—,
Translate: when geomants see the figure of Fortune Major rising to the east, before dawn, soon being clouded by sunlight,

Original: mi venne in sogno una femmina balba, ne li occhi guercia, e sovra i piè distorta, con le man monche, e di colore scialba
Translate: I saw in a dream a stuttering woman, with crooked eyes and lame feet, with her hands crippled, and with a dull colour.

Original: Io la mirava
Translate: I was looking at her.

Original: e come ’l sol conforta le fredde membra che la notte aggrava, così lo sguardo mio le facea scorta la lingua,
Translate: And as the sun warms the cold limbs during the night, so my gaze made her tongue loose,

Original: e poscia tutta la drizzava in poco d’ora, e lo smarrito volto, com’ amor vuol, così le colorava
Translate: And then he lifted up her body in a short time, and colored her face with the dark color that love requires.

Original: Poi ch’ell’ avea ’l parlar così disciolto, cominciava a cantar sì, che con pena da lei avrei mio intento rivolto
Translate: Since she had bought a loose little speech, she began to sing so that I would have had difficulty distracting my attention from her.

Original: «Io son», cantava, «io son dolce serena, che ’ marinari in mezzo mar dismago
Translate: Singing "I am a sweet mermaid, who fascinate the sailors in the middle of the sea,

Original: tanto son di piacere a sentir piena
Translate: so I'm pleasant to listen

Original: Io volsi Ulisse del suo cammin vago al canto mio
Translate: I turned away Ulysses, though desirous of his way, by my song.

Original: e qual meco s’ausa, rado sen parte
Translate: and who gets used to being with me, rarely abandons me,

Original: sì tutto l’appago»
Translate: so much I put it down

Original: Ancor non era sua bocca richiusa, quand’ una donna apparve santa e presta lunghesso me per far colei confusa
Translate: His mouth had not yet closed, when a holy and solicitous woman appeared beside me, who wanted to confuse the other.

Original: «O Virgilio, Virgilio, chi è questa?», fieramente dicea
Translate: And she said with pride, O Virgil, Virgil, who is this?

Original: ed el venìa con li occhi fitti pur in quella onesta
Translate: And he would approach, and keep his eyes fixed on that honest one.

Original: L’altra prendea, e dinanzi l’apria fendendo i drappi, e mostravami ’l ventre
Translate: Virgil took the other and tore her robe on the front, showing me her belly.

Original: quel mi svegliò col puzzo che n’uscia
Translate: It woke me with the smell that came out

Original: Io mossi li occhi, e ’l buon maestro
Translate: I turned my gaze and the good teacher

Original: «Almen tre voci t’ho messe», dicea,
Translate: "I've called you at least three times," he said,

Original: «Surgi e vieni
Translate: Get up and come,

Original: troviam l’aperta per la qual tu entre»
Translate: we find the passage to move to the next Frame

Original: Sù mi levai, e tutti eran già pieni de l’alto dì i giron del sacro monte, e andavam col sol novo a le reni
Translate: And I rose up, and all the cornices of the holy mountain were lighted by the high sun, that we might walk with the sun behind us.

Original: Seguendo lui, portava la mia fronte come colui che l’ha di pensier carca, che fa di sé un mezzo arco di ponte
Translate: Following Virgil, I kept my forehead as low as the one who charged her with thoughts, so much so that it is similar to a half arch of bridge

Original: quand’ io udi’
Translate: when I heard

Original: «Venite qui si varca»
Translate: "Come, the passage is here"

Original: parlare in modo soave e benigno, qual non si sente in questa mortal marca
Translate: with such a sweet and benevolent voice that you never hear in this mortal world

Original: Con l’ali aperte, che parean di cigno, volseci in sù colui che sì parlonne tra due pareti del duro macigno
Translate: And he that spake unto us, opening the white wings as the wings of a swan, turned us up between the two rocky walls of the mountain.

Original: Mosse le penne poi e ventilonne, ‘Qui lugent’ affermando esser beati, ch’avran di consolar l’anime donne
Translate: And he lifted up his feathers, and made wind, saying that they that weep are blessed: for they shall have the souls that are consolation.

Original: «Che hai che pur inver’ la terra guati?», la guida mia incominciò a dirmi,
Translate: My guide began to tell me, "What do you have, that you only look down?"

Original: poco amendue da l’angel sormontati
Translate: when we came up a little from where we met the angel

Original: E io
Translate: And I

Original: «Con tanta sospeccion fa irmi novella visïon ch’a sé mi piega, sì ch’io non posso dal pensar partirmi»
Translate: "A dream that I have made and that makes me think, moves me to walk full of doubts, because I can't get away from it."

Original: «Vedesti», disse, «quell’antica strega che sola sovr’ a noi omai si piagne
Translate: He said, "You have seen that ancient witch who is the only sin punished above us."

Original: vedesti come l’uom da lei si slega
Translate: You've seen how man can get rid of it.

Original: Bastiti, e batti a terra le calcagne
Translate: That's enough for you, and now hurry up.

Original: li occhi rivolgi al logoro che gira lo rege etterno con le rote magne»
Translate: turn your gaze to the call that the eternal king makes to spin with the celestial wheels.

Original: Quale ’l falcon, che prima a’ pié si mira, indi si volge al grido e si protende per lo disio del pasto che là il tira, tal mi fec’ io
Translate: Like the falcon, who first looks to the ground and then turns to the call of the master and flies for the desire of the food that attracts him, so I

Original: e tal, quanto si fende la roccia per dar via a chi va suso, n’andai infin dove ’l cerchiar si prende
Translate: And with this solicitude I climbed up the whole staircase dug between the rock, as far as the V Frame begins.

Original: Com’ io nel quinto giro fui dischiuso, vidi gente per esso che piangea, giacendo a terra tutta volta in giuso
Translate: As soon as I was in the Fifth Frame, I saw souls weeping and all lying face to face on the ground

Original: ‘Adhaesit pavimento anima mea’ sentia dir lor con sì alti sospiri, che la parola a pena s’intendea
Translate: I felt that they were saying 'My soul stuck to the ground', with so deep sighs that their words could barely be understood.

Original: «O eletti di Dio, li cui soffriri e giustizia e speranza fa men duri, drizzate noi verso li alti saliri»
Translate: "O souls chosen by God, whose sufferings are made less severe by righteousness and hope, show us the way up to the next Frame."

Original: «Se voi venite dal giacer sicuri, e volete trovar la via più tosto, le vostre destre sien sempre di fori»
Translate: If you walk without being forced to lie down and want to find the way faster, proceed with your right side towards the outside of the Frame.

Original: Così pregò ’l poeta, e sì risposto poco dinanzi a noi ne fu
Translate: So he prayed to Virgil, and so he was answered not far from us.

Original: per ch’io nel parlare avvisai l’altro nascosto, e volsi li occhi a li occhi al segnor mio
Translate: And because I understood that that soul wanted to say something else, I turned my gaze to my teacher.

Original: ond’ elli m’assentì con lieto cenno ciò che chiedea la vista del disio
Translate: He told me with a glad nod that I could do what I asked with my gaze

Original: Poi ch’io potei di me fare a mio senno, trassimi sovra quella creatura le cui parole pria notar mi fenno, dicendo
Translate: When I could do as I wanted, I took over that soul whose words before allowed me to spot it, saying,

Original: «Spirto in cui pianger matura quel sanza ’l quale a Dio tornar non pòssi, sosta un poco per me tua maggior cura
Translate: "O spirit, in which tears ripen that without which you cannot return to God, stop a moment for me your greatest concern

Original: Chi fosti e perché vòlti avete i dossi al sù, mi dì, e se vuo’ ch’io t’impetri cosa di là ond’ io vivendo mossi»
Translate: Tell me who you were and why you have your back turned up, and if you want me to get something for you in the world from which, I live, I come

Original: Ed elli a me
Translate: And him to me

Original: «Perché i nostri diretri rivolga il cielo a sé, saprai
Translate: "You know why heaven turns our backs to Him,

Original: ma prima scias quod ego fui successor Petri
Translate: But first know that I was the successor of Peter.

Original: Intra Sïestri e Chiaveri s’adima una fiumana bella, e del suo nome lo titol del mio sangue fa sua cima
Translate: Between Sestri Levante and Chiavari a beautiful river descends to the valley, and my house places its name on the upper part of its noble coat of arms

Original: Un mese e poco più prova’ io come pesa il gran manto a chi dal fango il guarda, che piuma sembran tutte l’altre some
Translate: I tried for a little more than a month how the papal cloak weighs to those who preserve it from corruption, so much so that every other charge in comparison seems light as a feather

Original: La mia conversïone, omè,
Translate: My conversion, alas,

Original: fu tarda
Translate: was late

Original: ma, come fatto fui roman pastore, così scopersi la vita bugiarda
Translate: But as soon as I became a pontiff, I discovered how much a liar my life was.

Original: Vidi che lì non s’acquetava il core, né più salir potiesi in quella vita
Translate: I realized that in that office my heart was not satisfied and I could not aspire to a higher dignity

Original: per che di questa in me s’accese amore
Translate: Then I turned with love to eternal life

Original: Fino a quel punto misera e partita da Dio anima fui, del tutto avara
Translate: Until then I had been a wretched soul and completely separated from God, full of greed.

Original: or, come vedi, qui ne son punita
Translate: Now, as you can see, I'm gonna give you the right amount of money.

Original: Quel ch’avarizia fa, qui si dichiara in purgazion de l’anime converse
Translate: Here the punishment inflicted on the converted souls declares the effects of greed

Original: e nulla pena il monte ha più amara
Translate: and the mountain has no more bitter pain than this

Original: Sì come l’occhio nostro non s’aderse in alto, fisso a le cose terrene, così giustizia qui a terra il merse
Translate: Just as our gaze did not rise up, standing fixed on earthly goods, so divine justice here has turned him to the ground.

Original: Come avarizia spense a ciascun bene lo nostro amore, onde operar perdési,
Translate: And just as greed extinguished our love for all spiritual good, so we lost the opportunity to work well,

Original: così giustizia qui stretti ne tene, ne’ piedi e ne le man legati e presi
Translate: So justice holds us tight here, bound in our hands and feet

Original: e quanto fia piacer del giusto Sire, tanto staremo immobili e distesi»
Translate: and we will be standing and lying on the ground as much as the righteous Lord will like.

Original: Io m’era inginocchiato e volea dire
Translate: I was on my knees and I wanted to talk.

Original: ma com’ io cominciai ed el s’accorse, solo ascoltando, del mio reverire,
Translate: But as soon as I started and he realized, just listening to me, my reverence,

Original: «Qual cagion», disse, «in giù così ti torse?»
