Translate: If you believed that my smile had another reason, ignore it as not true, and believe that the cause were those words you said about him.

Original: Già s’inchinava ad abbracciar li piedi al mio dottor, ma el li disse
Translate: Already Stazius bowed down to embrace my master's feet, but he said to him,

Original: «Frate, non far, ché tu se’ ombra e ombra vedi»
Translate: "Brother, don't do this, for you are a shadow and you see before you another shadow."

Original: Ed ei surgendo
Translate: And he rose up

Original: «Or puoi la quantitate comprender de l’amor ch’a te mi scalda,
Translate: "Now you can see how great the love I have for you is,

Original: quand’ io dismento nostra vanitate,
Translate: Since I forget our inconsistency,

Original: trattando l’ombre come cosa salda»
Translate: treating the shadows as if they were material bodies.

Original: Già era l’angel dietro a noi rimaso, l’angel che n’avea vòlti al sesto giro, avendomi dal viso un colpo raso
Translate: The angel was now behind us, the angel who had addressed us to the 6th Frame, after having wiped out of my forehead the Fear

Original: e quei c’hanno a giustizia lor disiro detto n’avea beati, e le sue voci con ‘sitiunt’, sanz’ altro, ciò forniro
Translate: and had declared blessed those who desire righteousness, and his words ended with 'sitiunt' without adding anything else.

Original: E io più lieve che per l’altre foci m’andava, sì che sanz’ alcun labore seguiva in sù li spiriti veloci
Translate: And I walked lighter than through the other passages, so that I followed up those fast spirits without any effort.

Original: quando Virgilio incominciò
Translate: when Virgil began to say,

Original: «Amore, acceso di virtù, sempre altro accese, pur che la fiamma sua paresse fore
Translate: A love, provided that it is virtuous, was always fulfilled, provided that its flame was visible.

Original: onde da l’ora che tra noi discese nel limbo de lo ’nferno Giovenale, che la tua affezion mi fé palese,
Translate: Therefore, from the day that he came down among us into the Limbo Giovenale, which revealed to me your affection for me,

Original: mia benvoglienza inverso te fu quale più strinse mai di non vista persona, sì ch’or mi parran corte queste scale
Translate: My benevolence toward you was as much as anyone ever felt for anyone ever seen, to the point that now these stairs will seem short to me.

Original: Ma dimmi, e come amico mi perdona se troppa sicurtà m’allarga il freno, e come amico omai meco ragiona
Translate: But tell me, and as a friend forgive me if I speak too confidently, and as a friend speak to me now

Original: come poté trovar dentro al tuo seno loco avarizia, tra cotanto senno di quanto per tua cura fosti pieno?»
Translate: How is it possible that in your heart he has lodged greed, in the wisdom of which you were filled for your concern?

Original: Queste parole Stazio mover fenno un poco a riso pria
Translate: These words moved Stazio to laugh at first a little

Original: poscia rispuose
Translate: then he answered

Original: «Ogne tuo dir d’amor m’è caro cenno
Translate: "Every word of yours is a pleasing clue to your affection."

Original: Veramente più volte appaion cose che danno a dubitar falsa matera per le vere ragion che son nascose
Translate: In truth, things often appear that cause doubt on nonexistent matters, because the real causes are hidden.

Original: La tua dimanda tuo creder m’avvera esser ch’i’ fossi avaro in l’altra vita, forse per quella cerchia dov’ io era
Translate: Your question confirms to me that you believe that I on Earth was miserable, perhaps because I was in that frame.

Original: Or sappi ch’avarizia fu partita troppo da me, e questa dismisura migliaia di lunari hanno punita
Translate: Now, know that greed was too far from me, and this excess has been punished for thousands of months in Purgatory.

Original: E se non fosse ch’io drizzai mia cura, quand’ io intesi là dove tu chiame, crucciato quasi a l’umana natura
Translate: And if I had not paid attention, when I read that passage in which you, almost angry against human nature, affirm

Original: ‘Per che non reggi tu, o sacra fame de l’oro, l’appetito de’ mortali?’, voltando sentirei le giostre grame
Translate: "O righteous hunger for gold, why doth not the hearts of mortals rule?" "I would be damned in hell and make the boulders rotate."

Original: Allor m’accorsi che troppo aprir l’ali potean le mani a spendere, e pente’mi così di quel come de li altri mali
Translate: Then I realized that my hands could spend too much, and I repented of that as of other sins.

Original: Quanti risurgeran coi crini scemi per ignoranza, che di questa pecca toglie ’l penter vivendo e ne li stremi
Translate: How many damned will rise again with their hair cut out out of ignorance of this, which during life and at the point of death precludes the repentance of this guilt

Original: E sappie che la colpa che rimbecca per dritta opposizione alcun peccato, con esso insieme qui suo verde secca
Translate: And know that the guilt that opposes a sin is atoned here together with it

Original: però, s’io son tra quella gente stato che piange l’avarizia, per purgarmi, per lo contrario suo m’è incontrato»
Translate: Therefore, if I have been among the penitent who expound greed, it has touched me to atone for the opposite sin.

Original: «Or quando tu cantasti le crude armi de la doppia trestizia di Giocasta»,
Translate: Now, when thou sang the cruel war of the two sons of Jocastah,

Original: disse ’l cantor de’ buccolici carmi,
Translate: said the author of the bucolic charms,

Original: «per quello che Clïò teco lì tasta, non par che ti facesse ancor fedele la fede, sanza qual ben far non basta
Translate: For what the Musa Clio plays in your verse does not seem that you still had faith, without which good deeds are insufficient

Original: Se così è, qual sole o quai candele ti stenebraron sì, che tu drizzasti poscia di retro al pescator le vele?»
Translate: If so, which sun or candles enlightened you to the point of making you follow St Peter's message?

Original: Ed elli a lui
Translate: And Station to him

Original: «Tu prima m’invïasti verso Parnaso a ber ne le sue grotte, e prima appresso Dio m’alluminasti
Translate: You first sent me to drink in the caves of Parnasus, and you first enlightened me after God.

Original: Facesti come quei che va di notte, che porta il lume dietro e sé non giova, ma dopo sé fa le persone dotte, quando dicesti
Translate: Thou hast done as that which goeth at night, bringing the light after it, not profiting itself, but enlightening those who follow it, when thou saidst,

Original: ‘Secol si rinova
Translate: 'Time is renewed

Original: torna giustizia e primo tempo umano, e progenïe scende da ciel nova’
Translate: The righteousness and the first age of man return, and from heaven a new seed descendeth.

Original: Per te poeta fui, per te cristiano
Translate: Thanks to you I became a poet and a Christian

Original: ma perché veggi mei ciò ch’io disegno, a colorare stenderò la mano
Translate: But that you may understand what I say better, I will add more details.

Original: Già era ’l mondo tutto quanto pregno de la vera credenza, seminata per li messaggi de l’etterno regno
Translate: Now the world was full of true religion, spread by the messengers of the everlasting kingdom.

Original: e la parola tua sopra toccata si consonava a’ nuovi predicanti
Translate: and your words that I mentioned before adapted to the new preachers

Original: ond’ io a visitarli presi usata
Translate: So I got used to visiting them.

Original: Vennermi poi parendo tanto santi, che, quando Domizian li perseguette, sanza mio lagrimar non fur lor pianti
Translate: They seemed to me to be so holy that, when Domitian pursued them, their tears were accompanied by my tears.

Original: e mentre che di là per me si stette, io li sovvenni, e i lor dritti costumi fer dispregiare a me tutte altre sette
Translate: And while I was alive, I helped them, and their upright manners led me to despise every other religious worship.

Original: E pria ch’io conducessi i Greci a’ fiumi di Tebe poetando, ebb’ io battesmo
Translate: And before I brought the Greeks to the rivers of Thebes in my verses, I was baptized.

Original: ma per paura chiuso cristian fu’mi, lungamente mostrando paganesmo
Translate: But for fear I hid my religion, long flaunting paganism

Original: e questa tepidezza il quarto cerchio cerchiar mi fé più che ’l quarto centesmo
Translate: and this fear forced me to turn the mountain into the 4th Frame over four centuries

Original: Tu dunque, che levato hai il coperchio che m’ascondeva quanto bene io dico, mentre che del salire avem soverchio,
Translate: You, then, who lifted up the cover that hid the good that I told you, while we were busy climbing up,

Original: dimmi dov’ è Terrenzio nostro antico, Cecilio e Plauto e Varro, se lo sai
Translate: Tell me where our ancient Terenzio is, and where Cecilio, Plauti and Varrone are, if you know

Original: dimmi se son dannati, e in qual vico»
Translate: tell me if they're damned, and in which circle

Original: «Costoro e Persio e io e altri assai»,
Translate: "Cosoro, Persio, me and many others

Original: rispuose il duca mio,
Translate: answered my teacher, saying,

Original: «siam con quel Greco che le Muse lattar più ch’altri mai, nel primo cinghio del carcere cieco
Translate: We are together with that Greek poet that the Muses nursed more than anyone else, in the First Circle of Dark Prison

Original: spesse fïate ragioniam del monte che sempre ha le nutrice nostre seco
Translate: We often talk about the mountain that always has our nutrients with it

Original: Euripide v’è nosco e Antifonte, Simonide, Agatone e altri piùe Greci che già di lauro ornar la fronte
Translate: With us there are also Euripides, Antiphons, Simonides, Agatones and many other Greeks who have adorned their foreheads with laurel

Original: Quivi si veggion de le genti tue Antigone, Deïfile e Argia, e Ismene sì trista come fue
Translate: Here you can see among your characters Antigone, Deifile and Argia, and Ismene as sad as it was

Original: Védeisi quella che mostrò Langia
Translate: You can see what the source of Langia showed.

Original: èvvi la figlia di Tiresia, e Teti, e con le suore sue Deïdamia»
Translate: There is the daughter of Tyresiah , Teths, and Deidamia, and her sisters.

Original: Tacevansi ambedue già li poeti, di novo attenti a riguardar dintorno, liberi da saliri e da pareti
Translate: The two poets were now silent, once again attentive to looking around, now free from climbing and walls

Original: e già le quattro ancelle eran del giorno rimase a dietro, e la quinta era al temo, drizzando pur in sù l’ardente corno, quando il mio duca
Translate: And by this time the four maids of the day were left behind, and the fifth was at the helm, raising up the burning point, when my teacher said,

Original: «Io credo ch’a lo stremo le destre spalle volger ne convegna, girando il monte come far solemo»
Translate: "I think we should turn our backs right at the edge of the Frame, turning the mountain as we used to do"

Original: Così l’usanza fu lì nostra insegna, e prendemmo la via con men sospetto per l’assentir di quell’ anima degna
Translate: So the custom showed us what to do, and we walked with less hesitation thanks to the tacit assent of that so worthy soul

Original: Elli givan dinanzi, e io soletto di retro, e ascoltava i lor sermoni, ch’a poetar mi davano intelletto
Translate: And they went before me, and I was alone behind them, and heard their words, which gave me the matter of poetry.

Original: Ma tosto ruppe le dolci ragioni un alber che trovammo in mezza strada, con pomi a odorar soavi e buoni
Translate: But suddenly the sweet reasonings were interrupted by a tree that we found in the middle of the way, with fruits of sweet and pleasant fragrance.

Original: e come abete in alto si digrada di ramo in ramo, così quello in giuso, cred’ io, perché persona sù non vada
Translate: And as a fir tree grows thinly upward, from branch to branch, so does it down, I think to prevent someone from climbing there.

Original: Dal lato onde ’l cammin nostro era chiuso, cadea de l’alta roccia un liquor chiaro e si spandeva per le foglie suso
Translate: From the side where our path was closed from the wall of the mountain, from the high rock there was a crystal clear water pouring out between the leaves, upward

Original: Li due poeti a l’alber s’appressaro
Translate: The two poets approached the tree

Original: e una voce per entro le fronde gridò
Translate: and a voice through the leaves cried out

Original: «Di questo cibo avrete caro»
Translate: "You will miss this food"

Original: Poi disse
Translate: Then he added

Original: «Più pensava Maria onde fosser le nozze orrevoli e intere, ch’a la sua bocca, ch’or per voi risponde
Translate: Mary cared more that the wedding was honorable than to her mouth, which now intercedes for you.

Original: E le Romane antiche, per lor bere, contente furon d’acqua
Translate: And the ancient Romans, to drink, were content with water.

Original: e Danïello dispregiò cibo e acquistò savere
Translate: And Daniel the prophet despised food, and gained wisdom.

Original: Lo secol primo, quant’ oro fu bello, fé savorose con fame le ghiande, e nettare con sete ogne ruscello
Translate: During the first age of man, as long as it was golden, hunger made the acorns appealing and thirst made every stream nectar

Original: Mele e locuste furon le vivande che nodriro il Batista nel diserto
Translate: Honey and locusts were the food that fed John the Baptist in the wilderness

Original: per ch’elli è glorïoso e tanto grande quanto per lo Vangelio v’è aperto»
Translate: Therefore he is glorious and as great as he is revealed to you in the Gospel.

Original: Mentre che li occhi per la fronda verde ficcava ïo sì come far suole chi dietro a li uccellin sua vita perde,
Translate: While I pushed my gaze through the green branches of the tree, just as it is customary to do those who waste their lives hunting birds,

Original: lo più che padre mi dicea
Translate: Virgil told me

Original: «Figliuole, vienne oramai, ché ’l tempo che n’è imposto più utilmente compartir si vuole»
Translate: Son, come away, for the time that is given to us must be spent more usefully.

Original: Io volsi ’l viso, e ’l passo non men tosto, appresso i savi, che parlavan sìe, che l’andar mi facean di nullo costo
Translate: I turned my gaze and step no less quickly behind those two wise men, who spoke in such a way as not to make me feel any difficulty in proceeding

Original: Ed ecco piangere e cantar s’udìe ‘Labïa mëa, Domine’ per modo tal, che diletto e doglia parturìe
Translate: And behold, there was someone crying and singing, 'O Lord, my lips', in such a way that joy and sorrow were born in us.

Original: «O dolce padre, che è quel ch’i’ odo?», comincia’ io
Translate: I started "O sweet father, what is what I feel?

Original: ed elli
Translate: And him

Original: «Ombre che vanno forse di lor dover solvendo il nodo»
Translate: "Perhaps they are souls who are atoning for their sins"

Original: Sì come i peregrin pensosi fanno, giugnendo per cammin gente non nota, che si volgono ad essa e non restanno,
Translate: How do pilgrims assorted in their thoughts, who, when on their way reach unknown people,

Original: così di retro a noi, più tosto mota, venendo e trapassando ci ammirava d’anime turba tacita e devota
Translate: They turn to them and do not stop, so a host of silent and devout souls watched us with astonishment, coming behind us at a faster pace and crossing us

Original: Ne li occhi era ciascuna oscura e cava, palida ne la faccia, e tanto scema che da l’ossa la pelle s’informava
Translate: Each of them had dark, hollowed eyes, and had pale, skin so thin that the skin was wholly attached to the bones.

Original: Non credo che così a buccia strema Erisittone fosse fatto secco, per digiunar, quando più n’ebbe tema
Translate: I don't think Erisittone had lost weight in this way to the skin alone, because of fasting, when he was more afraid of it.

Original: Io dicea fra me stesso pensando
Translate: I, thinking, was between me and me

Original: ‘Ecco la gente che perdé Ierusalemme, quando Maria nel figlio diè di becco’
Translate: These are the Jews who lost Jerusalem, when Mary of Eleazar devoured her son.

Original: Parean l’occhiaie anella sanza gemme
Translate: The shiners looked like rings without gems

Original: chi nel viso de li uomini legge ‘omo’ ben avria quivi conosciuta l’emme
Translate: Who in the face of men reads the word 'homo', on their faces could distinguish the 'emme'

Original: Chi crederebbe che l’odor d’un pomo sì governasse, generando brama, e quel d’un’acqua, non sappiendo como?
Translate: Who, not knowing how this happens, could believe that the scent of a fruit and water reduces in such a state, generating hunger and thirst?

Original: Già era in ammirar che sì li affama, per la cagione ancor non manifesta di lor magrezza e di lor trista squama,
Translate: I was intent on looking at them and wondering what would starve them like this, because the cause of their thinness and scaly skin was not yet known,

Original: ed ecco del profondo de la testa volse a me li occhi un’ombra e guardò fiso
Translate: when, behold, a soul turned my eyes from the bottom of my head, and stared at me.

Original: poi gridò forte
Translate: Then he shouted loudly

Original: «Qual grazia m’è questa?»
Translate: What grace is this for me?

Original: Mai non l’avrei riconosciuto al viso
Translate: I would never have recognized him by his appearance,

Original: ma ne la voce sua mi fu palese ciò che l’aspetto in sé avea conquiso
Translate: But in his voice it was clear to me what his face had hidden.

Original: Questa favilla tutta mi raccese mia conoscenza a la cangiata labbia, e ravvisai la faccia di Forese
Translate: This spark rekindled all my knowledge of that transformed face, and I recognized the face of Forese Donati

Original: «Deh, non contendere a l’asciutta scabbia che mi scolora», pregava, «la pelle, né a difetto di carne ch’io abbia
Translate: He prayed, and didn't take care of the arid crackling that makes my skin pale, nor that I lack the flesh.

Original: ma dimmi il ver di te, dì chi son quelle due anime che là ti fanno scorta
Translate: but tell me the truth about you, and tell me who are those two souls that accompany you

Original: non rimaner che tu non mi favelle»
Translate: Don't stay here without talking to me.

Original: «La faccia tua, ch’io lagrimai già morta, mi dà di pianger mo non minor doglia», rispuos’ io lui, «veggendola sì torta
Translate: I answered him, "Your face, which wept when you were dead, now causes me to cry, giving me the same pain, for I see it so upset.

Original: Però mi dì, per Dio, che sì vi sfoglia
Translate: So tell me, in God's name, what makes you lose weight like this.

Original: non mi far dir mentr’ io mi maraviglio, ché mal può dir chi è pien d’altra voglia»
Translate: Do not force me to speak while I am amazed, for he who is full of another desire speaks ill-willed.

Original: Ed elli a me
Translate: And him to me

Original: «De l’etterno consiglio cade vertù ne l’acqua e ne la pianta rimasa dietro ond’ io sì m’assottiglio
Translate: From the divine will a virtue falls in the water and in the plant left behind, for which I lose weight in this way.

Original: Tutta esta gente che piangendo canta per seguitar la gola oltra misura, in fame e ’n sete qui si rifà santa
Translate: All these people who sing crying, for having given themselves to the pleasure of the throat, here expiate their guilt with hunger and thirst

Original: Di bere e di mangiar n’accende cura l’odor ch’esce del pomo e de lo sprazzo che si distende su per sua verdura
Translate: The fragrance that comes out of the fruit and the spring of water that goes up along the branches of the tree gives birth in us the desire to drink and eat

Original: E non pur una volta, questo spazzo girando, si rinfresca nostra pena
Translate: And our punishment is not renewed once, while we turn along the frame space.

Original: io dico pena, e dovria dir sollazzo, ché quella voglia a li alberi ci mena che menò Cristo lieto a dire ‘Elì’,
Translate: I say sorrow, and I should say joy, because we are led to the trees by the same desire that moved Christ, joyful, to say 'Eli',

Original: quando ne liberò con la sua vena»
Translate: when he delivered us, pouring out his own blood.

Original: E io a lui
Translate: And I to him

Original: «Forese, da quel dì nel qual mutasti mondo a miglior vita, cinqu’ anni non son vòlti infino a qui
Translate: "Forese, from the day you passed to better life five years have not yet passed

Original: Se prima fu la possa in te finita di peccar più, che sovvenisse l’ora del buon dolor ch’a Dio ne rimarita,
Translate: If the possibility of sin had already ceased in you before the hour of repentance, which reconciles us with God,

Original: come se’ tu qua sù venuto ancora? Io ti credea trovar là giù di sotto, dove tempo per tempo si ristora»
Translate: How did you get into this frame? I thought I'd find you down there, where you make up for lost time in the time of waiting.

Original: Ond’ elli a me
Translate: Then he answered me.

Original: «Sì tosto m’ha condotto a ber lo dolce assenzo d’i martìri la Nella mia con suo pianger dirotto
Translate: My wife Nella, with her broken cry, has led me to drink the sweet venom of the penis so quickly

Original: Con suoi prieghi devoti e con sospiri tratto m’ha de la costa ove s’aspetta, e liberato m’ha de li altri giri
Translate: With her godly prayers and her sighs, she brought me out of the slope where she awaits and freed me from the other frames.

Original: Tanto è a Dio più cara e più diletta la vedovella mia, che molto amai, quanto in bene operare è più soletta
Translate: My good widow, whom I loved very much, is all the more dear and pleasing to God, for she is now the only one to work righteously.

Original: ché la Barbagia di Sardigna assai ne le femmine sue più è pudica che la Barbagia dov’ io la lasciai
Translate: in fact the Barbagia of Sardinia has women much more morigerate than those of Barbagia where I left her

Original: O dolce frate, che vuo’ tu ch’io dica?
Translate: Or sweet brother, what do you want me to say?

Original: Tempo futuro m’è già nel cospetto,
Translate: I predict a future time,

Original: cui non sarà quest’ ora molto antica,
Translate: in respect of which the present will not be very ancient,

Original: nel qual sarà in pergamo interdetto a le sfacciate donne fiorentine l’andar mostrando con le poppe il petto
Translate: in which from the pulpit it will be forbidden to brazen Florentine women to wander around undiscovered breasts

Original: Quai barbare fuor mai, quai saracine, cui bisognasse, per farle ir coperte, o spiritali o altre discipline?
Translate: What barbarians, what Saracens were there ever for whom they were necessary, to make them go covered, penalties and sanctions of the Church or of the State?

Original: Ma se le svergognate fosser certe di quel che ’l ciel veloce loro ammanna, già per urlare avrian le bocche aperte
Translate: But if the shameless knew what Heaven was preparing for them, they would have opened their mouths to scream.

Original: ché, se l’antiveder qui non m’inganna, prima fien triste che le guance impeli colui che mo si consola con nanna
Translate: For if that which I see not deceive me, they shall be sad before the beard groweth upon the cheeks of him that is now comforted with the lullaby.

Original: Deh, frate, or fa che più non mi ti celi
Translate: Oh, brother, now don't move on from me.

Original: vedi che non pur io, ma questa gente tutta rimira là dove ’l sol veli»
Translate: You see that not only me, but all these souls are amazed that you project shadow.

Original: Per ch’io a lui
Translate: Then I told him

Original: «Se tu riduci a mente qual fosti meco, e qual io teco fui, ancor fia grave il memorar presente
Translate: If you think about the life we both led on Earth, the memory will be annoying even now

Original: Di quella vita mi volse costui che mi va innanzi, l’altr’ ier, quando tonda vi si mostrò la suora di colui», e ’l sol mostrai
Translate: And he brought me out of that life, which went before me a few days ago, when the sister of him was round about in heaven, and I shewed the sun.

Original: «costui per la profonda notte menato m’ha d’i veri morti con questa vera carne che ’l seconda
Translate: He led me through the deep night of the true dead, with this body of flesh and bones following him.

Original: Indi m’han tratto sù li suoi conforti, salendo e rigirando la montagna che drizza voi che ’l mondo fece torti
Translate: Then his comfort drew me up, going up and round about, for this mountain, which purifies you, whom the world has turned away.

Original: Tanto dice di farmi sua compagna che io sarò là dove fia Beatrice
Translate: He says to support me with his company as long as I'm there where Beatrice appears.

Original: quivi convien che sanza lui rimagna
Translate: Here it will be necessary for me to remain without him

Original: Virgilio è questi che così mi dice», e addita’lo
Translate: These who say so is Virgilio, and I indicated it

Original: «e quest’ altro è quell’ ombra per cuï scosse dianzi ogne pendice lo vostro regno, che da sé lo sgombra»
Translate: "And this is the soul for which your kingdom, which separates it from itself, shook every slope"

Original: Né ’l dir l’andar, né l’andar lui più lento facea, ma ragionando andavam forte, sì come nave pinta da buon vento
Translate: The words did not slow down the pace of Forese, nor did this slow down his words, but speaking we proceeded as a ship driven by a good wind.

Original: e l’ombre, che parean cose rimorte, per le fosse de li occhi ammirazione traean di me, di mio vivere accorte
Translate: And the souls, which looked like two dead creatures, looked at me with their eyes in the ground, seeing that I was alive.

Original: E io, continüando al mio sermone, dissi
Translate: And I, continuing my speech, said,

Original: «Ella sen va sù forse più tarda che non farebbe, per altrui cagione
Translate: That soul may rise more slowly than it had to because of Virgil

Original: Ma dimmi, se tu sai, dov’ è Piccarda
Translate: But tell me, if you know, where is Piccarda?

Original: dimmi s’io veggio da notar persona tra questa gente che sì mi riguarda»
Translate: tell me if I see among these souls that so look at me someone worthy to be noticed

Original: «La mia sorella, che tra bella e buona non so qual fosse più, trïunfa lieta ne l’alto Olimpo già di sua corona»

Original: Né solo a me la tua risposta è uopo
Translate: Your answer is not only necessary to me

Original: ché tutti questi n’hanno maggior sete che d’acqua fredda Indo o Etïopo
Translate: For all these penitents thirst more than the inhabitants of India or Ethiopia have cold water.

Original: Dinne com’ è che fai di te parete al sol, pur come tu non fossi ancora di morte intrato dentro da la rete»
Translate: Tell us how it is possible that you project a shadow, as if you had not yet entered the net of death.

Original: Sì mi parlava un d’essi
Translate: So one of the penitent spoke to me

Original: e io mi fora già manifesto, s’io non fossi atteso ad altra novità ch’apparve allora
Translate: and I would have already manifested myself, if I had not turned to another new thing that appeared at that very moment

Original: ché per lo mezzo del cammino acceso venne gente col viso incontro a questa, la qual mi fece a rimirar sospeso
Translate: For in the midst of the wall of fire came a host that turned its face toward it, which caused me to observe marvellous things.

Original: Lì veggio d’ogne parte farsi presta ciascun’ ombra e basciarsi una con una sanza restar, contente a brieve festa
Translate: There I saw every soul of both hosts hastening the step and kissing each other, without stopping, contented with that quick festive greeting

Original: così per entro loro schiera bruna s’ammusa l’una con l’altra formica, forse a spïar lor via e lor fortuna
Translate: So the ants, within their dark host, touch one another's snout, perhaps to ask for information about the way and the fruits of their work.

Original: Tosto che parton l’accoglienza amica, prima che ’l primo passo lì trascorra, sopragridar ciascuna s’affatica
Translate: As soon as those pleasant receptions were interrupted, even before the souls took a step away, each of them cried out as much as possible.

Original: la nova gente
Translate: the newcomers shouted

Original: «Soddoma e Gomorra»
Translate: Sodoma and Gomorra

Original: e l’altra
Translate: and others

Original: «Ne la vacca entra Pasife, perché ’l torello a sua lussuria corra»
Translate: "Pasiphae enters the wooden cow, because the bull runs to satisfy his lust"

Original: Poi, come grue ch’a le montagne Rife volasser parte, e parte inver’ l’arene, queste del gel, quelle del sole schife,
Translate: Then, as a crane that for absurd parted, flying some to the Rifugio mountains and the others to the deserts,

Original: l’una gente sen va, l’altra sen vene
Translate: one army goes away and the other goes in the opposite direction

Original: e tornan, lagrimando, a’ primi canti e al gridar che più lor si convene
Translate: And when they wept, they returned to what they sang before, and to the shouts which were best suited to them.

Original: e raccostansi a me, come davanti, essi medesmi che m’avean pregato, attenti ad ascoltar ne’ lor sembianti
Translate: And those penitents that prayed unto me came near unto me as before, be careful in their appearance to hearken unto me.

Original: Io, che due volte avea visto lor grato, incominciai
Translate: I, who had twice seen what they wanted, began

Original: «O anime sicure d’aver, quando che sia, di pace stato, non son rimase acerbe né mature le membra mie di là,
Translate: "O souls who are certain to obtain, when it will be, eternal peace, my members have not remained unwavering nor mature on Earth,

Original: ma son qui meco col sangue suo e con le sue giunture
Translate: But they are here with me, with their blood and their joints.

Original: Quinci sù vo per non esser più cieco
Translate: I'm going up from here so I won't be blind anymore.

Original: donna è di sopra che m’acquista grazia, per che ’l mortal per vostro mondo reco
Translate: There is a woman on it who gives me divine grace, so I carry my body through your world.

Original: Ma se la vostra maggior voglia sazia tosto divegna, sì che ’l ciel v’alberghi ch’è pien d’amore e più ampio si spazia,
Translate: However and may your strongest desire be satisfied as soon as possible, so that the heavens, full of infinite love, host you,

Original: ditemi, acciò ch’ancor carte ne verghi, chi siete voi, e chi è quella turba che se ne va di retro a’ vostri terghi»
Translate: Tell me, that I may write of it when I return into the world, who are you, and who is that army that goes behind your backs?

Original: Non altrimenti stupido si turba lo montanaro, e rimirando ammuta, quando rozzo e salvatico s’inurba, che ciascun’ ombra fece in sua paruta
Translate: The mountaineer, when he goes to the rough and wild city and admires the silence, is not amazed and amazed in a different way from how he did each of those souls in his own appearance

Original: ma poi che furon di stupore scarche, lo qual ne li alti cuor tosto s’attuta,
Translate: but after they had left the astonishment, that in the noble hearts it subsided in haste,

Original: «Beato te, che de le nostre marche», ricominciò colei che pria m’inchiese, «per morir meglio, esperïenza imbarche
Translate: "Blessed are you, who, in order to better die, acquires the experience of our world," said the soul who had previously asked me his question.

Original: La gente che non vien con noi, offese di ciò per che già Cesar, trïunfando, “Regina” contra sé chiamar s’intese
Translate: The army that did not come with us committed the same sin that Caesar, during the triumph, felt the name of 'Queen'

Original: però si parton “Soddoma” gridando, rimproverando a sé com’ hai udito, e aiutan l’arsura vergognando
Translate: That is why they are crying out, 'Sodom', rebuking himself as you have heard, and increasing the punishment of fire with shame.

Original: Nostro peccato fu ermafrodito
Translate: Our sin was heterosexual in nature

Original: ma perché non servammo umana legge, seguendo come bestie l’appetito,
Translate: But because we did not observe the human law, following as beasts the appetite of the senses,

Original: in obbrobrio di noi, per noi si legge, quando partinci, il nome di colei che s’imbestiò ne le ’mbestiate schegge
Translate: For our shame when we separate, we cry out the name of her who became a beast in the false wooden cow.

Original: Or sai nostri atti e di che fummo rei
Translate: Now you know our conduct and what we were guilty of.

Original: se forse a nome vuo’ saper chi semo, tempo non è di dire, e non saprei
Translate: If you want to know the names of all of us, there's no time to tell you, and I don't know how to tell you.

Original: Farotti ben di me volere scemo
Translate: I will only grant such a desire for myself.

Original: son Guido Guinizzelli, e già mi purgo per ben dolermi prima ch’a lo stremo»
Translate: I'm Guido Guinizelli, and I'm already getting paid for repenting before the end of my life.

Original: Quali ne la tristizia di Ligurgo si fer due figli a riveder la madre, tal mi fec’ io,
Translate: As the two sons, because of the cruelty of the tyrant Liburgo, approached to see his mother again, so I found myself,

Original: ma non a tanto insurgo, quand’ io odo nomar sé stesso il padre mio e de li altri miei miglior che mai rime d’amore usar dolci e leggiadre
Translate: But I didn't dare so much, when I heard my father and other poets present themselves better than me that they never wrote verses of sweet and graceful love.

Original: e sanza udire e dir pensoso andai lunga fïata rimirando lui, né, per lo foco, in là più m’appressai
Translate: And for a long time I walked, and looked with admiration, and said nothing, and heard nothing, and dared not come near more for fear of fire.

Original: Poi che di riguardar pasciuto fui, tutto m’offersi pronto al suo servigio con l’affermar che fa credere altrui
Translate: After I was satisfied that I had observed him, I offered myself everything ready for his service, with an oath that impels people to believe the words

Original: Ed elli a me
Translate: And him to me

Original: «Tu lasci tal vestigio, per quel ch’i’ odo, in me, e tanto chiaro, che Letè nol può tòrre né far bigio
Translate: You leave in me such a remembrance, for what I hear, and so bright, that the Lete cannot erase it or fade it.

Original: Ma se le tue parole or ver giuraro, dimmi che è cagion per che dimostri nel dire e nel guardar d’avermi caro»
Translate: But if your words swear the truth a moment ago, tell me why do you show that you loved me in speaking and looking at me?

Original: E io a lui
Translate: And I to him

Original: «Li dolci detti vostri, che, quanto durerà l’uso moderno, faranno cari ancora i loro incostri»
Translate: "The reason is your sweet verses, which, as long as you use the vulgar, will always make precious the manuscripts that keep them"

Original: «O frate», disse, «questi ch’io ti cerno col dito»,
Translate: He said, "O brother, this one that I point out to you with his finger."

Original: e additò un spirto innanzi,
Translate: and showed a spirit before him,

Original: «fu miglior fabbro del parlar materno
Translate: he was a better maker of his mother vernacular

Original: Versi d’amore e prose di romanzi soverchiò tutti
Translate: He surpassed everyone in the field of Occitan love poetry and Oitanic narrative literature

Original: e lascia dir li stolti che quel di Lemosì credon ch’avanzi
Translate: And let the fools speak, who believe he is overcome by the Limousin.

Original: A voce più ch’al ver drizzan li volti, e così ferman sua oppinïone prima ch’arte o ragion per lor s’ascolti
Translate: They look up to the voices rather than to the truth, and thus form their opinion before listening to art or reasonableness

Original: Così fer molti antichi di Guittone, di grido in grido pur lui dando pregio, fin che l’ha vinto il ver con più persone
Translate: So many ancients did with Guitton, appreciating him to listen to the voices, until the truth passed through the work of many writers.

Original: Or se tu hai sì ampio privilegio, che licito ti sia l’andare al chiostro nel quale è Cristo abate del collegio,
Translate: Now, if you have the exceptional privilege of being able to go to the cloister where Christ is the abbot of the college,

Original: falli per me un dir d’un paternostro, quanto bisogna a noi di questo mondo, dove poter peccar non è più nostro»
Translate: recite before him for me a 'our father', at least as much as is necessary to us in Purgatory, where we no longer have the power to sin"

Original: Poi, forse per dar luogo altrui secondo che presso avea, disparve per lo foco, come per l’acqua il pesce andando al fondo
Translate: Then, perhaps to give way to those who stood by him, he disappeared into the fire like a fish in the water, when it goes to the bottom

Original: Io mi fei al mostrato innanzi un poco, e dissi ch’al suo nome il mio disire apparecchiava grazïoso loco
Translate: I came a little closer to the spirit he had indicated before, and I said that my desire prepared a welcome for his name.

Original: El cominciò liberamente a dire
Translate: He gladly began to say

Original: «Tan m’abellis vostre cortes deman, qu’ieu no me puesc ni voill a vos cobrire
Translate: "Your kind question pleases me so much, that I cannot and do not want to hide my identity

Original: Ieu sui Arnaut, que plor e vau cantan
Translate: I am Arnaut, crying and going singing

Original: consiros vei la passada folor, e vei jausen lo joi qu’esper, denan
Translate: I look at my past madness of love, and I see joy, which I hope, before me.

Original: Ara vos prec, per aquella valor que vos guida al som de l’escalina, sovenha vos a temps de ma dolor»
Translate: Now I beseech you, by that virtue which leads you to the top of this ladder, to remind you at the opportune moment of my sorrow.

Original: Poi s’ascose nel foco che li affina
Translate: Then he hid himself in the fire that purifies them.

Original: Sì come quando i primi raggi vibra là dove il suo fattor lo sangue sparse, cadendo Ibero sotto l’alta Libra,
Translate: The sun was in that position where it is when its first rays vibrate where its Creator was killed, while the Hebrew is under the constellation of Libra,

Original: e l’onde in Gange da nona rïarse, sì stava il sole
Translate: And the waves of the Ganges are burned from the south.

Original: onde ’l giorno sen giva, come l’angel di Dio lieto ci apparse
Translate: So the day was coming to an end, when the angel of God appeared to us gladly.

Original: Fuor de la fiamma stava in su la riva, e cantava ‘Beati mundo corde’
Translate: He stood on the edge of the frame, out of the flame, and sang 'Blessed are the pure of heart',

Original: in voce assai più che la nostra viva
Translate: with a much more intense voice than ours

Original: Poscia «Più non si va, se pria non morde, anime sante, il foco
Translate: Then, O holy souls, let no higher progress be made unless first the fire burns there.

Original: intrate in esso, e al cantar di là non siate sorde»,
Translate: enter into it and pay attention to the song that you will hear from the other side.

Original: ci disse come noi li fummo presso
Translate: He told us as soon as we got closer.

Original: per ch’io divenni tal, quando lo ’ntesi, qual è colui che ne la fossa è messo
Translate: Then, when I heard it, I became such as he who was put in the pit.

Original: In su le man commesse mi protesi, guardando il foco e imaginando forte umani corpi già veduti accesi
Translate: I prostrate my hands forward, looking at the fire and thinking with terror of human bodies that I saw already burned

Original: Volsersi verso me le buone scorte
Translate: Good guides turned to me

Original: e Virgilio mi disse
Translate: And Virgil said unto me,

Original: «Figliuol mio, qui può esser tormento, ma non morte
Translate: My son, here there may be torments, but not death

Original: Ricorditi, ricorditi
Translate: Remember, remember.

Original: E se io sovresso Gerïon ti guidai salvo, che farò ora presso più a Dio?
Translate: And if I guided you safely on the back of Gerion, what will I do now that I am closer to God?

Original: Credi per certo che se dentro a l’alvo di questa fiamma stessi ben mille anni, non ti potrebbe far d’un capel calvo
Translate: Do not doubt that, even if you were within these flames for a thousand years, they could not make you fall even a hair

Original: E se tu forse credi ch’io t’inganni, fatti ver’ lei, e fatti far credenza con le tue mani al lembo d’i tuoi panni
Translate: And if thou believest that I will deceive thee, come near to the fire, and make sure it is near to it a flap of thy garment.

Original: Pon giù omai, pon giù ogne temenza
Translate: Come on, lay down all your fear.

Original: volgiti in qua e vieni
Translate: Turn around this way and come,

Original: entra sicuro»
Translate: come in safe

Original: E io pur fermo e contra coscïenza
Translate: And I stood still, deaf to every call

Original: Quando mi vide star pur fermo e duro, turbato un poco disse
Translate: When he saw that I was not persuaded at any cost, a little upset he told me

Original: «Or vedi, figlio
Translate: Now think, son.

Original: tra Bëatrice e te è questo muro»
Translate: This wall divides you from Beatrice.

Original: Come al nome di Tisbe aperse il ciglio Piramo in su la morte, e riguardolla, allor che ’l gelso diventò vermiglio
Translate: Like Piram, in the name of Tisbe, he opened his eyes at the point of death and looked at it, when the mulberry became red,

Original: così, la mia durezza fatta solla, mi volsi al savio duca, udendo il nome che ne la mente sempre mi rampolla
Translate: So, after my hardness was eased, I turned to the wise teacher, hearing the name that is always present in my mind.

Original: Ond’ ei crollò la fronte e disse
Translate: Then he shook his head and said,

Original: «Come volenci star di qua?»
Translate: How do we want to stay here?

Original: indi sorrise come al fanciul si fa ch’è vinto al pome
Translate: So he smiled, as with a child won by the promise of a fruit.

Original: Poi dentro al foco innanzi mi si mise, pregando Stazio che venisse retro, che pria per lunga strada ci divise
Translate: Then he put himself in the fire, begging Statius to follow me, and before that he had stood against us for a long time.

Original: Sì com’ fui dentro, in un bogliente vetro gittato mi sarei per rinfrescarmi, tant’ era ivi lo ’ncendio sanza metro
Translate: As soon as I was inside, I would throw myself in a glowing glass to cool me down, so the heat there was unmatched

Original: Lo dolce padre mio, per confortarmi, pur di Beatrice ragionando andava, dicendo
Translate: My sweet father, to comfort me, was always talking about Beatrice, saying,

Original: «Li occhi suoi già veder parmi»
Translate: I think I can see his eyes already.

Original: Guidavaci una voce che cantava di là
Translate: We were led by a voice singing on the other side

Original: e noi, attenti pur a lei, venimmo fuor là ove si montava
Translate: and we, always attentive to it, came out of the flames where we went up.

Original: ‘Venite, benedicti Patris mei’,
Translate: 'Come, blessed of my Father'

Original: sonò dentro a un lume che lì era, tal che mi vinse e guardar nol potei
Translate: A voice resonated in a light that was there, so vivid that I couldn't look at it

Original: «Lo sol sen va», soggiunse, «e vien la sera
Translate: And the sun went away, and the night came.

Original: non v’arrestate, ma studiate il passo, mentre che l’occidente non si annera»
Translate: Don't stop, but hurry up until the west is completely darkened.

Original: Dritta salia la via per entro ’l sasso verso tal parte ch’io toglieva i raggi dinanzi a me del sol ch’era già basso
Translate: The way dug into the rock went straight up to the east, so that I interrupted before me the rays of the sun by now descending.

Original: E di pochi scaglion levammo i saggi, che ’l sol corcar, per l’ombra che si spense, sentimmo dietro e io e li miei saggi
Translate: And We made time to climb a few steps, when my guides and I realized that the sun had set because my shadow was gone.

Original: E pria che ’n tutte le sue parti immense fosse orizzonte fatto d’uno aspetto,
Translate: And before the horizon took on a single aspect in all its immense parts,

Original: e notte avesse tutte sue dispense, ciascun di noi d’un grado fece letto
Translate: And that the night had darkened all the lands, every one of us made a bed of one step.

Original: ché la natura del monte ci affranse la possa del salir più e ’l diletto
Translate: For the nature of the mountain extinguished us the ability and joy to ascend beyond

Original: Quali si stanno ruminando manse le capre, state rapide e proterve sovra le cime avante che sien pranse, tacite a l’ombra,
Translate: Like goats, after being swift and rebellious over the peaks before eating, they are meek and silent to ruminate in the shade,

Original: mentre che ’l sol ferve, guardate dal pastor, che ’n su la verga poggiato s’è e lor di posa serve
Translate: while the sun beats, guarded by the shepherd who leaned on the staff, and gave them rest.

Original: e quale il mandrïan che fori alberga, lungo il pecuglio suo queto pernotta, guardando perché fiera non lo sperga
Translate: And as the herd that spends the night outside and sleeps beside his quiet cattle, watching that no beast scatters it.

Original: tali eravamo tutti e tre allotta, io come capra, ed ei come pastori, fasciati quinci e quindi d’alta grotta
Translate: So we were all three then, I like the goat, and they like the shepherds, wrapped on both sides by the high rock.

Original: Poco parer potea lì del di fori
Translate: From there you could see little of what was outside,

Original: ma, per quel poco, vedea io le stelle di lor solere e più chiare e maggiori
Translate: but in any case I saw the stars bigger and brighter than usual

Original: Sì ruminando e sì mirando in quelle, mi prese il sonno
Translate: As I was reflecting and observing the stars, I was caught in sleep,

Original: il sonno che sovente, anzi che ’l fatto sia, sa le novelle
Translate: the sleep that is often the bringer of truthful prophecies

Original: Ne l’ora, credo, che de l’orïente prima raggiò nel monte Citerea, che di foco d’amor par sempre ardente,
Translate: In the hour, I think, when morning Venus appeared from the east on the mountain,

Original: giovane e bella in sogno mi parea donna vedere andar per una landa cogliendo fiori
Translate: I seemed to see in my dream a young and beautiful woman walking in a plain, capturing flowers

Original: e cantando dicea
Translate: And singing said,

Original: «Sappia qualunque il mio nome dimanda ch’i’ mi son Lia, e vo movendo intorno le belle mani a farmi una ghirlanda
Translate: "Whoever asks for my name, know that I am Leah, and I am moving around my beautiful hands to make a garland for myself."

Original: Per piacermi a lo specchio, qui m’addorno
Translate: Here I make myself beautiful to admire myself in the mirror

Original: ma mia suora Rachel mai non si smaga dal suo miraglio, e siede tutto giorno
Translate: My sister Rachel, on the other hand, never gets tired of mirroring and sits all day.

Original: Ell’ è d’i suoi belli occhi veder vaga com’ io de l’addornarmi con le mani
Translate: She is eager to see her beautiful eyes, as much as I am to gloat myself with my hands.

Original: lei lo vedere, e me l’ovrare appaga»
Translate: She's satisfied with the look, I'm satisfied with the operation.

Original: E già per li splendori antelucani, che tanto a’ pellegrin surgon più grati,
Translate: And now the darkness was dissolved from all sides by the first lights of the dawn,

Original: quanto, tornando, albergan men lontani, le tenebre fuggian da tutti lati,
Translate: who rise all the more pleasing to the travelers as, during the return, they are close to home

Original: e ’l sonno mio con esse
Translate: And my sleep went away with them,

Original: ond’ io leva’mi, veggendo i gran maestri già levati
Translate: So I stood up, seeing the great masters already standing.

Original: «Quel dolce pome che per tanti rami cercando va la cura de’ mortali, oggi porrà in pace le tue fami»
Translate: "That sweet fruit which the affliction of mortals is seeking for many branches, today shall satisfy all your desires."

Original: Virgilio inverso me queste cotali parole usò
Translate: Virgil addressed these words to me

Original: e mai non furo strenne che fosser di piacere a queste iguali
Translate: and there were never glad tidings that would give more joy than these

Original: Tanto voler sopra voler mi venne de l’esser sù, ch’ad ogne passo poi al volo mi sentia crescer le penne
Translate: It took me such a desire to be high, in addition to what I had, that at every step I felt the feathers growing.

Original: Come la scala tutta sotto noi fu corsa e fummo in su ’l grado superno, in me ficcò Virgilio li occhi suoi, e disse
Translate: As soon as we were at the top of the ladder and arrived on the last step, Virgil looked intently at me, saying,

Original: «Il temporal foco e l’etterno veduto hai, figlio
Translate: Son, you have seen eternal and temporary punishments,

Original: e se’ venuto in parte dov’ io per me più oltre non discerno
Translate: And thou hast come to a place from which I cannot see any more with my own strength.

Original: Tratto t’ho qui con ingegno e con arte
Translate: I brought you here with those devices that I found with reason.

Original: lo tuo piacere omai prendi per duce
Translate: now follow as your guide your pleasure

Original: fuor se’ de l’erte vie, fuor se’ de l’arte
Translate: you are out of the steep and narrow streets

Original: Vedi lo sol che ’n fronte ti riluce
Translate: See the sun shining in your forehead

Original: vedi l’erbette, i fiori e li arbuscelli che qui la terra sol da sé produce
Translate: See the grass, the flowers, and the tender shrubs that the earth produces spontaneously here.

Original: Mentre che vegnan lieti li occhi belli che, lagrimando, a te venir mi fenno, seder ti puoi e puoi andar tra elli
Translate: Until the beautiful eyes come to you, which weeped, and moved me to help you, you can sit down and walk among them.

Original: Non aspettar mio dir più né mio cenno
Translate: Don't wait any longer for my word or nod

Original: libero, dritto e sano è tuo arbitrio, e fallo fora non fare a suo senno
Translate: your will is free from sin, just and healthy, so it would be a mistake not to act on it

Original: per ch’io te sovra te corono e mitrio»
Translate: Therefore, I crown thee lord of thyself.

Original: Vago già di cercar dentro e dintorno la divina foresta spessa e viva,
Translate: Wanted to explore inside and all around the divine forest, thick and luxuriant,

Original: ch’a li occhi temperava il novo giorno, sanza più aspettar, lasciai la riva,
Translate: that sharpened to the eyes the rays of the sun just risen, without waiting beyond I left the rocky margin

Original: prendendo la campagna lento lento su per lo suol che d’ogne parte auliva
Translate: I went slowly into the vegetation, on the ground that sent sweet scents from every side.

Original: Un’aura dolce, sanza mutamento avere in sé, mi feria per la fronte non di più colpo che soave vento
Translate: A gentle and regular breeze struck my forehead, no stronger than a gentle wind

Original: per cui le fronde, tremolando, pronte tutte quante piegavano a la parte u’ la prim’ ombra gitta il santo monte
Translate: Because of it the branches trembled, and all bowed to the part wherein the holy mountain cast forth the first shadow.

Original: non però dal loro esser dritto sparte tanto, che li augelletti per le cime lasciasser d’operare ogne lor arte
Translate: But they bowed not so much that the little birds, on the branches, ceased to use all their art.

Original: ma con piena letizia l’ore prime, cantando, ricevieno intra le foglie,
Translate: but with full joy, singing, they welcomed the first hours of the day among the leaves,

Original: che tenevan bordone a le sue rime, tal qual di ramo in ramo si raccoglie per la pineta in su ’l lito di Chiassi,
Translate: who accompanied their songs, just as it happens from branch to branch in the pine forest on the Class Lido,

Original: quand’ Ëolo scilocco fuor discioglie
Translate: when Eolo melts the wind of sirocco

Original: Già m’avean trasportato i lenti passi dentro a la selva antica tanto, ch’io non potea rivedere ond’ io mi ’ntrassi
Translate: By now the slow steps had carried me into the ancient forest to the point that I could no longer see where I had entered.

Original: ed ecco più andar mi tolse un rio, che ’nver’ sinistra con sue picciole onde piegava l’erba che ’n sua ripa uscìo
Translate: And behold, he kept me from going beyond a little stream, which with its small waves bent to the left the grass that was growing on its shore.

Original: Tutte l’acque che son di qua più monde, parrieno avere in sé mistura alcuna verso di quella,
Translate: All the waters on Earth that are purer, would seem subtle and muddy compared to that,

Original: che nulla nasconde,
Translate: that doesn't hide anything,

Original: avvegna che si mova bruna bruna sotto l’ombra perpetüa, che mai raggiar non lascia sole ivi né luna
Translate: even if it flows dark under that perpetual shadow, which never lets the rays of the sun or moon filter

Original: Coi piè ristetti e con li occhi passai di là dal fiumicello, per mirare la gran varïazion d’i freschi mai
Translate: And I stopped the way, and looked beyond the stream, to see the great variety of the blossoming branches.

Original: e là m’apparve, sì com’ elli appare subitamente cosa che disvia per maraviglia tutto altro pensare,
Translate: And there appeared unto me, as a thing suddenly appeared, which, arousing wonder, turned away from every other thought,

Original: una donna soletta che si gia e cantando e scegliendo fior da fiore ond’ era pinta tutta la sua via
Translate: A woman who went away all alone, and as she sang, she caught the flowers of her way.

Original: «Deh, bella donna, che a’ raggi d’amore ti scaldi, s’i’ vo’ credere a’ sembianti che soglion esser testimon del core,
Translate: "Orsu, beautiful woman, who is warmed up by love, if I want to believe the aspect that is usually a faithful mirror of feelings,

Original: vegnati in voglia di trarreti avanti», diss’ io a lei, «verso questa rivera, tanto ch’io possa intender che tu canti
Translate: Have the complacency to step a little further towards this river, so that I can understand what you're singing.

Original: Tu mi fai rimembrar dove e qual era Proserpina nel tempo che perdette la madre lei, ed ella primavera»
Translate: You remind me of where she was, and how Proserpina was, when her mother lost her, and she lost her eternal spring.

Original: Come si volge, con le piante strette a terra e intra sé, donna che balli, e piede innanzi piede a pena mette,
Translate: How a woman who dances flies, with her feet on the ground and between them, and barely puts one foot in front of the other,

Original: volsesi in su i vermigli e in su i gialli fioretti verso me, non altrimenti che vergine che li occhi onesti avvalli
Translate: So she turned to me on the red and yellow flowers, not unlike a virgin who lowered her dignified eyes.

Original: e fece i prieghi miei esser contenti, sì appressando sé, che ’l dolce suono veniva a me co’ suoi intendimenti
Translate: And he answered my prayers, and came to the point that the sweet sound of his song was heard and understood by me.

Original: Tosto che fu là dove l’erbe sono bagnate già da l’onde del bel fiume, di levar li occhi suoi mi fece dono
Translate: As soon as he was there where the herbs were bathed by the waters of the beautiful river, he gave me the gift to lift up his eyes.

Original: Non credo che splendesse tanto lume sotto le ciglia a Venere, trafitta dal figlio fuor di tutto suo costume
Translate: I don't think under the eyelashes of Venus, pierced by his son Cupid unintentionally, he shone such a light of love

Original: Ella ridea da l’altra riva dritta, trattando più color con le sue mani, che l’alta terra sanza seme gitta
Translate: She laughed standing on the other side, intertwining with her hands more colorful flowers, which that high earth produces without seed

Original: Tre passi ci facea il fiume lontani
Translate: The river separated us by no more than three steps

Original: ma Elesponto, là ’ve passò Serse, ancora freno a tutti orgogli umani,
Translate: but the Hellesponth, where Xerxes passed, whose example is still admonition for every human pride,

Original: più odio da Leandro non sofferse per mareggiare intra Sesto e Abido, che quel da me perch’ allor non s’aperse
Translate: He was no longer hated by Leander because of his tidal waves between the cities of Sesto and Abido, compared to that river because he did not let me pass.

Original: «Voi siete nuovi, e forse perch’ io rido»,
Translate: "You have just arrived, and perhaps for me to laugh

Original: cominciò ella,
Translate: she began,

Original: «in questo luogo eletto a l’umana natura per suo nido, maravigliando tienvi alcun sospetto
Translate: in this place which was chosen as a nest for the human species, you are amazed.

Original: ma luce rende il salmo Delectasti, che puote disnebbiar vostro intelletto
Translate: but the Psalm 'Deletasts' provides the explanation that can dissipate all your doubts

Original: E tu che se’ dinanzi e mi pregasti, dì s’altro vuoli udir
Translate: And you who are in front of me and prayed to me, tell me if you want to know anything else.

Original: ch’i’ venni presta ad ogne tua question tanto che basti»
Translate: For I have come here to answer every question of yours, that is enough.

Original: «L’acqua», diss’ io, «e ’l suon de la foresta impugnan dentro a me novella fede di cosa ch’io udi’ contraria a questa»
Translate: I said "The water and the storm of the forest contrast in my thought with something I have heard"

Original: Ond’ ella
Translate: Then you

Original: «Io dicerò come procede per sua cagion ciò ch’ammirar ti face, e purgherò la nebbia che ti fiede
Translate: "I will tell you what is the cause of your astonishment, and I will clear the fog that clouds your intellect.

Original: Lo sommo Ben, che solo esso a sé piace, fé l’uom buono e a bene, e questo loco diede per arr’ a lui d’etterna pace
Translate: The high good, which is pleasing only to himself, created the good man and disposed for good, and gave this place to him as a deposit of eternal peace.

Original: Per sua difalta qui dimorò poco
Translate: For his sin he stayed here little time

Original: per sua difalta in pianto e in affanno cambiò onesto riso e dolce gioco
Translate: for his sin turned his joy and happiness into weeping and distressing

Original: Perché ’l turbar che sotto da sé fanno l’essalazion de l’acqua e de la terra,
Translate: So that the perturbations that are produced on Earth by the steam of water and soil,

Original: che quanto posson dietro al calor vanno, a l’uomo non facesse alcuna guerra, questo monte salìo verso ’l ciel tanto,
Translate: who follow the heat as far as they can, did not bother man, this mountain ascended to heaven so far,

Original: e libero n’è d’indi ove si serra
Translate: and it is immune from atmospheric events from here to the door of Purgatory

Original: Or perché in circuito tutto quanto l’aere si volge con la prima volta, se non li è rotto il cerchio d’alcun canto,
Translate: Now, since all the air moves in a circle with the Primo Mobile, unless the celestial movement is interrupted somewhere,

Original: in questa altezza ch’è tutta disciolta ne l’aere vivo, tal moto percuote, e fa sonar la selva perch’ è folta
Translate: this movement of the air hits the top of the mountain that is all free in the moving air, and makes the forest that is full of fronds stumble

Original: e la percossa pianta tanto puote, che de la sua virtute l’aura impregna e quella poi, girando, intorno scuote
Translate: and the plant hit by the wind has such power that it immerses the air of its generative virtue, and the air, turning, then spreads it all around

Original: e l’altra terra, secondo ch’è degna per sé e per suo ciel, concepe e figlia di diverse virtù diverse legna
Translate: and the Earth populated by men, depending on its fertility and climate, conceives and produces different plants from different virtues

Original: Non parrebbe di là poi maraviglia, udito questo, quando alcuna pianta sanza seme palese vi s’appiglia
Translate: Upon hearing this, one should not be surprised on Earth when a plant appears to be born without being sown

Original: E saper dei che la campagna santa dove tu se’, d’ogne semenza è piena, e frutto ha in sé che di là non si schianta
Translate: And you must know that the sacred wood where you are is full of every seed, and it has in it fruits that do not grow in the world

Original: L’acqua che vedi non surge di vena che ristori vapor che gel converta, come fiume ch’acquista e perde lena
Translate: The water you see does not flow from a source that is fed by vapours that the frost transforms into rain, like a river that loses and acquires flow

Original: ma esce di fontana salda e certa, che tanto dal voler di Dio riprende, quant’ ella versa da due parti aperta
Translate: but comes out of a firm and sure source, which receives from the will of God what it then pours out from two parts

Original: Da questa parte con virtù discende che toglie altrui memoria del peccato
Translate: On this side descends with the virtue of taking away the memory of sin

Original: da l’altra d’ogne ben fatto la rende
Translate: on the other with the virtue of strengthening the memory of every good action

Original: Quinci Letè
Translate: It's called Lete from here.

Original: così da l’altro lato Eünoè si chiama, e non adopra se quinci e quindi pria non è gustato
Translate: On the other side is called Eunoah, and it does not act if you do not drink this water first and then the other

Original: a tutti altri sapori esto è di sopra
Translate: this taste is superior to any other

Original: E avvegna ch’assai possa esser sazia la sete tua perch’ io più non ti scuopra, darotti un corollario ancor per grazia
Translate: And even though your curiosity can be satisfied without me adding anything else, by my grace I will give again a corollary

Original: né credo che ’l mio dir ti sia men caro, se oltre promession teco si spazia
Translate: And I don't think that my words will be less pleasing to you if they go beyond what I promised you.

Original: Quelli ch’anticamente poetaro l’età de l’oro e suo stato felice, forse in Parnaso esto loco sognaro
Translate: Those who in ancient times wrote verses about the golden age and its happy state, perhaps dreamed of this very place in Parnasus

Original: Qui fu innocente l’umana radice
Translate: Here the first men were innocent

Original: qui primavera sempre e ogne frutto
Translate: Here reigns an eternal spring and every fruit

Original: nettare è questo di che ciascun dice»
Translate: The water of this river is the nectar of which each of them speaks.

Original: Io mi rivolsi ’n dietro allora tutto a’ miei poeti, e vidi che con riso udito avëan l’ultimo costrutto
Translate: Then I turned to Virgil and Statius, and saw that they had heard these last words smiling.

Original: poi a la bella donna torna’ il viso
Translate: Then I went back to look at the beautiful woman

Original: Cantando come donna innamorata, continüò col fin di sue parole
Translate: Singing like a woman in love, he continued his words saying,

Original: ‘Beati quorum tecta sunt peccata’
Translate: Blessed are those whose sins have been covered with forgiveness.

Original: E come ninfe che si givan sole per le salvatiche ombre, disïando qual di veder, qual di fuggir lo sole,
Translate: And as the nymphs wandered alone among the shadows of the woods, some desiring to see the sun and others to escape it,

Original: allor si mosse contra ’l fiume, andando su per la riva
Translate: Then the woman began to go up the river, by the shore.

Original: e io pari di lei, picciol passo con picciol seguitando
Translate: and I followed her, adapting my step to hers, slower

Original: Non eran cento tra ’ suoi passi e ’ miei, quando le ripe igualmente dier volta, per modo ch’a levante mi rendei
Translate: We had not yet taken a hundred steps in two, when the river flowed toward the east, and I followed its course.

Original: Né ancor fu così nostra via molta, quando la donna tutta a me si torse, dicendo
Translate: Even in this direction we did not go far, when the woman turned to me and said,

Original: «Frate mio, guarda e ascolta»
Translate: My brother, look and listen.

Original: Ed ecco un lustro sùbito trascorse da tutte parti per la gran foresta, tal che di balenar mi mise in forse
Translate: And behold, a sudden glow went through the forest from all sides, so that I doubted it was a lightning.

Original: Ma perché ’l balenar, come vien, resta, e quel, durando, più e più splendeva, nel mio pensier dicea
Translate: But for the lightning ceased as soon as it came, while it persisted and became more and more shining, between me and me I said,

Original: ‘Che cosa è questa?’
Translate: What can it be?

Original: E una melodia dolce correva per l’aere luminoso
Translate: And a sweet melody spread in the bright air

Original: onde buon zelo mi fé riprender l’ardimento d’Eva, che là dove ubidia la terra e ’l cielo,
Translate: Then a righteous zeal led me to rebuke the pride of Eve, who, though the earth and heaven obeyed her,

Original: femmina, sola e pur testé formata, non sofferse di star sotto alcun velo
Translate: Though she was the only woman who was just created, I would not tolerate any limit to one's knowledge.

Original: sotto ’l qual se divota fosse stata, avrei quelle ineffabili delizie sentite prima e più lunga fïata
Translate: And if he had respected that limit, devout, I would have tasted those unspeakable delights before, and for a longer time.

Original: Mentr’ io m’andava tra tante primizie de l’etterno piacer tutto sospeso,
Translate: As I proceeded with the soul of so many anticipations of the heavenly beauties,

Original: e disïoso ancora a più letizie, dinanzi a noi, tal quale un foco acceso, ci si fé l’aere sotto i verdi rami
Translate: And desirous of other joys, the air was made before us a red color as the fire, under the green branches.

Original: e ’l dolce suon per canti era già inteso
Translate: and that sweet sound was now like a song

Original: O sacrosante Vergini, se fami, freddi o vigilie mai per voi soffersi, cagion mi sprona ch’io mercé vi chiami
Translate: O holy Muse, if I have ever suffered for you fasts, colds or vigils, now a reason motivates me to ask you for a reward for this

Original: Or convien che Elicona per me versi, e Uranìe m’aiuti col suo coro forti cose a pensar mettere in versi
Translate: Now it is necessary that the Helicona pours poetic inspiration for me, and that Urania helps me with the compañeras to put in verses difficult things even just to think

Original: Poco più oltre, sette alberi d’oro falsava nel parere il lungo tratto del mezzo ch’era ancor tra noi e loro
Translate: Not far away, the long stretch of the air that was still between us and them, made me think I saw seven golden trees.

Original: ma quand’ i’ fui sì presso di lor fatto, che l’obietto comun, che ’l senso inganna,
Translate: but when I was approached more, to the point that the object of perception, which can deceive the senses,

Original: non perdea per distanza alcun suo atto, la virtù ch’a ragion discorso ammanna, sì com’ elli eran candelabri apprese,
Translate: He did not lose any of his qualities for the distance, the virtue that gives the elements of judgment to reason recognized them as candlesticks,

Original: e ne le voci del cantare ‘Osanna’
Translate: and in the voices heard the song 'Hosanna'

Original: Di sopra fiammeggiava il bello arnese più chiaro assai che luna per sereno di mezza notte nel suo mezzo mese
Translate: The beautiful set of candlesticks flaming upwards, making a light more intense than that of the moon at midnight, when it is full

Original: Io mi rivolsi d’ammirazion pieno al buon Virgilio, ed esso mi rispuose con vista carca di stupor non meno
Translate: I turned with wonder to the good Virgil, and he answered me with a look no less full of wonder.

Original: Indi rendei l’aspetto a l’alte cose che si movieno incontr’ a noi sì tardi, che foran vinte da novelle spose
Translate: Then I looked back at those lofty things that were moving toward us, so slowly that they would be won by newlyweds.

Original: La donna mi sgridò
Translate: The woman yelled at me

Original: «Perché pur ardi sì ne l’affetto de le vive luci, e ciò che vien di retro a lor non guardi?»
Translate: "Why do you only look at the lampstands, full of love, and look at what comes after them?"

Original: Genti vid’ io allor, come a lor duci, venire appresso, vestite di bianco
Translate: Then I saw characters following them, as if they were their guides, dressed in white.

Original: e tal candor di qua già mai non fuci
Translate: and such a whiteness was never on Earth

Original: L’acqua imprendëa dal sinistro fianco, e rendea me la mia sinistra costa, s’io riguardava in lei, come specchio anco
Translate: The water of Lete shone on my left hand, and reflected my left side like a mirror, if I looked in it.

Original: Quand’ io da la mia riva ebbi tal posta, che solo il fiume mi facea distante, per veder meglio ai passi diedi sosta,
Translate: When I was by the shore, so much so that only the river separated me from those objects, to see better I stopped the passage,

Original: e vidi le fiammelle andar davante, lasciando dietro a sé l’aere dipinto, e di tratti pennelli avean sembiante
Translate: And I saw the flames go on and leave behind the painted air, and those bright stripes looked like brush strokes.

Original: sì che lì sopra rimanea distinto di sette liste, tutte in quei colori onde fa l’arco il Sole e Delia il cinto
Translate: So that above the candlesticks the air was divided into seven stripes, all of those colors that the Sun produces in the rainbow and the Moon in its halo.

Original: Questi ostendali in dietro eran maggiori che la mia vista
Translate: These banners stretched back more than I could see them.

Original: e, quanto a mio avviso, diece passi distavan quei di fori
Translate: And I think the two outer ones were ten steps away.

Original: Sotto così bel ciel com’ io diviso, ventiquattro seniori, a due a due, coronati venien di fiordaliso
Translate: Under such a beautiful sky, as I describe it, came twenty-four old men, two by two, crowned with lilies.

Original: Tutti cantavan
Translate: Everyone was singing

Original: «Benedicta tue ne le figlie d’Adamo, e benedette sieno in etterno le bellezze tue»
Translate: Blessed be thou among the daughters of Adam, and blessed be thy beauties for ever.

Original: Poscia che i fiori e l’altre fresche erbette a rimpetto di me da l’altra sponda libere fuor da quelle genti elette,
Translate: After the flowers and other fresh herbs before me, on the opposite bank, were freed from those holy nations,

Original: sì come luce luce in ciel seconda, vennero appresso lor quattro animali, coronati ciascun di verde fronda
Translate: As one constellation follows another in heaven, four animals came after them, each crowned with a green leaf.

Original: Ognuno era pennuto di sei ali
Translate: Each had six wings

Original: le penne piene d’occhi
Translate: the wings were full of eyes

Original: e li occhi d’Argo, se fosser vivi, sarebber cotali
Translate: The eyes would be the same as those of Argo, if they were still alive.

Original: A descriver lor forme più non spargo rime, lettor
Translate: Reader, to describe their appearance I do not spend a larger number of verses,

Original: ch’altra spesa mi strigne, tanto ch’a questa non posso esser largo
Translate: because other arguments hold me, to the point that on this I cannot be prodigal of details

Original: ma leggi Ezechïel, che li dipigne come li vide da la fredda parte venir con vento e con nube e con igne
Translate: But read Ezekiel, who describes them as he saw them coming from the north with wind, with clouds, and with fire.

Original: e quali i troverai ne le sue carte, tali eran quivi, salvo ch’a le penne Giovanni è meco e da lui si diparte
Translate: And those whom I saw were identical to those which thou shalt read in his book, except that John is with me for the detail of the feathers, and departs from him.

Original: Lo spazio dentro a lor quattro contenne un carro, in su due rote, trïunfale, ch’al collo d’un grifon tirato venne
Translate: The space between them was occupied by a triumphal chariot, on two wheels, which was drawn from the neck of a griffin.

Original: Esso tendeva in sù l’una e l’altra ale tra la mezzana e le tre e tre liste, sì ch’a nulla, fendendo, facea male
Translate: It had its wings stretched up, between the luminous list in the center and the three on each side, so that it did not damage any of them.

Original: Tanto salivan che non eran viste
Translate: They climbed so high that they couldn't see.

Original: le membra d’oro avea quant’ era uccello, e bianche l’altre, di vermiglio miste
Translate: He had the members of a golden bird, the others of a white colour mixed with red.

Original: Non che Roma di carro così bello rallegrasse Affricano, o vero Augusto, ma quel del Sol saria pover con ello
Translate: Not only in Rome was there never such a beautiful chariot to celebrate Scipione the African or Augustus, but even that of the Sun would be poor compared to that

Original: quel del Sol che, svïando, fu combusto per l’orazion de la Terra devota, quando fu Giove arcanamente giusto
Translate: that of the Sun, which, by deviating, was burned for the prayers of the godly earth, when Jupiter was righteous in a mysterious way

Original: Tre donne in giro da la destra rota venian danzando
Translate: Three women were dancing in circles next to the right wheel

Original: l’una tanto rossa ch’a pena fora dentro al foco nota
Translate: One was red, so much so that she would barely notice herself inside the fire

Original: l’altr’ era come se le carni e l’ossa fossero state di smeraldo fatte
Translate: The second had the flesh and bones that looked like green emerald.

Original: la terza parea neve testé mossa
Translate: the third seemed snow just fallen from the sky

Original: e or parëan da la bianca tratte, or da la rossa
Translate: and now they seemed guided in the dance by the white, now by the red

Original: e dal canto di questa l’altre toglien l’andare e tarde e ratte
Translate: and from the singing of the latter the others assumed a rhythm of slow or fast dance

Original: Da la sinistra quattro facean festa, in porpore vestite, dietro al modo d’una di lor ch’avea tre occhi in testa
Translate: On the left side of the chariot four women danced, clothed in purple red, following the rhythm of one of them who had three eyes on his head.

Original: Appresso tutto il pertrattato nodo vidi due vecchi in abito dispari, ma pari in atto e onesto e sodo
Translate: Behind all these characters, I saw two old clothes differently in the dress, but identical in the dignified and solemn attitude

Original: L’un si mostrava alcun de’ famigliari di quel sommo Ipocràte che natura a li animali fé ch’ell’ ha più cari
Translate: The first was shown to be one of the followers of that high Hippocrates that Nature created for the loved ones

Original: mostrava l’altro la contraria cura con una spada lucida e aguta, tal che di qua dal rio mi fé paura
Translate: The other showed the opposite interest, holding a sharp and shiny sword, so much so that it frightened me even though I was on this side of the river

Original: Poi vidi quattro in umile paruta
Translate: Then I saw four humble - looking characters

Original: e di retro da tutti un vecchio solo venir, dormendo, con la faccia arguta
Translate: And behind them all a lonely old man, who went on sleeping, with an expressive face.

Original: E questi sette col primaio stuolo erano abitüati, ma di gigli dintorno al capo non facëan brolo,
Translate: And these seven were clothed like the first twenty-four old men, but around their heads were not crowned with lilies,

Original: anzi di rose e d’altri fior vermigli
Translate: but of roses and other red flowers

Original: giurato avria poco lontano aspetto che tutti ardesser di sopra da’ cigli
Translate: He would have sworn, looking at them from afar, that they would burn all over his forehead.

Original: E quando il carro a me fu a rimpetto, un tuon s’udì, e quelle genti degne parvero aver l’andar più interdetto,
Translate: And when the chariot was right in front of me, a thunder was heard, and those holy nations seemed to be forbidden to go further,

Original: fermandosi ivi con le prime insegne
Translate: So they stood there with the signs that led the procession.

Original: Quando il settentrïon del primo cielo, che né occaso mai seppe né orto né d’altra nebbia che di colpa velo,
Translate: When the constellation formed by seven stars of the Empire, which never knew sunrise or sunset, nor was it ever clouded by fog except that of sin,

Original: e che faceva lì ciascun accorto di suo dover, come ’l più basso face qual temon gira per venire a porto, fermo s’affisse
Translate: and that there indicated to each one his duty, just as the Great Bear indicates the way to whoever turns the rudder to reach the port, he stopped,

Original: la gente verace, venuta prima tra ’l grifone ed esso, al carro volse sé come a sua pace
Translate: The holy people who had come between it and the griffin turned to the chariot, as to his peace.

Original: e un di loro, quasi da ciel messo, ‘Veni, sponsa, de Libano’ cantando gridò tre volte, e tutti li altri appresso
Translate: and one of the old men, as if he were a messenger of heaven, cried out three times, "Come, bride, from Lebanon," followed by all the others.

Original: Quali i beati al novissimo bando surgeran presti ognun di sua caverna, la revestita voce alleluiando,
Translate: As the Blessed will rise solicitously to the last call, each one from his tomb, singing alleluia with the voice coming from the body with which they will be clothed,

Original: cotali in su la divina basterna si levar cento, ad vocem tanti senis, ministri e messaggier di vita etterna
Translate: So a hundred ministers and messengers of everlasting life arose on the divine chariot, in response to the voice of such an authoritative old man.

Original: Tutti dicean
Translate: Everyone said,

Original: ‘Benedictus qui venis’,
Translate: 'Blessed are you who come',

Original: e fior gittando e di sopra e dintorno,
Translate: And when they threw flowers up and round about, they added,

Original: ‘Manibus, oh, date lilïa plenis’
