Translate: 'Oh, sprinkle lilies with full hands

Original: Io vidi già nel cominciar del giorno la parte orïental tutta rosata, e l’altro ciel di bel sereno addorno
Translate: 'I have already seen at the beginning of the day the whole pink oriental part, and the rest of the sky adorned with a beautiful serene color

Original: e la faccia del sol nascere ombrata, sì che per temperanza di vapori l’occhio la sostenea lunga fïata
Translate: and I saw the sun be born behind a veil, so that the eye could stare at it for a long time thanks to thick vapours that tempered it.

Original: così dentro una nuvola di fiori che da le mani angeliche saliva e ricadeva in giù dentro e di fori,
Translate: Likewise, inside the cloud of flowers that came up from the hands of angels and fell down into the chariot and outside,

Original: sovra candido vel cinta d’uliva donna m’apparve, sotto verde manto vestita di color di fiamma viva
Translate: And there appeared unto me a woman that wore a white veil, and was crowned with an olive tree, under a green robe, and clothed with a bright red colour.

Original: E lo spirito mio, che già cotanto tempo era stato ch’a la sua presenza non era di stupor, tremando, affranto,
Translate: And my spirit, which had already been so long without shaking, struck by the astonishment of his presence,

Original: sanza de li occhi aver più conoscenza, per occulta virtù che da lei mosse, d’antico amor sentì la gran potenza
Translate: even without seeing her with her eyes, thanks to a hidden virtue that moved from her, she felt the great power of an ancient love

Original: Tosto che ne la vista mi percosse l’alta virtù che già m’avea trafitto prima ch’io fuor di püerizia fosse,
Translate: As soon as my sight was struck by the high loving virtue that had already pierced me before I came out of childhood,

Original: volsimi a la sinistra col respitto col quale il fantolin corre a la mamma quando ha paura o quando elli è afflitto, per dicere a Virgilio
Translate: I turned to the left with the anxiety with which the child runs to Mother, when he is afraid or upset by something, to tell Virgilio

Original: ‘Men che dramma di sangue m’è rimaso che non tremi
Translate: 'I haven't got a single drop of blood left that doesn't tremble

Original: conosco i segni de l’antica fiamma’
Translate: I know the signs of the ancient flame.

Original: Ma Virgilio n’avea lasciati scemi di sé, Virgilio dolcissimo patre, Virgilio a cui per mia salute die’mi
Translate: But Virgilio had left us devoid of himself, Virgilio, most sweet father, Virgilio, to whom I entrusted myself for my salvation.

Original: né quantunque perdeo l’antica matre, valse a le guance nette di rugiada, che, lagrimando, non tornasser atre
Translate: and all that the old mother lost did not prevent my dew-clean cheeks from coming back dirty for my weeping

Original: «Dante, perché Virgilio se ne vada, non pianger anco, non piangere ancora
Translate: Dante, because Virgil left, don't cry so soon, don't weep yet,

Original: ché pianger ti conven per altra spada»
Translate: for you will have to weep for other reasons.

Original: Quasi ammiraglio che in poppa e in prora viene a veder la gente che ministra per li altri legni, e a ben far l’incora
Translate: And like an admiral who, at the stern and forward, watches over the sailors who rule the other ships, and urges them to do good.

Original: in su la sponda del carro sinistra, quando mi volsi al suon del nome mio, che di necessità qui si registra,
Translate: on the left side of the chariot, when I turned to the sound of my name which I am forced to quote in these verses,

Original: vidi la donna che pria m’appario velata sotto l’angelica festa, drizzar li occhi ver’ me di qua dal rio
Translate: I saw the woman who had previously appeared to me veiled by the flowers thrown by the angels, staring at me on this side of the river.

Original: Tutto che ’l vel che le scendea di testa, cerchiato de le fronde di Minerva, non la lasciasse parer manifesta,
Translate: Even if the veil that came down on her head, crowned by Minerva's fronds, did not allow to see her face,

Original: regalmente ne l’atto ancor proterva continüò come colui che dice e ’l più caldo parlar dietro reserva
Translate: still royally alters his attitude, as he who speaks and reserves the most effective arguments for the end of the discourse

Original: «Guardaci ben
Translate: •Look well here

Original: Ben son, ben son Beatrice
Translate: Yeah, it's me, it's Beatrice.

Original: Come degnasti d’accedere al monte?
Translate: How dare you enter the Earthly Paradise?

Original: non sapei tu che qui è l’uom felice?»
Translate: Did you not know that this is the seat of the happy man?

Original: Li occhi mi cadder giù nel chiaro fonte
Translate: My eyes fell down into the clear waters of the river

Original: ma veggendomi in esso, i trassi a l’erba, tanta vergogna mi gravò la fronte
Translate: But when I saw my image reflected, I turned them to the grass, because a great shame made my forehead bow.

Original: Così la madre al figlio par superba, com’ ella parve a me
Translate: As the mother seems superb to her son, so she seemed to me

Original: perché d’amaro sente il sapor de la pietade acerba
Translate: in fact the affection that manifests itself with rebuke has a bitter taste

Original: Ella si tacque
Translate: The woman was silent

Original: e li angeli cantaro di sùbito ‘In te, Domine, speravi’
Translate: and the angels sang immediately 'In you, O Lord, I have put my hope',

Original: ma oltre ‘pedes meos’ non passaro
Translate: But they didn't go beyond the verse that says 'My feet'

Original: Sì come neve tra le vive travi per lo dosso d’Italia si congela, soffiata e stretta da li venti schiavi,
Translate: As the snow freezes in the trees of the Apennines, hit by the cold winds of Schiavonia,

Original: poi, liquefatta, in sé stessa trapela, pur che la terra che perde ombra spiri, sì che par foco fonder la candela
Translate: Then, liquefied, it melts little by little, as soon as Africa sends its warm winds, so that it looks like a candle loosed from the fire

Original: così fui sanza lagrime e sospiri anzi ’l cantar di quei che notan sempre dietro a le note de li etterni giri
Translate: in the same way I was without tears and sighs, before the song of those who always sing behind the harmony of the heavenly wheels

Original: ma poi che ’ntesi ne le dolci tempre lor compatire a me, par che se detto avesser
Translate: But after I heard in their sweet melodies that pitied me, as if they had said,

Original: ‘Donna, perché sì lo stempre?’,
Translate: 'Woman, why are you so disheartening him?',

Original: lo gel che m’era intorno al cor ristretto, spirito e acqua fessi, e con angoscia de la bocca e de li occhi uscì del petto
Translate: And the frost that was about my heart turned into water and breath, and came out of my mouth and out of my eyes with anguish.

Original: Ella, pur ferma in su la detta coscia del carro stando, a le sustanze pie volse le sue parole così poscia
Translate: Beatrice, always standing firm on the left side of the chariot, then turned her words to those godly creatures.

Original: «Voi vigilate ne l’etterno die, sì che notte né sonno a voi non fura passo che faccia il secol per sue vie
Translate: "You watch in the eternal light of God, so that neither night nor sleep will take away from you any passage that the world takes in its ways.

Original: onde la mia risposta è con più cura che m’intenda colui che di là piagne, perché sia colpa e duol d’una misura
Translate: Therefore my answer is to be heard by him that weeps beyond the river, that the pain may be in proportion to the guilt.

Original: Non pur per ovra de le rote magne, che drizzan ciascun seme ad alcun fine secondo che le stelle son compagne,
Translate: Not only through the influence of Heaven, which direct each being to its end according to the virtue of the star that presides at his birth,

Original: ma per larghezza di grazie divine, che sì alti vapori hanno a lor piova, che nostre viste là non van vicine,
Translate: but also because of the generosity of divine grace, which rains from clouds so high that our sight cannot even approach,

Original: questi fu tal ne la sua vita nova virtüalmente, ch’ogne abito destro fatto averebbe in lui mirabil prova
Translate: he in his youth had such virtues in power that in him all good attitude would lead to extraordinary results

Original: Ma tanto più maligno e più silvestro si fa ’l terren col mal seme e non cólto, quant’ elli ha più di buon vigor terrestro
Translate: But a soil becomes all the more bad and wild, with bad seeds and when it is not cultivated, the more it is endowed with natural fertility

Original: Alcun tempo il sostenni col mio volto
Translate: For some time I supported Dante with my face

Original: mostrando li occhi giovanetti a lui, meco il menava in dritta parte vòlto
Translate: Showing him my young eyes, I led him with me to the right path.

Original: Sì tosto come in su la soglia fui di mia seconda etade e mutai vita, questi si tolse a me, e diessi altrui
Translate: But as soon as I was on the threshold of my youth and changed my life, he betrayed my memory and gave himself to other women.

Original: Quando di carne a spirto era salita, e bellezza e virtù cresciuta m’era, fu’ io a lui men cara e men gradita
Translate: When I had turned from flesh to spirit and my beauty and virtue were increased, I was less expensive and less pleasing to him.

Original: e volse i passi suoi per via non vera, imagini di ben seguendo false, che nulla promession rendono intera
Translate: and turned his footsteps by a fallacious way, following false images of good, which keep no promise made.

Original: Né l’impetrare ispirazion mi valse, con le quali e in sogno e altrimenti lo rivocai
Translate: It did not serve me to get good inspiration from Heaven, with which I called him back in a dream and in other way

Original: sì poco a lui ne calse
Translate: He cared so little

Original: Tanto giù cadde, che tutti argomenti a la salute sua eran già corti, fuor che mostrarli le perdute genti
Translate: He fell so low, that by now every means to save him was ineffective, except to show him the lost people

Original: Per questo visitai l’uscio d’i morti, e a colui che l’ha qua sù condotto, li prieghi miei, piangendo, furon porti
Translate: Therefore I visited the threshold of Hell, and wept, and prayed unto him that brought him up to this place.

Original: Alto fato di Dio sarebbe rotto, se Letè si passasse e tal vivanda fosse gustata sanza alcuno scotto di pentimento che lagrime spanda»
Translate: God's high will would be broken if Dante overcame the Lete and tasted such food without feeling such repentance as to make him shed tears.

Original: «O tu che se’ di là dal fiume sacro»,
Translate: "O you who are beyond the sacred river,

Original: volgendo suo parlare a me per punta, che pur per taglio m’era paruto acro, ricominciò, seguendo sanza cunta,
Translate: Speaking directly to me his words which, even indirectly, seemed harsh to me, he began to speak again without delay.

Original: «dì, dì se questo è vero
Translate: Tell me, tell me if this is true

Original: a tanta accusa tua confession conviene esser congiunta»
Translate: to such an accusation it is necessary that your confession be united

Original: Era la mia virtù tanto confusa, che la voce si mosse, e pria si spense che da li organi suoi fosse dischiusa
Translate: My virtue was so confused that my voice went up, and stood still before it was issued by the organs of the word.

Original: Poco sofferse
Translate: She patientized a little,

Original: poi disse
Translate: then he said,

Original: «Che pense? Rispondi a me
Translate: What do you think? Answer me,

Original: ché le memorie triste in te non sono ancor da l’acqua offense»
Translate: For the remembrance of sin has not yet been erased in thee from the water of Lete.

Original: Confusione e paura insieme miste mi pinsero un tal «sì» fuor de la bocca, al quale intender fuor mestier le viste
Translate: The confusion and the fear, mixed together, pushed out of my mouth a "yes" so weak that, to understand it, sight was necessary and not hearing

Original: Come balestro frange, quando scocca da troppa tesa, la sua corda e l’arco,
Translate: Like a crossbow breaks the rope and the bow, when it strikes an arrow with excessive tension,

Original: e con men foga l’asta il segno tocca, sì scoppia’ io sottesso grave carco, fuori sgorgando lagrime e sospiri, e la voce allentò per lo suo varco
Translate: And the dart came to the mark with little force, and I burst under the weight of anguish, and cast out tears and sighs, and the voice was uttered with less force.

Original: Ond’ ella a me
Translate: Then she said to me

Original: «Per entro i mie’ disiri, che ti menavano ad amar lo bene di là dal qual non è a che s’aspiri,
Translate: "Following the desire that inspired you and moved you to love good, beyond which there is nothing to aspire to,

Original: quai fossi attraversati o quai catene trovasti, per che del passare innanzi dovessiti così spogliar la spene?
Translate: What ditches of places crossed or what chains did you find, so I had to leave the hope of going beyond them?

Original: E quali agevolezze o quali avanzi ne la fronte de li altri si mostraro, per che dovessi lor passeggiare anzi?»
Translate: And what ease, what advantages were shown to you in the appearance of the other goods, so that I should wander them?

Original: Dopo la tratta d’un sospiro amaro, a pena ebbi la voce che rispuose, e le labbra a fatica la formaro
Translate: After drawing a bitter sigh, I barely found my voice to answer, and my lips barely spoke.

Original: Piangendo dissi
Translate: I said crying

Original: «Le presenti cose col falso lor piacer volser miei passi, tosto che ’l vostro viso si nascose»
Translate: "The goods before me, with their pleasant appearance, turned away my steps as soon as your face was hidden from me."

Original: Ed ella
Translate: And you.

Original: «Se tacessi o se negassi ciò che confessi, non fora men nota la colpa tua
Translate: If you also shut up or deny what you confess, your guilt would be no less obvious.

Original: da tal giudice sassi
Translate: I learn it from a judge so infallible

Original: Ma quando scoppia de la propria gota l’accusa del peccato, in nostra corte rivolge sé contra ’l taglio la rota
Translate: But when the accusation of sin is pronounced by the one who committed it, in our court the stone turns itself against the cut

Original: Tuttavia, perché mo vergogna porte del tuo errore, e perché altra volta, udendo le serene, sie più forte, pon giù il seme del piangere e ascolta
Translate: However, because you are less ashamed of your error, and because you are stronger once again when you listen to the sirens, the reason for your weeping ceases, and you listen.

Original: sì udirai come in contraria parte mover dovieti mia carne sepolta
Translate: So you will feel how my earthly death should have led you on a road opposite the one you followed

Original: Mai non t’appresentò natura o arte piacer, quanto le belle membra in ch’io rinchiusa fui, e che so’ ’n terra sparte
Translate: Nature or art never showed you a beauty comparable to that of the mortal body in which I was locked up, and which is now scattered underground

Original: e se ’l sommo piacer sì ti fallio per la mia morte, qual cosa mortale dovea poi trarre te nel suo disio?
Translate: And if that marvelous beauty failed you with my death, what other earthly thing could then arouse your desire?

Original: Ben ti dovevi, per lo primo strale de le cose fallaci, levar suso di retro a me che non era più tale
Translate: You should have, after that first disappointment of fleeting possessions, lifted up high behind me that I was no longer earthly and fleeting.

Original: Non ti dovea gravar le penne in giuso, ad aspettar più colpo, o pargoletta o altra novità con sì breve uso
Translate: He should not have let you fly down, waiting for more strokes of fate, a young woman or another vain and ephemeral earthly good

Original: Novo augelletto due o tre aspetta
Translate: A young bird awaits two or three blows

Original: ma dinanzi da li occhi d’i pennuti rete si spiega indarno o si saetta»
Translate: but in front of the adult birds the hunter deploys the nets or throws the arrows in vain

Original: Quali fanciulli, vergognando, muti con li occhi a terra stannosi, ascoltando e sé riconoscendo e ripentuti, tal mi stav’ io
Translate: As the children, being ashamed, are mute with their eyes on the ground, listening and admitting their guilt, repented, so I was

Original: ed ella disse
Translate: and she said,

Original: «Quando per udir se’ dolente, alza la barba, e prenderai più doglia riguardando»
Translate: "For when you listen to my words, you grieve, lift up your beard, and you will feel more when you look at me."

Original: Con men di resistenza si dibarba robusto cerro, o vero al nostral vento o vero a quel de la terra di Iarba, ch’io non levai al suo comando il mento
Translate: A sturdy deer is uprooted from the wind of our land or from the wind that blows from Africa with less resistance than I raised my chin at his command.

Original: e quando per la barba il viso chiese, ben conobbi il velen de l’argomento
Translate: And when he commanded me to lift up my face with the word "shave," he immediately understood his bitter rebuke.

Original: E come la mia faccia si distese, posarsi quelle prime creature da loro aspersïon l’occhio comprese
Translate: And as soon as I lifted up my face, the eye knew that the angels had ceased to scatter the flowers.

Original: e le mie luci, ancor poco sicure, vider Beatrice volta in su la fiera ch’è sola una persona in due nature
Translate: and my eyes, still unsure, saw Beatrice turning to the fair that she is one person with two natures

Original: Sotto ’l suo velo e oltre la rivera vincer pariemi più sé stessa antica, vincer che l’altre qui, quand’ ella c’era
Translate: Even though she was veiled and beyond the river, she seemed to surpass herself in beauty when she was alive, more than she, when she was alive, surpassed all the other women.

Original: Di penter sì mi punse ivi l’ortica, che di tutte altre cose qual mi torse più nel suo amor, più mi si fé nemica
Translate: The nettle of repentance pricked me so much that, compared to all other things, the one that most distracted me from love for Beatrice became more hateful to me

Original: Tanta riconoscenza il cor mi morse, ch’io caddi vinto
Translate: This recognition struck my heart so much that I fell unconscious

Original: e quale allora femmi, salsi colei che la cagion mi porse
Translate: And as I became then, she knows that she gave me the cause.

Original: Poi, quando il cor virtù di fuor rendemmi, la donna ch’io avea trovata sola sopra me vidi, e dicea
Translate: Then, when the heart returned the life force to me in the outer members, I saw the woman whom I had met alone standing above me, saying,

Original: «Tiemmi, tiemmi»
Translate: Clutch to me...

Original: Tratto m’avea nel fiume infin la gola, e tirandosi me dietro sen giva sovresso l’acqua lieve come scola
Translate: He had plunged me into the river to the throat, and pulling behind me he went on the water, slipping lightly like a gondola.

Original: Quando fui presso a la beata riva, ‘Asperges me’ sì dolcemente udissi, che nol so rimembrar, non ch’io lo scriva
Translate: When I was near the opposite bank, I heard the angels singing 'You will sprinkle me' with such sweetness that not only do I not know how to describe it, but I don't even remember it

Original: La bella donna ne le braccia aprissi
Translate: The beautiful woman opened her arms,

Original: abbracciommi la testa e mi sommerse ove convenne ch’io l’acqua inghiottissi
Translate: He embraced my head and plunged me to the point of forcing me to swallow the water

Original: Indi mi tolse, e bagnato m’offerse dentro a la danza de le quattro belle
Translate: Then he pulled me out and relied on me, wet, to the dance of the four women,

Original: e ciascuna del braccio mi coperse
Translate: And each covered me with his arm.

Original: «Noi siam qui ninfe e nel ciel siamo stelle
Translate: We are nymphs here and in the sky we are stars

Original: pria che Beatrice discendesse al mondo, fummo ordinate a lei per sue ancelle
Translate: Before Beatrice came into the world, we were created as her handmaids.

Original: Merrenti a li occhi suoi
Translate: We will lead you to his eyes

Original: ma nel giocondo lume ch’è dentro aguzzeranno i tuoi le tre di là, che miran più profondo»
Translate: But the other three women shall sharpen thine eyes, that thou mayest see the light within them: for they have the deepest sight.

Original: Così cantando cominciaro
Translate: So they started singing

Original: e poi al petto del grifon seco menarmi, ove Beatrice stava volta a noi
Translate: And they took me with them to the breast of the griffin, where Beatrice was turning toward us.

Original: Disser
Translate: They said,

Original: «Fa che le viste non risparmi
Translate: "Look at his eyes without sparing you

Original: posto t’avem dinanzi a li smeraldi ond’ Amor già ti trasse le sue armi»
Translate: We placed you in front of the emeralds from which Love threw his darts that made you fall in love

Original: Mille disiri più che fiamma caldi strinsermi li occhi a li occhi rilucenti, che pur sopra ’l grifone stavan saldi
Translate: A thousand desires, warmer than the flame, shook my eyes to the shining eyes of Beatrice, who were fixed on the griffin.

Original: Come in lo specchio il sol, non altrimenti la doppia fiera dentro vi raggiava, or con altri, or con altri reggimenti
Translate: Like the sun in a mirror, not unlike the double fair was reflected inside, now with one attitude, now with another

Original: Pensa, lettor, s’io mi maravigliava, quando vedea la cosa in sé star queta, e ne l’idolo suo si trasmutava
Translate: Think, reader, what was my wonder, when I saw the gryphon remain equal to himself and transmutate into the reflected image

Original: Mentre che piena di stupore e lieta l’anima mia gustava di quel cibo che, saziando di sé, di sé asseta,
Translate: As my soul, full of amazement and gladness, tasted that food which, by satiating it, made it more thirsty,

Original: sé dimostrando di più alto tribo ne li atti, l’altre tre si fero avanti, danzando al loro angelico caribo
Translate: the other three women, demonstrating in their acts that they belong to a higher condition, came forward dancing in their angelic dance

Original: «Volgi, Beatrice, volgi li occhi santi», era la sua canzone, «al tuo fedele che, per vederti, ha mossi passi tanti
Translate: Their song said, "Beatrice, turn your holy eyes to your faithful who, to see you, has come a long way."

Original: Per grazia fa noi grazia che disvele a lui la bocca tua, sì che discerna la seconda bellezza che tu cele»
Translate: By your grace, grant us to reveal to him your smile, so that I may see the second beauty that you solo

Original: O isplendor di viva luce etterna, chi palido si fece sotto l’ombra sì di Parnaso,
Translate: O splendor of bright eternal light, who became pale under the shadow of Parnasus.

Original: o bevve in sua cisterna, che non paresse aver la mente ingombra,
Translate: or he drank at his source to such an extent that he did not seem to have the mind clouded,

Original: tentando a render te qual tu paresti là dove armonizzando il ciel t’adombra, quando ne l’aere aperto ti solvesti?
Translate: trying to describe how you appeared where the heavenly spheres with their harmony surround you, when you revealed yourself in the open air?

Original: Tant’ eran li occhi miei fissi e attenti a disbramarsi la decenne sete, che li altri sensi m’eran tutti spenti
Translate: My eyes were so fixed and attentive to fulfilling the longing for ten years, that all my other senses were inert.

Original: Ed essi quinci e quindi avien parete di non caler
Translate: And they were shielded on one side and on the other, not knowing anything.

Original: — così lo santo riso a sé traéli con l’antica rete —
Translate: so the holy smile drew them to itself with the endical call of love

Original: quando per forza mi fu vòlto il viso ver’ la sinistra mia da quelle dee, perch’ io udi’ da loro un «Troppo fiso»
Translate: when those goddesses turned my gaze to the left force, for I heard them say "too fixed"

Original: e la disposizion ch’a veder è ne li occhi pur testé dal sol percossi, sanza la vista alquanto esser mi fée
Translate: and the visual faculty that remains in the eyes just dazzled by the sun made me stay for some time without sight

Original: Ma poi ch’al poco il viso riformossi
Translate: But after the sight returned to get used to a less intense light,

Original: (e dico ‘al poco’ per rispetto al molto sensibile onde a forza mi rimossi),
Translate: and I say 'less intense' in relation to the high vision from which I turned away by force

Original: vidi ’n sul braccio destro esser rivolto lo glorïoso essercito, e tornarsi col sole e con le sette fiamme al volto
Translate: And I saw that the glorious army turned to the right hand, and went with the sun, and the seven candlesticks before it.

Original: Come sotto li scudi per salvarsi volgesi schiera, e sé gira col segno, prima che possa tutta in sé mutarsi
Translate: As a military column operates a conversion under shields, to save itself, and turns with signs, before all can reverse the march,

Original: quella milizia del celeste regno che procedeva, tutta trapassonne pria che piegasse il carro il primo legno
Translate: So that hostage of the heavenly kingdom passed us all before the chariot turned the rudder.

Original: Indi a le rote si tornar le donne, e ’l grifon mosse il benedetto carco sì, che però nulla penna crollonne
Translate: Then the seven women returned by the wheels, and the griffin moved the blessed load so that no pen was moved.

Original: La bella donna che mi trasse al varco e Stazio e io seguitavam la rota che fé l’orbita sua con minore arco
Translate: The beautiful woman who made me pass through the river, Stazio and I followed the wheel that had made a minor bow

Original: Sì passeggiando l’alta selva vòta, colpa di quella ch’al serpente crese, temprava i passi un’angelica nota
Translate: As we passed through the deserted high forest, because of the one who believed in the serpent, our steps were accompanied by an angelic song.

Original: Forse in tre voli tanto spazio prese disfrenata saetta, quanto eramo rimossi, quando Bëatrice scese
Translate: Perhaps we walked through the space that would cover an arrow thrown three times, when Beatrice came down from the chariot.

Original: Io senti’ mormorare a tutti «Adamo»
Translate: I heard everyone murmuring "Adam"

Original: poi cerchiaro una pianta dispogliata di foglie e d’altra fronda in ciascun ramo
Translate: And they surrounded a plant without leaves, and with every other leaf, in all its branches.

Original: La coma sua, che tanto si dilata più quanto più è sù, fora da l’Indi ne’ boschi lor per altezza ammirata
Translate: His hair, which gradually widens upwards, would be admired by the Indians in their woods, for its height

Original: «Beato se’, grifon, che non discindi col becco d’esto legno dolce al gusto, poscia che mal si torce il ventre quindi»
Translate: You are blessed, O gryphon, in that you do not tear the wood of this sweet plant with the belly to taste, since then the belly of torches with pain.

Original: Così dintorno a l’albero robusto gridaron li altri
Translate: So the others cried out around the strong tree.

Original: e l’animal binato
Translate: and the double-natured animal

Original: «Sì si conserva il seme d’ogne giusto»
Translate: Thus the foundation of all justice is preserved

Original: E vòlto al temo ch’elli avea tirato, trasselo al piè de la vedova frasca, e quel di lei a lei lasciò legato
Translate: And when he turned to the helm which he had drawn, he dragged him to the foot of the bare tree, and bound him to it with a dash of the tree itself.

Original: Come le nostre piante, quando casca giù la gran luce mischiata con quella che raggia dietro a la celeste lasca,
Translate: Like our plants, when the great light of the sun goes down mixed with the one that shines behind the constellation of Pisces,

Original: turgide fansi,
Translate: they are inturgid,

Original: e poi si rinovella di suo color ciascuna, pria che ’l sole giunga li suoi corsier sotto altra stella
Translate: and then each one renews its colors, before the sun joins with another star.

Original: men che di rose e più che di vïole colore aprendo, s’innovò la pianta, che prima avea le ramora sì sole
Translate: So that plant was renewed, which had the branches so bare before, and blossomed blossoms between pink and violet.

Original: Io non lo ’ntesi, né qui non si canta l’inno che quella gente allor cantaro, né la nota soffersi tutta quanta
Translate: I didn't understand, and there is no singing here on Earth, the hymn that those people sang at that time, nor could I listen to all the notes

Original: S’io potessi ritrar come assonnaro li occhi spietati udendo di Siringa, li occhi a cui pur vegghiar costò sì caro
Translate: If I could describe how they slept their ruthless eyes listening to the story of Syringe, the eyes that it cost so much to stay awake,

Original: come pintor che con essempro pinga, disegnerei com’ io m’addormentai
Translate: As a painter who paints with a pattern, I would describe how I fell asleep

Original: ma qual vuol sia che l’assonnar ben finga
Translate: But whoever wills, if he can, picture the act of falling asleep.

Original: Però trascorro a quando mi svegliai, e dico ch’un splendor mi squarciò ’l velo del sonno, e un chiamar
Translate: So I move on to the moment when I woke up, and I say that my sleep was interrupted by a splendor and call

Original: «Surgi
Translate: Get up

Original: che fai?»
Translate: What are you doing?

Original: Quali a veder de’ fioretti del melo che del suo pome li angeli fa ghiotti e perpetüe nozze fa nel cielo, Pietro e Giovanni e Iacopo condotti e vinti,
Translate: Like Peter, John, and James, led you to see an essay of Christ's splendor, which makes the angels greedy, and enlivens an eternal wedding meal in heaven, after being stunned,

Original: ritornaro a la parola da la qual furon maggior sonni rotti, e videro scemata loro scuola così di Moïsè come d’Elia, e al maestro suo cangiata stola
Translate: And they returned to themselves, to the sound of the word that brake down deeper sleeps, and saw that their company was diminished, and that Moses and Elijah were gone, and that their teacher had changed his robe.

Original: tal torna’ io, e vidi quella pia sovra me starsi che conducitrice fu de’ miei passi lungo ’l fiume pria
Translate: So I woke up, and I saw that the godly woman who had led me along the river Lete stood above me.

Original: E tutto in dubbio dissi
Translate: And, caught in a doubt, I said,

Original: «Ov’ è Beatrice?»
Translate: Where's Beatrice?

Original: Ond’ ella
Translate: Then you

Original: «Vedi lei sotto la fronda nova sedere in su la sua radice
Translate: There it is, sitting under the renewed leaf of the tree, on the root.

Original: Vedi la compagnia che la circonda
Translate: See the company around her

Original: li altri dopo ’l grifon sen vanno suso con più dolce canzone e più profonda»
Translate: others go to heaven following the gryphon, with a sweeter and deeper song.

Original: E se più fu lo suo parlar diffuso, non so, però che già ne li occhi m’era quella ch’ad altro intender m’avea chiuso
Translate: And I do not know if his words were more diffused, for by now I was staring down at her who had absorbed all my attention.

Original: Sola sedeasi in su la terra vera, come guardia lasciata lì del plaustro che legar vidi a la biforme fera
Translate: She sat lonely on the true earth, as if she had been left there to guard the chariot that I had seen being bound by the biform beast.

Original: In cerchio le facevan di sé claustro le sette ninfe, con quei lumi in mano che son sicuri d’Aquilone e d’Austro
Translate: The seven nymphs surrounded her, holding in her hand those lights that cannot be extinguished from the kite or the Austro

Original: «Qui sarai tu poco tempo silvano
Translate: Thou shalt be little in this forest, after thy death.

Original: e sarai meco sanza fine cive di quella Roma onde Cristo è romano
Translate: And thou shalt be with me for ever a citizen of that Rome of which Christ is a worthy inhabitant.

Original: Però, in pro del mondo che mal vive, al carro tieni or li occhi, e quel che vedi, ritornato di là, fa che tu scrive»
Translate: Therefore, to the benefit of the world that lives in sin, keep your gaze fixed on the chariot, and once you return to Earth, write what you will soon see.

Original: Così Beatrice
Translate: So Beatrice

Original: e io, che tutto ai piedi d’i suoi comandamenti era divoto, la mente e li occhi ov’ ella volle diedi
Translate: And I, being devoted to all his commandments, turned my mind and my eyes where she wished.

Original: Non scese mai con sì veloce moto foco di spessa nube, quando piove da quel confine che più va remoto,
Translate: Never did lightning descend so quickly from a thick cloud, when it falls from that part of the sky that is higher,

Original: com’ io vidi calar l’uccel di Giove per l’alber giù, rompendo de la scorza, non che d’i fiori e de le foglie nove
Translate: As I saw the holy bird descending from above to Jupiter on the tree, tearing off its bark, its outs, and its freshly born leaves.

Original: e ferì ’l carro di tutta sua forza
Translate: And he struck the chariot with all his might.

Original: ond’ el piegò come nave in fortuna, vinta da l’onda, or da poggia, or da orza
Translate: It swinged like a ship in the storm, swaying from one side to the other.

Original: Poscia vidi avventarsi ne la cuna del trïunfal veiculo una volpe che d’ogne pasto buon parea digiuna
Translate: Then I saw a fox rushing to the bottom of the chariot, which seemed to fast from every good meal.

Original: ma, riprendendo lei di laide colpe, la donna mia la volse in tanta futa quanto sofferser l’ossa sanza polpe
Translate: But when my wife accused her of grave sins, she fled, as quickly as she could bear her extreme lewdness.

Original: Poscia per indi ond’ era pria venuta, l’aguglia vidi scender giù ne l’arca del carro e lasciar lei di sé pennuta
Translate: Then I saw the eagle return to the same place she had come before, and come down into the chariot and leave some of her feathers there.

Original: e qual esce di cuor che si rammarca, tal voce uscì del cielo e cotal disse
Translate: And as a voice came out of a sorrowful heart, so came a voice out of heaven, and said,

Original: «O navicella mia, com’ mal se’ carca»
Translate: "O my ship, as you are badly charged"

Original: Poi parve a me che la terra s’aprisse tr’ambo le ruote, e vidi uscirne un drago che per lo carro sù la coda fisse
Translate: And it seemed to me that the earth was opened between the two wheels, and I saw that a dragon came out, and thrust his tail up by the chariot.

Original: e come vespa che ritragge l’ago, a sé traendo la coda maligna, trasse del fondo, e gissen vago vago
Translate: And as a wasp that drew the stinger, the dragon, pulling his evil tail, took away a part of the bottom of the chariot, and went astray.

Original: Quel che rimase, come da gramigna vivace terra, da la piuma, offerta forse con intenzion sana e benigna,
Translate: What was left of the chariot, and the wheel and the rudder, like a fertile land choked with the grass,

Original: si ricoperse, e funne ricoperta e l’una e l’altra rota e ’l temo, in tanto che più tiene un sospir la bocca aperta
Translate: he covered all the feathers that perhaps had been left with benevolent and healthy intentions, at a shorter time than it took to pull a sigh with an open mouth

Original: Trasformato così ’l dificio santo mise fuor teste per le parti sue, tre sovra ’l temo e una in ciascun canto
Translate: So transformed, the holy chariot put out heads in all its parts, three on the rudder, and four in its corners.

Original: Le prime eran cornute come bue, ma le quattro un sol corno avean per fronte
Translate: The first three were horned like the head of an ox, but the other four had one horn on their forehead.

Original: simile mostro visto ancor non fue
Translate: You've never seen a monster like that.

Original: Sicura, quasi rocca in alto monte, seder sovresso una puttana sciolta m’apparve con le ciglia intorno pronte
Translate: It seemed to me that on it sat a brazen prostitute, sure as a fortress on a high mountain, who revolved around the seductive eyes

Original: e come perché non li fosse tolta, vidi di costa a lei dritto un gigante
Translate: And I saw a giant beside her, who seemed not to want her to be taken away from him.

Original: e basciavansi insieme alcuna volta
Translate: and kissed together several times

Original: Ma perché l’occhio cupido e vagante a me rivolse, quel feroce drudo la flagellò dal capo infin le piante
Translate: But because the harlot looked upon me full of desire, that fierce lover whipped her from one foot to another.

Original: poi, di sospetto pieno e d’ira crudo, disciolse il mostro, e trassel per la selva,
Translate: Then, full of suspicion and cruel anger, he removed the monster from the tree and dragged him away into the forest,

Original: tanto che sol di lei mi fece scudo a la puttana e a la nova belva
Translate: So much so that it was only the one that kept me from seeing the prostitute and the new beast

Original: ‘Deus, venerunt gentes’,
Translate: "God, the Gentiles have come."

Original: alternando or tre or quattro dolce salmodia, le donne incominciaro, e lagrimando
Translate: The women began, first three o'clock, then four o'clock, to sing a sweet song, and weeping

Original: e Bëatrice, sospirosa e pia, quelle ascoltava sì fatta, che poco più a la croce si cambiò Maria
Translate: and Beatrice listened to them, sighing devoutly, with such an appearance that Mary transfigured in a similar way at the foot of the cross.

Original: Ma poi che l’altre vergini dier loco a lei di dir, levata dritta in pè, rispuose, colorata come foco
Translate: But when the other women had let her speak, and stood up, she answered red with indignation.

Original: ‘Modicum, et non videbitis me
Translate: 'Just a little while longer, and you won't see me anymore.

Original: et iterum, sorelle mie dilette, modicum, et vos videbitis me’
Translate: And a little more, my dear sisters, you will see me again.

Original: Poi le si mise innanzi tutte e sette, e dopo sé, solo accennando, mosse me e la donna e ’l savio che ristette
Translate: And he sent them all seven before him, and with a nod led me, Matedah, and the wise man that remained after her.

Original: Così sen giva
Translate: That's how it went.

Original: e non credo che fosse lo decimo suo passo in terra posto, quando con li occhi li occhi mi percosse
Translate: And I don't think he took the tenth step when he looked at me.

Original: e con tranquillo aspetto
Translate: and with a serene appearance

Original: «Vien più tosto», mi disse, «tanto che, s’io parlo teco, ad ascoltarmi tu sie ben disposto»
Translate: "Come faster, so that, if I speak to you, you will be willing to listen to me."

Original: Sì com’ io fui, com’ io dovëa, seco, dissemi
Translate: As soon as I got close, as I had to, he said to me,

Original: «Frate, perché non t’attenti a domandarmi omai venendo meco?»
Translate: Brother, why don't you ask me questions while you're walking with me?

Original: Come a color che troppo reverenti dinanzi a suo maggior parlando sono, che non traggon la voce viva ai denti,
Translate: As is the case with those who are too respectful to speak in front of their superiors, so they do not utter a secure voice,

Original: avvenne a me, che sanza intero suono incominciai
Translate: So it happened to me, that I began to murmur

Original: «Madonna, mia bisogna voi conoscete, e ciò ch’ad essa è buono»
Translate: "My lady, you know my desires and what suits them."

Original: Ed ella a me
Translate: And her to me

Original: «Da tema e da vergogna voglio che tu omai ti disviluppe, sì che non parli più com’ om che sogna
Translate: I want you to free yourself from fear and shame, so that you don't talk in a confused way anymore.

Original: Sappi che ’l vaso che ’l serpente ruppe, fu e non è
Translate: Know that the vessel that the snake broke is as if it no longer existed.

Original: ma chi n’ha colpa, creda che vendetta di Dio non teme suppe
Translate: But whoever is guilty of this, believe that the vengeance of God will be inexorable.

Original: Non sarà tutto tempo sanza reda l’aguglia che lasciò le penne al carro, per che divenne mostro e poscia preda
Translate: The eagle that left the feathers in the chariot, which for this reason became a monster and then prey of the giant, will not always be without heirs

Original: ch’io veggio certamente, e però il narro, a darne tempo già stelle propinque, secure d’ogn’ intoppo e d’ogne sbarro,
Translate: For I certainly see, and therefore I tell it, that a constellation is near, away from every obstacle, and from every barrier,

Original: nel quale un cinquecento diece e cinque, messo di Dio, anciderà la fuia con quel gigante che con lei delinque
Translate: who will give the world a time when a five hundred ten and five, sent by God, will kill the harlot and the giant who deals with her

Original: E forse che la mia narrazion buia, qual Temi e Sfinge, men ti persuade, perch’ a lor modo lo ’ntelletto attuia
Translate: Maybe my dark tale, like that of Themes or Sphinx, doesn't convince you much, because it tires your intellect like they did.

Original: ma tosto fier li fatti le Naiade, che solveranno questo enigma forte sanza danno di pecore o di biade
Translate: But soon the Naiades will loosen with the facts this difficult enigma, without harm of sheep or biadas.

Original: Tu nota
Translate: You take note

Original: e sì come da me son porte, così queste parole segna a’ vivi del viver ch’è un correre a la morte
Translate: and refer to those who live on earth and are destined to die these words, as I tell you.

Original: E aggi a mente, quando tu le scrivi, di non celar qual hai vista la pianta ch’è or due volte dirubata quivi
Translate: And remember, when you write to her, don't omit the way you saw the plant that has now been stripped twice.

Original: Qualunque ruba quella o quella schianta, con bestemmia di fatto offende a Dio, che solo a l’uso suo la creò santa
Translate: Whosoever depreciates or harms that plant, in fact offends God in a sacrilegious way, who created it sacred only for His ends.

Original: Per morder quella, in pena e in disio cinquemilia anni e più l’anima prima bramò colui che ’l morso in sé punio
Translate: For having eaten its fruits, the first man desired in pain and desire for more than five thousand years the one who redeemed this sin by his death.

Original: Dorme lo ’ngegno tuo, se non estima per singular cagione esser eccelsa lei tanto e sì travolta ne la cima
Translate: Your ingenuity vanishes if it doesn't understand that the plant is so high and upside down for an exceptional reason

Original: E se stati non fossero acqua d’Elsa li pensier vani intorno a la tua mente,
Translate: And if the vain thoughts around your mind had not hardened it as the waters of the Elsa River do,

Original: e ’l piacer loro un Piramo a la gelsa, per tante circostanze solamente la giustizia di Dio, ne l’interdetto, conosceresti a l’arbor moralmente
Translate: And if their pleasure had not clouded your understanding as Piram did with the mulberry tree, only by these circumstances would you understand that the righteousness of God is the symbolic meaning of the tree, that is, for the prohibition of biting it.

Original: Ma perch’ io veggio te ne lo ’ntelletto fatto di pietra e, impetrato, tinto,
Translate: But since I see that your intellect is as petrified, and so done, it is obscured,

Original: sì che t’abbaglia il lume del mio detto, voglio anco, e se non scritto, almen dipinto, che ’l te ne porti dentro a te per quello che si reca il bordon di palma cinto»
Translate: So the light of my words dazzles you, I want you to keep a summary image of what I have said to you, if not a precise memory, how the pilgrim keeps a palm tree on his staff.

Original: E io
Translate: And I...

Original: «Sì come cera da suggello, che la figura impressa non trasmuta, segnato è or da voi lo mio cervello
Translate: My brain is now marked by you as the wax is imprinted by the seal, so that it does not change its shape.

Original: Ma perché tanto sovra mia veduta vostra parola disïata vola, che più la perde quanto più s’aiuta?»
Translate: But why does your word desired by me fly so far above my intellect, that the more it seeks to follow it, the less it understands it?

Original: «Perché conoschi»,
Translate: "Why do you recognize

Original: disse,
Translate: said

Original: «quella scuola c’hai seguitata, e veggi sua dottrina come può seguitar la mia parola
Translate: that school that you followed and understand that its doctrine is insufficient to follow my words

Original: e veggi vostra via da la divina distar cotanto, quanto si discorda da terra il ciel che più alto festina»
Translate: and that you may see that human wisdom is as far from that divine as the Earth is far from Heaven that moves higher

Original: Ond’ io rispuosi lei
Translate: Then I answered her.

Original: «Non mi ricorda ch’i’ stranïasse me già mai da voi, né honne coscïenza che rimorda»
Translate: "I don't remember ever turning away from you, nor does my conscience remorse me for this."

Original: «E se tu ricordar non te ne puoi»,
Translate: And if you can't remember,

Original: sorridendo rispuose,
Translate: replied smilingly

Original: «or ti rammenta come bevesti di Letè ancoi
Translate: Remember how you drank the water of Lete today

Original: e se dal fummo foco s’argomenta, cotesta oblivïon chiaro conchiude colpa ne la tua voglia altrove attenta
Translate: and as the smoke is sure the clue of the fire, this forgetfulness of yours is the sure proof of your guilt, when you have turned your attention to others

Original: Veramente oramai saranno nude le mie parole, quanto converrassi quelle scovrire a la tua vista rude»
Translate: However, from now on my words will be simpler, as much as it will be necessary for your crude ingenuity to understand them.

Original: E più corusco e con più lenti passi teneva il sole il cerchio di merigge, che qua e là, come li aspetti, fassi, quando s’affisser,
Translate: And the sun had come brighter and with a slower path to the meridian, which changes position depending on how the gaze changes,

Original: sì come s’affigge chi va dinanzi a gente per iscorta se trova novitate o sue vestigge,
Translate: how one who precedes others stops as a guide if he finds something new or his tracks,

Original: le sette donne al fin d’un’ombra smorta, qual sotto foglie verdi e rami nigri sovra suoi freddi rivi l’alpe porta
Translate: And the seven women stood in a shadowy clearing, like the one under the green leaves, and the dark branches in the mountains, by the cold rivers.

Original: Dinanzi ad esse Ëufratès e Tigri veder mi parve uscir d’una fontana, e, quasi amici, dipartirsi pigri
Translate: In front of the women it seemed to me to see the Tigris and the Euphrates flowing from a single source, and, as friends, slowly drift away

Original: «O luce, o gloria de la gente umana, che acqua è questa che qui si dispiega da un principio e sé da sé lontana?»
Translate: "O light, or glory of humanity, what rivers are these two born from the same source and then separate themselves from each other?"

Original: Per cotal priego detto mi fu
Translate: To this question I was answered

Original: «Priega Matelda che ’l ti dica»
Translate: Pray Matelda to explain it to you.

Original: E qui rispuose, come fa chi da colpa si dislega, la bella donna
Translate: And at this point the beautiful woman, like the one who apologizes for a guilt, answered

Original: «Questo e altre cose dette li son per me
Translate: I've already explained this and other things to him.

Original: e son sicura che l’acqua di Letè non gliel nascose»
Translate: And I am sure that the water of the Lete hath not erased in him the remembrance of it.

Original: E Bëatrice
Translate: And Beatrice

Original: «Forse maggior cura, che spesse volte la memoria priva, fatt’ ha la mente sua ne li occhi oscura
Translate: "Perhaps a greater concern, often devoid of memory, has clouded the eyes of his mind

Original: Ma vedi Eünoè che là diriva
Translate: But you see the Euno is born there

Original: menalo ad esso, e come tu se’ usa, la tramortita sua virtù ravviva»
Translate: lead him to the river and, as you used to do, revive his attenuated memory.

Original: Come anima gentil, che non fa scusa, ma fa sua voglia de la voglia altrui tosto che è per segno fuor dischiusa
Translate: Like a noble soul that doesn't make excuses, but embraces the desires of others as soon as these are made evident,

Original: così, poi che da essa preso fui, la bella donna mossesi, e a Stazio donnescamente disse
Translate: And when she had taken me by the hand, the beautiful woman arose, and said to St.

Original: «Vien con lui»
Translate: Come with him.

Original: S’io avessi, lettor, più lungo spazio da scrivere, i’ pur cantere’ in parte lo dolce ber che mai non m’avria sazio
Translate: If I, the reader, had more space to write, I would describe at least in part the sweet taste of the water of the One who would never have satisfied me

Original: ma perché piene son tutte le carte ordite a questa cantica seconda, non mi lascia più ir lo fren de l’arte
Translate: but since all the cards prepared for this second Song are now full, the brake of art does not allow me to continue

Original: Io ritornai da la santissima onda rifatto sì come piante novelle rinovellate di novella fronda,
Translate: I went away from the sacred river completely renewed, like the young plants that flourish and cover themselves with new branches,

Original: puro e disposto a salire a le stelle
Translate: purified and ready to rise to the stars
